choices.text: Aggregation with collagen and ADP is normal
Due to GP Ib IX receptor defect

questions.text: Which is not true regarding Bernard soulier syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Ristocetin aggregation is normal
 
  • Bernard-Soulier syndrome is a rare congenital bleeding disorder characterized by a defect in platelet function and decreased platelet adhesion.
  • Ristocetin-induced platelet aggregation is specifically impaired in Bernard-Soulier syndrome.
  • Ristocetin is a medication that induces platelet aggregation by causing the binding of von Willebrand factor (vWF) to platelet surface receptors.
  • In Bernard-Soulier syndrome, the affected platelets lack the glycoprotein Ib-IX-V complex, which is the receptor for vWF, resulting in abnormal platelet-vWF interactions and impaired aggregation.



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 120.

questions.text: What is the gold standard test for the diagnosis of Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH) is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Flow cytometry 
 
  • Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria is a rare, acquired disorder characterized by the deficiency of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)-anchored proteins on the cell surface.
  • Flow cytometry is used to detect and quantify the absence or reduced expression of GPI-anchored proteins, such as CD55 and CD59, on red blood cells, granulocytes, and monocytes.
  • This test is essential for confirming the diagnosis of PNH and assessing the extent of GPI-anchored protein deficiency.
  • Other tests, such as sucrose hemolysis and Ham test, can also provide supportive evidence for PNH diagnosis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 649.

questions.text: Which one of the following anemias has a raised MCV and normal MCHC?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Vitamin B12 and folic acid deficiency
 
  • Anemia refers to a decrease in the number of red blood cells or a decrease in hemoglobin levels, leading to reduced oxygen-carrying capacity.
  • Mean Corpuscular Volume (MCV) is a measure of the average size of red blood cells.
  • Vitamin B12 and folic acid deficiency anemias are macrocytic anemias, characterized by an increased MCV (> 100 fL).
  • In these anemias, the red blood cells are larger than normal, but the Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin Concentration (MCHC) remains within the normal range.
  • Other causes of macrocytic anemia, such as alcoholism and certain medications, can also be associated with an increased MCV.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 651.

questions.text: Which of the following anemias causes is linked to hypoplastic marrow?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Fanconi's anemia
 
  • Fanconi's anemia is a rare genetic disorder characterized by bone marrow failure, congenital abnormalities, and an increased risk of developing malignancies.
  • It is caused by mutations in genes involved in DNA repair mechanisms, leading to genomic instability.
  • The bone marrow in Fanconi's anemia patients may show hypoplasia or aplasia, meaning a decrease or absence of normal cellularity.
  • This bone marrow failure results in reduced production of all blood cell lineages, leading to pancytopenia.
  • Other features of Fanconi's anemia include physical abnormalities, such as skeletal malformations and characteristic facial features.
  • Other options - Primary Myelofibrosis has a proliferative and fibrotic phase, so hypercellular marrow is possible
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 314.

questions.text: Which of the following myeloproliferative illnesses is least likely to be linked to massive splenomegaly?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) ET
 
  • Essential Thrombocythemia is a chronic myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by an elevated platelet count in the absence of secondary causes.
  • While splenomegaly can occur in ET, it is typically modest and not massive compared to other myeloproliferative disorders.
  • Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML), PV and Primary Myelofibrosis (PMF) are myeloproliferative disorders that commonly present with massive splenomegaly.
  • In ET, the predominant feature is thrombocytosis, which can lead to an increased risk of thrombotic and hemorrhagic complications.



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 625.

questions.text: Except for______,  all of the following are linked to secondary hemochromatosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH)
 
  • Secondary hemochromatosis refers to iron overload resulting from chronic transfusions or increased iron absorption.
  • Thalassemia Major, Sideroblastic Anemia, and Hereditary Spherocytosis can lead to secondary hemochromatosis due to chronic ineffective erythropoiesis, which causes increased iron absorption from the gut and subsequent iron overload.
  • In contrast, Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH) is not directly associated with secondary hemochromatosis as it is primarily characterized by complement-mediated hemolysis rather than chronic erythropoiesis and iron overload. Moreover, blood transfusion is not required in PNH so it has less chances of developing secondary hemochromatosis. 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 848.

questions.text: A short but high frequency 5 Hz stimulation of perforating substance pathway in the hippocampus would result in
questions.solution:
A short high frequency 5 Hz stimulation of perforating substance pathway in the hippocampus would result in Long-term potentiation. 

Long term potentiation
Long-term potentiation is a fast-developing and prolonged enhancement of the postsynaptic potential response, after a brief period of rapidly repeated stimulation of the potentiation neuron. It occurs due to an accumulation of Ca2+ in the postsynaptic neuron
LTP is a type of synaptic plasticity where there is generation of new synapses associated with memory formation in hippocampus 



Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 140

questions.text: One can find which of these in Schwannoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Antoni A and Antoni B pattern

* Histology of Schwannoma:

Biphasic: Hypercellular/compact Antoni A areas + hypocellular/myxoid Antoni B areas.

Verocay bodies (Nuclear palisading around the fibrillary process)- seen in cellular area. 



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1237.

questions.text: Serum levels that are suggestive of lithium toxicity:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 2 mEq/L

Therapeutic range 0.8-1.2 mEq/L
Levels above 1.5 mEq/L are considered toxic. Hence, option (1) is the most appropriate answer.

* [Extra Edge]: Lithium


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 476.

choices.text: Stop levetiracetam and start on a different antiepileptic
Discontinue the drug as he is seizure free
Slowly taper the drug over next 6 months
Continue levetiracetam since a 5-year seizure free interval is needed

questions.text: A patient who has a history of epilepsy, is currently taking levetiracetam 1 gm BD. He has been seizure-free for two years, but the drug use caused him to become agitated and angry, which interfered with his day-to-day activities. Which should be the next best step?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Slowly taper the drug over next 6 months
Levetiracetam is a broad spectrum anti seizure medication whose mechanism of action involves modulation of neurotransmitter release by binding to synaptic vesicle glycoprotein 2A.
  • Levetiracetam can cause neuropsychiatric side effects such as agitation and anger in some individuals.
  • Since the patient’s quality of life is significantly affected by these side effects, discontinuing levetiracetam and switching to another antiepileptic drug with a different mechanism of action may be necessary.
 
  • The mood changes seen in this patient are likely a result of an adverse effect of levetiracetam. Abrupt discontinuation of the medication could lead to rebound seizures. Therefore, the optimal management approach is to gradually taper the drug over the next 6 months.
 

Adverse effects of levetiracetam include:

  • Somnolence
  • Asthenia
  • Ataxia
  • Dizziness
  • Mood and behavioral changes
  • Psychotic reactions (rare)


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 447, 449.
Katzung Basic and Clinical Pharmacology, 13th edition, Page no 407.

questions.text: What is the most frequently used shunt for hydrocephalus?
questions.solution:
Therapy for hydrocephalus depends on the cause.
  • Medical management, including the use of acetazolamide and furosemide, can provide temporary relief by reducing the rate of CSF production, but long-term results have been disappointing.
  • Most cases of hydrocephalus require extracranial shunts, particularly a ventriculoperitoneal shunt.
  • Endoscopic third ventriculostomy (ETV) has evolved as a viable approach and criteria have been developed for its use, but the procedure might need to be repeated to be effective.
 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 578
 Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3080

questions.text: In what stage of sleep are K-complexes and sleep spindles visible?
questions.solution:
K-complexes: High voltage biphasic waves (single wave with both positive and negative components).
Sleep spindles: 1-2 s bursts of 12-14 Hz activity in the brain.

Both the above-mentioned features are of Stage 2 of NREM sleep.




Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 268-272

questions.text: Identify the acessory protein indicated in the diagram below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Alpha actinin

The star in image shows Z line. 

Z- line 
The Z line is mostly made up of alpha-actinin homodimers arranged in an antiparallel pattern,
which serves as a framework for the insertion of thin filaments made of actin, titin, and nebulin/nebulette.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 1804.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is responsible for Heterochromia iridis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Latanoprost

Among the given options, latanoprost is known to cause heterochromia iridis. 

* Hypochromic
Idiopathic congenital
Horner syndrome, particularly if congenital
Waardenburg syndrome

* Hyperchromic
Unilateral use of a topical prostaglandin analogue for glaucoma
Oculodermal melanocytosis (naevus of Ota)
Oculodermal melanocytosis (naevus of Ota)
Ocular siderosis
Diffuse iris naevus or melanoma
Struge-Weber syndrome

* Hypo or hyperchromic
Fuchs uveitis syndrome
Other chronic anterior uveitides

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 169.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in myasthenia gravis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Absent DTRs
 
  • Deep tendon reflexes (DTRs) are usually preserved in myasthenia gravis.
  • However, if the weakness is severe, it may be difficult to elicit DTRs due to inadequate muscle response.
Myasthenia gravis is an acquired autoimmune disorder where autoantibodies act against the nicotinic post synaptic receptors causing blockade of neuromuscular transmission which results in symmetric proximal predominant weakness of limbs along with occular and bulbar symptoms








Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3510, 3511.

questions.text: Gram-positive bacilli were discovered during a CSF test of a neonate who had meningitis. Which of the following organisms is most likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
Listeria monocytogenes is a Gram-positive bacillus and a well-known cause of neonatal meningitis. It is typically transmitted vertically from mother to baby during delivery or in utero.

Other options
  1. Streptococcus pneumoniae: Gram-positive cocci (not bacilli), more common in older children and adults.
  2. Hemophilus influenzae: Gram-negative bacillus, typically associated with older children upto 3-5 years after the neonatal period.
  3. Neisseria meningitidis: Gram-negative diplococcus, more common in older children and most common cause in adolescents and adults.


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3223-3232

questions.text: Which of these mediates attention and concentration?
questions.solution:
Attention and concentration are functions of the Frontal Lobe. 
Hypothalamus mediates and controls body temperature, hunger and thirst, mood, sex drive, blood pressure and sleep
Parietal Lobe functions include sensory perception and integration which includes touch, pain, temperature, and the sense of limb.
Basal Ganglia Functions include motor control and learning, executive functions along with behaviors/emotions.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 270

questions.text: The microscopic appearance of schwannoma—a nerve sheath tumour most typically involving the cerebellopontine angle—is seen below. What does the region shown with arrow represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Antony A pattern

The microscopic appearance of schwannoma typically shows a pattern known as Antony A pattern. This pattern consists of spindle cells arranged in a palisading pattern with nuclear alignment.
Therefore, the correct answer is 2. Antony A pattern.

The hypercellular part - Antoni A containing Verouccay bodies
The hypocellular area - Antoni B


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1237.

questions.text: Which of the following has an acrid or a pear odour?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Paraldehyde

Paraldehyde is a clear, colorless liquid with an unpleasant ethereal odour, and an acrid nauseous taste. It is used as a hypnotic by mouth, rectum or parenterally and as a basal anesthetic.



Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, 33rd edition, Page No 591.
Online Reference: 
PubChem [Internet]. Bethesda (MD): National Library of Medicine (US), National Center for Biotechnology Information; 2004-. PubChem Compound Summary for CID 31264, Paraldehyde; [cited 2024 Sept. 15]. Available from: https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Paraldehyde

questions.text: Which of the following complications after a stroke doesn't require medical intervention?
questions.solution:
Correct option: Neglect (Option 4) > Spasticity (Option 2)
Controversial Question

Neglect is a common feature of stroke that often does not require treatment.
While neglect can indicate a poor prognosis, most patients show recovery without intervention within 1 to 6 months.

Other options:
 
  • Fever (Option 1) is harmful in stroke patients and needs to be addressed.
  • Dysphagia (Option 3) presents a significant risk of aspiration and should not be ignored.
  • Spasticity (Option 2) can be managed with medications such as baclofen or tizanidine, as untreated spasticity can have a negative psychosocial impact on patients.
 
  • Neglect can result from damage to the cortical-limbic-reticular network, which is responsible for directing attention and integrating the localization and identification of stimuli. Although neglect is linked to poorer outcomes and slower recovery, severe cases are uncommon beyond 6 months. Recovery is typically rapid in the first two weeks, regardless of which side the stroke affects, and by three months, patients may still experience some residual visual neglect. Treatment options for neglect depend on its underlying mechanisms; for instance, patients with underaroused right hemispheres may struggle to process sensory inputs.
 
  • Spasticity occurs in fewer than 20% of stroke patients, and those with bilateral weakness from hypoxic injury are more likely to exhibit signs of spasticity. Symptoms such as exaggerated cutaneous and autonomic reflexes and involuntary spasms can be quite disabling. Physical therapies like slow stretching and daily passive exercises can help alleviate spasticity and prevent contractures. Medications like baclofen, tizanidine, and clonidine are effective in reducing clonus and extensor spasms.



Reference: Bradley’s Neurology in Clinical Practice, 7th Edition, Page no 829, 830, 832-845.

questions.text: In the image below, which of the following congenital defects can be seen?
questions.solution:
The figure shows a skin-covered, brilliantly transilluminate defect in the back in a newborn. This is typical of a meningocele.
  • Meninges herniate through a gap in the posterior vertebral arches and result in a meningocele.
  • Although tethering, syringomyelia, or diastematomyelia may occur, the spinal cord often assumes a normal position in the spinal canal and is in a normal state.
  • Along the vertebral column, typically in the low back, is a fluctuant midline mass that may transilluminate.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No  3066,3067

questions.text: Which method from the list below is used to examine current flow within a single ion channel?
questions.solution:
The Patch Clamp technique can be used to study the current across a few or a single ion channel. Only a few transport proteins(possibly even one) are typically present in the membrane patch beneath the pipette tip, enabling a thorough biophysical analysis of these proteins.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 49,50

questions.text: Investigation of a patient with bilateral proptosis determine the diagnosis using the region's biopsy that has been provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Schwannoma
 
  • The given histopathological slide along with clinical features goes in favor of schwannoma. 
  • Schwannomas often abut orbital apertures, and patients present with nonspecific symptoms such as progressive painless proptosis.
  • On histopathological examination, in the Antoni A pattern of growth, elongated cells with cytoplasmic processes are organized in fascicles in regions of moderate to high cellularity and substantial stromal matrix.
  • The "nuclear-free cones" of processes that lie in between the regions of nuclear palisading are known as Verocay bodies.
  • A loose meshwork of cells, microcysts, and myxoid stroma make up the Antoni B pattern of head and neck tumors, which are less densely cellular.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1237.

questions.text: Which anticonvulsant causes the vision field to contract?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Vigabatrin

  • The retinal nerve fiber layer suffers from permanent widespread atrophy brought on by vigabatrin.
  • The outside region of the retina is mainly affected by this (as opposed to the macular or central region), which causes contraction of visual field.
  • Taurine depletion may be the cause of vigabatrin's retinal toxicity.
* Audio Explanation:


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 448.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man had a history of fall and along with one episode of vomiting following which he had certain memory disturbances. On evaluation at a nearby hospital he was found to have anterograde amnesia. which of the following structures are most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Hippocampus
Anterograde amnesia is the inability to create new memories after an event that caused amnesia, leading to a partial or complete inability to recall the recent past , while long term memories from before the event remain intact. 

Anterograde amnesia can occur from damage caused to the structures involving the Papez circuit.




Reference: Bradley  Neurology in clinical practice, 8th edition, Chapter 7 page 63

questions.text: A sick intubated neonate is having bilateral jerks of both right/left and upper limbs with some occasional twitching of the neck as well. Likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Multifocal clonic seizure is the most likely seizure in a patient who has bilateral jerks of both their right and left upper limbs as well as occasional neck twitching."
  •  Several bodily sections are involved in multifocal clonic seizures, which are migratory in character.
  • The migration has a non-Jacksonian pattern, meaning that jerks in the left arm can be associated with jerks in the right leg."

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3111

questions.text: Suppose you are examining a patient's knee-jerk reflex. Deep tendon reflexes' afferents are transported by

questions.text: Where can we find Verocay bodies?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Schwannoma 
 
  • Schwannoma (neurilemoma) is typically a solitary tumor, most commonly located on the flexor surfaces of the extremities, neck, mediastinum, retroperitoneum, posterior spinal roots, and cerebellopontine angle.
  • Grossly, larger schwannomas often contain cystic areas.
  • Microscopically, there are two different patterns, designated as type A and type B.
  • In type A, the cells are spindle-shaped and arranged in a palisading or organoid formation aka Verocay bodies.
  • In type B, the cells are separated by edematous fluid that can form cystic spaces. Ancient schwannomas may contain isolated cells with bizarre hyperchromatic nuclei, though these are of no particular significance.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1237.

questions.text: Which of the following effects of valproate is exclusive to gender?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) polycystic ovarian syndrome

The most frequent side effects of valproate are "nausea (22%)" and "drowsiness (19%)."
Vomiting (12%), dizziness (12%), and weakness (10%)

* Severe side effects are:

  • Bleeding
  • reduced blood platelets
  • Encephalopathy
  • Suicidal actions and ideas
  • decreased body temperature

* Valproic acid may raise the risk of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) in females with epilepsy or bipolar disorder, according to some data.

* Audio Explanation:


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 444.

questions.text: Where is hypertensive haemorrhage most commonly seen?
questions.solution:
• Hypertensive ICH usually results from spontaneous rupture of a small penetrating artery deep in the brain.
  • The most common sites are the basal ganglia (especially the putamen), thalamus, cerebellum, and pons.
  • The small arteries in these areas seem most prone to hypertension-induced vascular injury.
 
  • ICH accounts for ~10% of all strokes, and ~35–45% of patients die within the first month. Incidence rates are particularly high in Asians and blacks.
  • Hypertension, coagulopathy, sympathomimetic drugs (cocaine, methamphetamine), and cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA) cause most of these hemorrhages.



Transaxial NCCT Brain showing Hypertensive basal ganglia hemorrhage



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3349.

questions.text: On CT brain, a neonate was found to have periventricular calcification.What is the most effective method of diagnosing this etiological agent?
questions.solution:
Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection results in periventricular calcification.
  • Urine and saliva are the best specimens for culture while saliva and cord blood are the best for PCR in the diagnosis of congenital CMV infection.
  • Urine is the best choice out of the ones provided. Within 2-3 weeks. 
  • Definitive diagnosis: Viral isolation or PCR showing CMV DNA (done during the first 1–2 weeks of life).


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 264,265

3. Hypertension

questions.text: According to histopathology, rosettes are not present in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Neurocysticercosis 

Out of the given options, Neurocysticercosis do no show rosettes.
a. Retinoblastoma has Flexer-Wintersteiner rosettes.
b. Ewing sarcoma has Homer-Wright rosettes.
c. Ependymoma has round rosettes or elongated canals.
d. Medulloblastoma shows Homer Wright or neuroblastic rosette

questions.text: Which of the following side effects increases when valproate is used with carbamazepine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Hepatotoxicity

The risk of hepatotoxicity increases if carbamazepine is used along with valproate.
  • By way of CYP450 enzymes, valproate is converted into the hepatotoxic minor metabolite 2-propyl-4-pentenoic acid (4-ene-VPA).
  • The microsomal enzymes can be induced, and the production of this metabolite increased by enzyme inducers like carbamazepine, phenytoin, and phenobarbital.
Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 416.

choices.text: Put a handkerchief in his mouth and restrain him by holding hands and legs
Take him away from the train, give him medicine with small sips of water and wait for seizure to resolve
Take him away from the train, give him medicine with small sips of water and raise his legs and wait for seizure to resolve
Take him away from the train, make him lie down and call for the hospital

questions.text: While waiting for the train, a passenger started having seizures at the train station. It was discovered that he wears a wristband identifying him as an epilepsy patient who has a medication in his pocket. What are your next actions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Take him away from the train, make him lie down and call for the hospital

Take him away from the train, make him lie down, and call for medical assistance or the hospital.
If someone is having a seizure, the following steps can be taken:
  1. Ensure the person's safety: Move the individual away from any potential dangers or hazards, such as sharp objects or traffic.
  2. Support their head and protect them: Cushion their head with something soft to prevent injury during the seizure. It is important not to restrain the person or put anything in their mouth.
  3. Clear the area: Create space around the person by moving objects and people away. This helps prevent accidental contact during the seizure.
  4. Time the seizure: Note the start time of the seizure. If the seizure lasts longer than five minutes or if the person has difficulty breathing, it is crucial to call for emergency medical assistance immediately.
  5. After the seizure: Once the seizure ends, check the person's responsiveness and breathing. If they are not responsive or are having difficulty breathing, perform CPR if you are trained to do so or wait for medical professionals to arrive.
  6. Nothing should be administered in the mouth during active seizure episode as it may lead to aspiration of contents.



Reference: First Aid for Seizures, CDC guidelines (2024), URL: https://www.cdc.gov/epilepsy/first-aid-for-seizures/index.html

choices.text: Generalized Tonic-Clonic Seizure on going to sleep

questions.text: What is the most typical presentation of JME(Janz syndrome)?
questions.solution:
Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME) typically begins in childhood or adolescence.
  • The most common clinical presentation of JME is myoclonus (involuntary muscle jerking or twitching), generally most prominent when waking up.
  • When the myoclonus occurs along with other seizure types more frequently and lasts more than a short duration, the diagnosis of JME is more secure.
  • Other seizure types that can occur with JME are tonic-clonic (grand mal), absence (petit mal) and tonic seizures.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3098

questions.text: Where can you see free nerve endings carrying nociceptive fibers?

The afferent innervations from the mesentery are provided by spinal afferent fibers which are free nerve endings

choices.text: One in 10 people age 65 and older has Alzheimer’s disease.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Alzheimer's disease is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Alzheimer’s disease is curable.
 
  • The incorrect statement is B. Alzheimer's disease is curable.
  • Alzheimer's disease is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder that causes memory loss, cognitive decline, and behavioral changes.
  • Currently, there is no cure for Alzheimer's disease, but various treatments and interventions can help manage symptoms and slow down its progression.

Drug is slowly tapered off after Continuing for 2 years.

* [Extra Edge]: Withdrawal of Antiepileptic drugs - 
  • Seizure free period of 2 years 
  • Normal CNS examination 
  • Normal EEG and normal MRI
  • Single seizure type
  • No F/H/O seizure

questions.text: Which of the following diseases saw the first reduction in a single neurotransmitter's levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Parkinson's disease

Parkinson's disease was the first among the diseases that have reduction in a single neurotransmitter's levels.
It is caused due to degeneration  of dopaminergic neurons in the Substantia nigra.

questions.text: A child with recurrent seizures, glaucoma, and palpable plaques in the Ophthalmic and Maxillary distribution. Mother complained, it is present since birth and has not changed since then. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Sturge-Weber syndrome, or encephalotrigeminal angiomatosis, is a phakomatosis characterized by facial port wine stains and pial angiomas. 

  • The most common clinical manifestation is with childhood seizures, present in 71-89% of cases.
  • These usually begin in the first few years of life and are often associated with developmental delay and hemispheric symptoms including hemiplegia/hemiparesis and hemianopsia.
  • Approximately a third of patients have choroidal or scleral angiomatous involvement, which may be complicated by retinal detachment, buphthalmos or glaucoma.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3146-3148

questions.text: Which of the following chronic illnesses exhibits degenerative changes in the brain that are not a result of ageing normally?
questions.solution:
Best option among this is amnestic syndrome, this is a condition causing brain damage due to injury, alcohol abuse or neurological condition.

Other options: -
  • Dementia occurs from normal ageing process of brain
  • delirium is an acute and reversible condition risk factors being old age and cognitive decline.
  • Pseudodementia is the memory loss that occurs in severe depression

questions.text: Swelling in the wrist joint of a 20 aged patient. Histopathology exhibits spindle cells and verocay bodies most likely to be diagnosed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Schwannoma

  • Schwannoma is a benign neural tumor made up of Schwann cells, which are cells that are typically located in the peripheral nervous system which are the nerves that run from the central nervous system to the extremities.
  • It can be found in solitary or multiple forms, depending on if it is associated with a type 2 Recklinghausen disease.
  • It usually develops on flexed surfaces of limbs, neck, mediastinum, retroperitoneum, posterior spinal roots, and the cerebellopontine angle. Schwannomas are linked to the NF2 gene located on chromosome 22q12 and codes for merlin.
  • In microscopic examination, these tumors typically have an Antoni A (cellular) and an Antoni B (hypocellular) pattern. They can also have Verocay bodies, which are unique structures.
  • There are other types, like melanotic and cellular schwannomas, as well as psammomatous melanotic schwannomas which are components of the Carney complex. Immunohistochemistry shows S-100 protein, calretinin, and calcineurin present in Schwannomas.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1237.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions should morphine not be given to a patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Biliary colic
 
  • Morphine can cause contraction of sphincter of Oddi and biliary spasm; hence it can worsen pain of biliary colic and is not used for the same.
  • The opioids can cause biliary colic by tightening the biliary smooth muscle and
  • As a result of the sphincter of Oddi constricting, biliary and pancreatic secretions may reflux, and plasma amylase and lipase levels may rise.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 500.

questions.text: A 15 year old boy presented with headache vomiting and altered sensorium. On probing his parents gave a history of recent URTI after swimming at a near by pond.  He was diagnosed to have meningitis and he succumbed to his illness on day five.  What is the most likely etiological agent among the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Naegleria fowleri
 
  • Naegleria fowleri is a free-living amoeba that can cause a rare but severe infection of the central nervous system called primary amebic meningoencephalitis (PAM).
  • It is commonly associated with warm freshwater environments such as lakes and hot springs. Infections occur when contaminated water enters the nasal passages and allows the amoeba to reach the brain.
  • The symptoms of Naegleria fowleri infection typically include a severe headache, high fever, neck stiffness, and often purulent nasal discharge.
  • The infection progresses rapidly and can lead to coma and death within a few days.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1718, 1719.

questions.text: Young child was brought to the OPD with difficulty in walking. Below is the image of his legs. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image above shows calf pseudohypertrophy, an abnormal expansion of the calves by fibrofatty proliferation
  • It is a hallmark of Duchenne muscular dystrophy, the most prevalent kind of muscular dystrophy.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3281-3284

questions.text: Which of these is not carried by the dorsal column?
questions.solution:
All of the above sensations except PAIN are carried by the dorsal column. Pain sensations are carried by the lateral spinothalamic tract present in the Lateral column.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 165,166

choices.text: There is loss of function type of mutation
It is a trinucleotide expansion mutation related disorder
Abnormality is seen due to mutation in chromosome

questions.text: Select the accurate option for Huntington 's Chorea.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) It is a trinucleotide expansion mutation related disorder
 
  • Huntington Disease (HD) is an autosomal dominant movement disorder caused by CAG trinucleotide repeat expansions in a gene located on 4p16.3, which encodes the protein huntington.
  • The number of repeats increases with each generation, causing an earlier onset in subsequent generations. Clinically, HD presents with a triad of motor, cognitive, and psychiatric symptoms, including involuntary jerky movements, dementia, behavioural changes, and an increased risk of suicide.
  • Pathologically, HD is characterized by atrophy of the caudate nucleus and putamen as well as the loss of neurons and the accumulation of intranuclear inclusions containing ubiquitin. It is most commonly transmitted from father to child.
Memorizing Trick: -
Hunter- CAGE
Huntington- CAG repeats
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1285.

questions.text: A patient complained of pain in the right lower quadrant of his abdomen. He has a history of right kidney stones. He was given an opioid, which is both a partial agonist mu and an antagonist at kappa receptors. What was the most likely medication administered?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Buprenorphine
 
  • Buprenorphine is partial agonist at mu and antagonist at kappa
  • Pentazocine is full agonist at kappa and antagonist at mu
* [Extra Edge]: Nature of interaction of opioid ligands with the three major types of opioid receptors




Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 510.

questions.text: The H-reflex can be used to diagnose
questions.solution:
The H-reflex (or Hoffmann's reflex) is used primarily to diagnose S1 radiculopathy.
 
  • An H-reflex is a spinal reflex that involves both sensory and motor fibers. It's a sensitive test that can be used to assess radiculopathy.
  • During an H-reflex test, the tibial nerve in the popliteal fossa is stimulated to elicit a monosynaptic S1 reflex response.
  • It assesses the integrity of the S1 nerve root by measuring the electrical response of the muscle following stimulation of the sensory nerve.
  • In evaluating radiculopathy, a unilateral absent H reflex or a side-to-side latency difference greater than 2.0 ms supports a diagnosis of an S1 radiculopathy




Reference: Alrowayeh, Hesham N, and Mohamed A Sabbahi. “H-reflex amplitude asymmetry is an earlier sign of nerve root involvement than latency in patients with S1 radiculopathy.” BMC research notes vol. 4 102. 5 Apr. 2011, doi:10.1186/1756-0500-4-102. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3078869/

questions.text: Determine the sleep stage from the given picture.
questions.solution:
Sawtooth waves (as shown in the picture) corresponding to eye movements and EMG flat is seen in REM sleep

Features of REM sleep:
  • Light phase of sleep, but arousal is difficult
  • Mixed frequency, low amplitude waves on EEG. Pre- dominantly beta like activity.
  • Also known as Desynchronized or paradoxical sleep
  • Dreaming is seen
  • Active sleep

Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 272

questions.text: Slow conduction of the motor and sensory pathway in multiple sclerosis is due to which of the following reasons?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Loss of myelin sheath

  • Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disorder of the central nervous system (CNS) caused by chronic inflammation and resulting in demyelination, gliosis (plaques or scarring) and neuronal loss.
  • The disease can progress in a relapsing or progressive manner.
  • The myelin sheath, which facilitates nerve conduction, is affected, causing conduction block and hyperpolarization of the nerve axon. To compensate, the sodium channels redistribute, allowing for continuous propagation through the demyelinated section.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1269.

choices.text: Lamotrigine acts by opening of GABA mediated Cl-channels

questions.text: What is false about antiepileptics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Lamotrigine acts by opening of GABA mediated Cl-channels
 
  • The main mechanism of action of lamotrigine is inactivation of voltage gated sodium channels.
  • It also stabilizes presynaptic neuronal membrane and prevents pre-synaptic release of aspartate and glutamate. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 446.

questions.text: What is the time frame for thrombolysis in a stroke patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: 4.5 hours
  • Thrombolysis, or the administration of clot-dissolving medication, is a treatment option for acute ischemic stroke.
  • The recommended time window for thrombolysis is within 4.5 hours from the onset of stroke symptoms.
  • Initiating thrombolysis within this time frame can help improve blood flow to the affected area of the brain and potentially minimize long-term disability.

NOTE: Current recommendations state IV rTPA efficacy to extend from 4.5 hours to 6 hours.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3337.

questions.text: A 13 years old male child presented with abnormal body movements with MRI showing Abnormal T2 hyperintensity in the putamen. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Most likely diagnosis is Wilson's disease.

  • Wilson disease has an autosomal recessive mode of inheritance and is characterized by tremors, rigidity, dementia, and pseudobulbar features. 
  • A Kayser-Fleischer ring may be discovered during a slit-lamp examination of the eyes. 
  • MRI in Wilson disease is characterized by high-intensity lesions in the basal ganglia, thalami, and midbrain on T2-weighted images.
  • The typical 'face-of-the-giant-panda' sign is caused by the normal low intensity of red nuclei and SN surrounded by abnormal high-signal intensity in the tegmentum of the mid brain. 
  • The best diagnostic clue is symmetrical T2 hyperintensity or mixed intensity in the putamen (with hyperintense putaminal rim) and globus pallidus, as well as the caudate nuclei and thalami.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2103-2105

questions.text: Which of the following is regulated using a feed-forward control system?
questions.solution:
Feed forward control system is employed during the regulation of temperature. Our bodies have a control mechanism that nevertheless anticipates and makes adjustments when no stimulus is present. A system like this is known as feed forward, anticipatory control, or adaptive control. Temperature control : The hypothalamus starts the thermoregulatory reactions before the changes in external temperature really cause the body's core temperature to change

 

Reference- Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition Page nos: 8-10

questions.text: Which of the following is most common form of muscular dystrophies
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) DMD
 
  • Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) is the most common hereditary neuromuscular disorder, occurring in an estimated 1 in 3,600 live born infant boys. It is caused by an abnormal gene located at the Xp21.2 locus, which encodes a 427-kDa cytoskeletal protein called dystrophin.
  • The most common molecular defect in DMD is a deletion of the gene, which may be followed by duplication or point mutations. Some female carriers, or affected girls, can experience a mild form of the disorder, due to the Lyon Hypothesis which states that the normal X chromosome becomes silenced, and the one with the gene deletion is active. Girls with Turner Syndrome, a disorder caused by a single X chromosome, have a gene deletion at the Xp21 locus.
  • Characteristic clinical features of DMD includes progressive muscle weakness, intellectual impairment, hypertrophy of the calves, and proliferation of connective tissue in the muscle. Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD) is similar to DMD, but usually has a milder phenotype.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1232.

questions.text: Blood alcohol level of an alcoholic with poor judgment and decreased in skilled movements would be:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) 80-200 mg/dl
 
  • Alcohol intoxication occurs when an individual has consumed a large enough quantity of alcohol to raise their blood alcohol content level past the legal limit of 0.08%.
  • At blood alcohol levels between 80-200 mg/dl, the individual will exhibit a number of impairments, primarily related to motor coordination and judgment. These impairments may include slurred speech, blurred vision, and unstable balance, poor judgment, and lack of coordination.
  • At higher levels of intoxication > 300 mg/dl, more serious impairments can occur, such as unconsciousness, coma, and even death in extreme cases.
* [Extra Edge]: Serum Ethanol level Vs Symptoms



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 522.

questions.text: Which is the most specific sign of metabolic encephalopathy?
questions.solution:
Although asterixis on the motor examination is vague, it typically points to a toxic or metabolic cause of the delirium.

It is a disorder of motor control, defined as sudden, brief, arrhythmic lapses of sustained posture due to involuntary interruption in muscle contraction.
This condition involves a specific form of negative myoclonus, characterized by momentary loss of muscle tone in agonist muscles, followed by a compensatory jerk involving antagonistic muscles
 
  • Bilateral asterixis is a sure symptom of metabolic encephalopathy or drug intoxication in a sleepy and disoriented patient.
  • However, Most common symptom of Metabolic encephalopathy is Delirium.
Other symptoms include:
  • Hallucinations
  • Involuntary movements (tremors)
  • Seizures
  • Difficulty breathing
  • Loss of consciousness
  • Nausea
  • Fatigue and difficulty sleeping (insomnia)
  • Depression 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 186.
Agarwal, R, and R Baid. “Asterixis.” Journal of postgraduate medicine vol. 62,2 (2016): 115-7. doi:10.4103/0022-3859.180572. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4944342/

questions.text:
An eight-year-old boy experiences increased physical weakness. His calves are thick and exhibit muscle tightening after examination. His serum creatine kinase levels rise with ageing.
Which of the following diagnoses is more likely?
questions.solution:
• Most likely diagnosis is Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy due to Dystrophin deficiency.
  • DMD typically starts in early childhood (around 2-5 years of age).
    • It begins with weakness in the proximal muscles (those closer to the trunk), especially in the legs and pelvis, leading to difficulty with running, climbing stairs, and walking.
    • Over time, it affects other muscle groups, leading to generalized muscle wasting.

  • Gowers' Sign: This is a classic sign where the child uses their hands and arms to "climb up" their own body to stand up from a sitting or lying position due to weakness in the hip and thigh muscles.

  • Calf Muscle Pseudohypertrophy: The calves often appear large and muscular due to the replacement of muscle tissue with fat and fibrous tissue, a phenomenon called pseudohypertrophy.

  • Elevated Creatine Kinase (CK) Levels: Blood levels of CK, an enzyme released by damaged muscles, are significantly elevated in DMD patients, sometimes up to 10-100 times the normal range, even before symptoms appear.

  • Cardiac and Respiratory Complications: As DMD progresses, it affects the heart muscles, leading to cardiomyopathy and heart failure. Respiratory muscles also become weak, leading to breathing difficulties and an increased risk of respiratory infections, typically in the teenage years or early adulthood.



    Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3281-3284

choices.text: Alpha motor neurons are activated first followed by gamma motor neurons
Gamma motor neurons are activated first followed by alpha motor neurons

questions.text: Which statement about alpha and gamma motor neurons during the initiation of voluntary movements is correct?
questions.solution:
Both alpha as well as gamma motor neurons fire in response to excitatory input from spinal motor circuits.
Intrafusal and extrafusal fibers contract concurrently as a result of this "a—y coactivation," allowing spindle afferent activity to continue throughout the duration of muscle contraction.
By doing this, the spindle maintains its capacity to react to stretch and reflexively modify a-motor neuron discharge.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 236,237

questions.text: A 75-year-old man arrives at the OPD with a left-sided testicular tumor and ataxia. What is the most likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Non-Hodgkins lymphoma
 
  • According to the given history the patient is most likely to have Non - Hodgkin’s Lymphoma.
  • Non - Hodgkin’s Lymphoma can involve extra nodal tissues (testes, GIT, brain, etc) and hence it is the most likely answer for this question. Glioblastoma is seen in the brain and it rarely metastasises to the testes.
  • Non - seminomatous Germ Cell Tumour can present with testicular swelling but ataxia is less likely. Hodgkin’s Lymphoma usually presents with cervical lymphadenopathy, it rarely involves extra nodal tissues.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 592.

questions.text: Select the drug that can be used in benzodiazepine toxicity.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Flumazenil

Flumazenil is a competitive inhibitor of BZD, hence is used in cases of its toxicity.

Flumazenil abolishes the hypnogenic, psychomotor, cognitive and EEG effects of BZDs.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 435.

questions.text: In which of the following aphasias naming and fluency are impaired?
questions.solution:
Broca's aphasia:
Preserved comprehension (except grammar) with impaired naming and fluency. 
Brocas aphasia is caused  due to damage to the inferior frontal lobe of the brain's dominant hemisphere, made up of Brodmann areas 44 and 45. 





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 196, 197.

questions.text: Newborn with meningomyelocele has been listed for surgery. The defect should be repaired right away with:
questions.solution:
Meningomyelocele is a caudal NTD which requires prompt and correct management from a skilled team in order to improve the chances of survival.
  • Surgical correction should be performed within 48 hours of delivery, and the infant should be placed in a prone position with a non-adherent, sterile saline dressing and a plastic shield wrap in order to maintain moisture and protect the defect from drying, trauma, and infection.Saline dressing helps to keep the exposed neural tissue moist and prevents infection while minimizing irritation
  • Early treatment and support will provide the best chance of recovery.



Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3066-3068

questions.text: What does pink box in the given image represent?
questions.solution:
The Pink box shows EEG with High amplitude, low frequency waves, EMG with Moderate muscle tone and EOG showing Minimal eye movement - all of which are suggestive of NREM. 



Here is a table summarising the findings of EEG/EMG and EOG in awake/NREM and REM State. 
 


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 272

questions.text: A patient presented with meningitis, four-day fever, and erythematous rashes on the chest. There was no previous travel or tick bite history. Increased protein, normal glucose, moderate lymphocytosis and  presence of RBCs were all observed in the CSF. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Enterovirus

Meningitis with CSF parameters of normal glucose, increased protein and lymphocytosis goes in favor of viral meningitis due to enterovirus. 
  • Option A- West Nile virus is endemic in North America but since there is no history of travel, we rule out this option.
  • Option B- Bacterial meningitis will have increased protein and WBC count with predominant neutrophils and decreased CSF glucose levels. Gram staining will show gram positive lanceolate shaped diplococci. 
  • Option C- Meningococcal meningitis will also have increased protein and WBC count with predominant neutrophils and decreased CSF glucose levels. Gram staining will show gram negative diplococci. 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 351.

questions.text:
Which is the incorrect match about anti-epileptic drugs ?
1st line drugs Second line drugs
Focal seizure Lamotrigine, CBZ, Phenytoin Valproate
Absence seizure CBZ Ethosuximide, Valproate
Myoclonic seizure  valproate, Lamotrigine Clonazepam
GTCS Valproate, Lamotrigine, Topiramate Phenytoin, CBZ
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) 2

The first line drug in Absence seizure is Ethosuximide.
Lamotrigine, Clonazepam, Zonisamide and Levetiracetam can be used as second line Drugs.
Thus option 2 is the incorrect match.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 443.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child complained of having trouble combing his hair and climbing stairs. on examination bilateral calves were enlarged. His mother also gave a history that the child has been toe walking since a few days. What comes next in the diagnostic process?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Creatine kinase levels

The above mentioned clinical features points to a diagnosis of Proximal myopathy most probably associated with Duchenne Muscular dystrophy (DMD).

Clinical features include: 
  • Proximal muscles, especially of the lower extremities, are prominently involved.
  • This becomes evident in DMD very early; boys with DMD have difficulty climbing stairs and never run well.
  • As the disease progresses, weakness becomes more generalized. Hypertrophy of muscles, particularly in the calves, is an early and prominent finding.

 
  • The initial preferred muscle enzyme to evaluate when assessing myopathies is Creatine Kinase (CK) levels.
  • The CK leaks from the muscle fibre to the serum as a result of muscle damage.
  • CK is the most sensitive measure of muscle damage. The MM isoenzyme predominates in skeletal muscle, whereas CK-myocardial bound (CK-MB) is the marker for cardiac muscle.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3520, 3521.

questions.text: In a child of Rett syndrome, all of the following are seen except:
questions.solution:
• Rett syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder caused due to MECP2 gene mutation that begins soon after birth and manifests around 1-2 years of age.
  • Its almost exclusively seen in females.
  • It is characterized by a neurodevelopmental regression(slowing of cognitive, social, and physical development) sudden behavior changes, and repetitive hand movements/autistic behavior.
  • Other features include seizures, slowed head growth causing microcephaly (NOT Macrocephaly as mentioned in option 1), difficulties with motor coordination, and scoliosis.
  • Trofinetide(Tripeptide - (Gly - Pro - Glu) - analog of the neuropeptide (1-3) IGF-1) is a new drug used for its treatment.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3192,3193

questions.text: Which NT mediates the Bezold-Jarisch reflex?
questions.solution:
Serotonin mediates the Bezold-Jerish reflex.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 581

questions.text: Which nerve is obstructed in the following picture?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Nasociliary nerve
 
* Nasociliary nerve block- Close to the ethmoidal foramen, the nasociliary nerve is blocked before it splits into nasal branches of the anterior ethmoidal nerve and the intratracheal nerve. 
  • Epinephrine-free solutions ought to be applied here to reduce the risk of retinal artery spasm. 
  • One centimeter above the medial canthus, halfway between the posterior palpebral fold and the eyebrow, a 15–30 mm, 25–27-gauge intradermal needle is inserted. 
  • After that, it is aimed medially and backward in order to make contact with the orbit's bony roof. 
  • After a negative aspiration test, a maximum of 2 mL of local anesthetic solution is slowly injected at a depth of 1.5 cm, at the anterior ethmoidal foramen. The external nasal nerve can be blocked by continuously injecting while removing the needle. 
  • The finger's compression of the inferior angle of the eye helps the solution diffuse into the foramen.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 3438.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman is prescribed phenytoin and valproate after being diagnosed with epilepsy. She experienced a generalised rash all over her body four weeks later, which eventually went away after she stopped using both medications. When she is given another chance to take phenytoin and valproate, how many weeks will pass before the rash reappears?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 1 day
 
  • The situation given in the question appears to be of a hypersensitivity to Phenytoin.
  • This manifests in 3- to 4-week intervals. 
  • When the medication is retested, the mediators are already created and released considerably more quickly, resulting in the rash developing much more quickly.
Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 419.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of benign intracranial hypertension?
questions.solution:
Graves disease exhibits proptosis. Benign intracranial hypertension does not exhibit it.

Benign Intracranial Hypertension:  (a.k.a Pseudotumor cerebri)
  • Adult idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) is a rare condition of unknown cause, which results in raised intracranial pressure (ICP).
  •  Young obese women are most commonly affected, although rarely it may occur in men.
  • Patients first experience headaches, diplopia (typically from CN VI palsy), and unaltered mental status.
  • A diagnosis of IIH requires CSF opening pressure greater than 250 mmCSF



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 116.

questions.text: An abnormality was discovered during a routine ultrasound performed at 20 weeks of gestation on a pregnant 31-year-old woman. The patient requests a second opinion from you and brings the following ultrasound film. What birth defect would you describe to the couple?
questions.solution:
Anencephaly is a severe congenital condition in which a large part of the skull is absent along with the cerebral hemispheres of the brain.
  • On ultrasound, the cranial vault (bony calvarium) is symmetrically absent.
  • A "Frog-eye" or "Mickey mouse" appearance may be seen in coronal plane due to absent cranial bone and/or brain & bulging orbits.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3068

questions.text: Determine the tetanizing frequency of the frog's gastrocnemius muscle using the graph below.
questions.solution:
Tetanising frequency= A particular frequency of stimulus that is capable of producing a state of sustained contraction(complete tetanus) Tetanizing Frequency = 1/contraction period Here, contraction period includes approx. 4 scales so it will be 40mm TF = 1/0.04 =25Hz .Contraction period can be calculated by the amount of distance travelled


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 107

questions.text: A multiple sclerosis diagnosis is made for a patient. Where is the disease most prevalent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Oligodendrocytes
 
  • In multiple sclerosis (MS), the disease is most prevalent in oligodendrocytes.
  • Oligodendrocytes are responsible for producing myelin, the protective covering around nerve fibers in the central nervous system.
  • In MS, the immune system mistakenly attacks and damages the myelin, leading to communication problems between the brain and the rest of the body.
  • Oligodendrocyte damage and loss of myelin are characteristic features of MS lesions.
  • The disease primarily affects the white matter of the brain and spinal cord, where oligodendrocytes are abundant.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1269.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-Parkinsonian medications causes peripheral vasospasm?
questions.solution:
Correct Answers is (Option 3) Bromocriptine
 
  • Bromocriptine is a dopamine-receptor agonist derived from the vasoconstrictive alkaloid ergotamine.
  • It is typically administered in slowly increasing doses over a period of 2 to 3 months, but there are numerous potential side effects, including hallucinations, confusion, delirium, nausea and orthostatic hypotension.
  • It can also increase the risk of psychiatric illness, and serious cardiac problems, such as myocardial infarction, may develop.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 261.

choices.text: Breath holding is not required for the procedure
The bevel of the needle face upwards while inserting the needle

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the procedure done with the following needle?
questions.solution:
Platelets below 50,000 is a contraindication to Lumbar Puncture.


Contraindications of LP:
