questions.text: The most common cause of meningoencephalitis in children:
questions.solution:
• Correct Option is 4: Enterovirus Enteroviruses are the most common cause of meningoencephalitis worldwide.
  • Option 1 – Mumps : Mumps is caused by the paramyxovirus of the genus Rubulavirus spreads through respiratory droplets characteristic symptoms of mumps include swelling and tenderness of one or both parotid glands Complications : orchitis, oophoritis, meningitis, encephalitis, pancreatitis and deafness
  • Option 2 : arbovirus family transmits infection from mosquitoes, ticks or other arthropods to humans includes dengue, West Nile fever, Japanese encephalitis, eastern and western equine encephalitis.
  • Option 3 : HSV encephalitis is the most common cause of sporadic encephalitis in the world

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3232-3234

questions.text:
While walking with his eyes closed, a syphilis patient experienced an unbalance and had to elevate his foot and stomp the ground in order to move.
Which tract is affected by the described condition?
questions.solution:
The tract involved is Dorsal column tract.
 
  • Given condition represents a positive Romberg test in the patient of syphilis.
  • The patient is asked to close his eyes. Loss of equilibrium is viewed as a positive test. 
  • The Romberg test is designed to show how posterior column disease affects a person's ability to maintain an upright posture.
  • Since dorsal column is involved and it carries propioception, thus loss of propioception leads to imbalance when visual input is eliminated by closing eyes.
  • Syphilis involves dorsal column of spinal cord leading to - Tabes dorsalis

Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 165

questions.text: Which of the following indicates a poor prognosis for multiple myeloma patients?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Serum ß2 Microglobulin

Beta 2 microglobulin, the light chain of the HL-A histocompatibility complex, is a low molecular weight protein that is present on the surface of all nucleated cells.
Patients with multiple myeloma who have higher serum beta 2 microglobulin levels have a worse prognosis.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 607.

choices.text: It is rapidly absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and is detected in plasma 30 minutes after oral administration
The primary use of methadone is relief of chronic pain
The onset of analgesia is 30-60 minutes after parenteral administration and 1-2 hours after oral administration

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about methadone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) The onset of analgesia is 30-60 minutes after parenteral administration and 1-2 hours after oral administration
 
  • Methadone is a mu full agonist.
  • The onset of analgesia occurs 10-20 minutes after parenteral administration and 30-60 minutes after oral medication.
  • The average minimal effective analgesic concentration in blood is ~30 ng/mL.
  • It is used in management of chronic pain and antitussive.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 504.

choices.text: Give loading dose of aspirin and clopidogrel

questions.text:
A 60 years old female patient has left sided weakness since 1 hour and left sided face weakness with BP, 160/100 mm Hg.
What is the best next step if the CT scan is normal?
questions.solution:
The first step in such patients is NCCT head to rule out hemorrhagic stroke.

As CT head is normal in the question, it is suggestive of non-hemorrhagic stroke and Window period for thrombolysis is <4.5 hour so this patient can be considered for thrombolysis with Alteplase/Tenecteplase.
Thrombolytic agent, recombinant t-PA can be use between 3-4.5 hours after the onset of stroke.

The preferred drug is alteplase and it's dose is 0.9 mg/kg. 

Management of Acute Stroke:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3336, 3337.

questions.text: Which of the following best marker for having neural tube defects
questions.solution:
• NTD occurs due to failure of closure of the Neuropore.
  • Antenatal diagnosis of NTD is usually done by USG at 14-16 weeks of gestation. The earliest it can be done by USG is at 10-12 weeks.
  • Maternal serum markers can also be used for diagnosis While Acetylcholine esterase and Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) both indicate NTD, Acetylcholine esterase is the most specific and best marker.
  • Acetylcholinesterase is an enzyme that is primarily found in nerve tissue. In the case of neural tube defects, the protective layer around the neural tissue may be compromised, allowing AChE to leak into the amniotic fluid.
  • Detecting elevated levels of AChE in amniotic fluid can, therefore, be indicative of NTDs.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3064,890

questions.text: What does the maximum area in homunculus represent?
questions.solution:
Maximum area in homunculus signifies increased preciseness of movements.
 
  • Each body part's cortical representation is proportional in size to the skill with which it is utilised in fine, voluntary movement, according to the motor homunculus theory.
  • The parts of the cortex that are involved in speech and hand motions are very vast; humans are particularly good at using the pharynx, lips, and tongue to produce words as well as the fingers and opposable thumbs to manipulate the surroundings.

Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 232

questions.text: Which one of the following is not an alpha synucleinopathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Alzheimer

Alzheimer is not alpha synnucleopathy.
α-Synucleinopathies are neurodegenerative diseases characterized by the abnormal accumulation of α-synuclein aggregates in neurons, nerve fibers or glial cells.
It’s examples are:
  • Parkinson’s disease
  • Dementia with levy bodies
  • Multiple system atrophy
Alzheimer's disease on the other hand is an example of Taupathy. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1275.

questions.text: How long does flumazenil take to start working?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) within seconds
 
  • Flumazenil typically starts its action within 60- 90 seconds of IV administration.
  • Duration of action of flumazenil is 40 minutes. It is a BZD analogue, with little intrinsic activity, used in overdose of BZD.
  • On IV injection, action of flumazenil starts in seconds and lasts for 1-2 hours; elimination t-half is 1 hour, due to rapid metabolism.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 435.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old man with a recent history of CVA is hospitalized. He is drowsy and not responding to commands. The CT image is displayed as in the figure.
What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient has low GCS  and NCCT of the head shows a large wedge shaped infarct in left MCA territory with significant midline shift. In such a scenario,  decompressive neurosurgery will be the next best step of management in order to prevent impending brain herniation. 
 
  • Decompressive craniectomy is a neurosurgical procedure that reduces increased intracranial pressure in the presence of space-occupying brain lesions or brain swelling due to stroke.
  • Cerebral edema is a potential complication in 5-10% of patients with strokes, leading to obtundation and brain herniation. The severity of edema is highest on the second or third day after the stroke and can last for around 10 days.
  • Medical management may not be successful in case of significant edema or infarcts involving the cerebellum.

 
  • Decompressive surgery is recommended for patients who are less than 60 years old and experience deterioration within 48 hours, despite receiving medical therapy.
  • Hypodensity on head CT within the first 6 hours of stroke onset, involving > one-third of the MCA territory, early midline shift, and a diffusion-weighted imaging volume on MRI within 6 hours >80 mL are predictors of severe cerebral edema. 




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3337.

questions.text: A 6-year-old baby was brought to the emergency department with Lower limb tenderness for 2 days and h/o fever, sore throat, and cough for the past 5 days. there is no abnormality currently except for pain on pressing the muscles. CNS examination and reflexes are normal. CK level is 2000. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is viral myositis. 

Option B- Normal reflexes and no significant motor weakness rule out GBS.

Option C- There are no cutaneous indications to support dermatomyositis, but dermatomyositis wouldn't have muscle discomfort either.

Option D- DMD doesn't manifest at this age and will have a far higher CPK level.


Reference:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5429052/

questions.text: Which indicated area in the provided histology section is related to how massage relieves pain?
questions.solution:
The marked area A is substantia gelatinosa.

Massage activates the A-beta fiber, which influences the dorsal gelatinosa neuron and suppresses the small diameter pain fiber (closing the gate at spinal cord level). 


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 150

choices.text: Number of senile plaques correlates with age
Number of neurofibrillary tangles is associated with the severity of dementia
Extracellular inclusions can be found in the absence of intracellular inclusions

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Extracellular inclusions can be found in the absence of intracellular inclusions

Extracellular inclusions cannot be observed in the absence of intracellular inclusions because neurofibrillary tangles are intracellular accumulations that may manifest extracellularly following neuronal death. Other statements given are true.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1275.

choices.text: Has been known to cause Steven-Johnson's syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following statements about carbamazepine is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Has been known to cause Steven-Johnson's syndrome 

  • Carbamazepine has been known to cause Steven-Johnson's syndrome.
  • Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) is a rare, serious disorder of the skin and mucous membranes. It's usually a reaction to medication that starts with flu-like symptoms, followed by a painful rash that spreads and blisters. Then the top layer of affected skin dies, sheds and begins to heal after several days.
  • Acute intoxication with carbamazepine can result in stupor or coma, hyperirritability, convulsions, and respiratory depression.
  • During Long term therapy, the more frequent untoward effects of the drug include drowsiness, vertigo, ataxia, diplopia, and blurred vision. The frequency of seizures may increase, especially with overdose.
  • Other adverse effects include nausea, vomiting, serious hematological toxicity (aplastic anemia, agranulocytosis), and hypersensitivity reactions (dangerous skin reactions, eosinophilia, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly).
  • A late complication of therapy with carbamazepine is retention of water, with decreased osmolality and concentration of Na+ in plasma, especially in elderly patients with cardiac disease.
     
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 442.

questions.text: A patient with a headache visits the emergency room and claims it is the worst headache he has ever had. What is the next course of treatment?
questions.solution:
“The worst headache I've ever had” is a  symptom of a subarachnoid haemorrhage.

CT of the brain should be the next step for diagnosis.
 
  • The hallmark of aneurysmal rupture is blood in the CSF. More than 95% of cases have enough blood to be visualized on a high-quality noncontrast CT scan obtained within 72 h.
 
  • The extent and location of subarachnoid blood on a noncontrast CT scan help locate the underlying aneurysm, identify the cause of any neurologic deficit, and predict the occurrence of vasospasm.
 
  • If the scan fails to establish the diagnosis of SAH and no mass lesion or obstructive hydrocephalus is found, a lumbar puncture should be performed to establish the presence of subarachnoid blood. Lysis of the red blood cells and subsequent conversion of hemoglobin to bilirubin stains the spinal fluid yellow within 6–12 h. This xanthochromic spinal fluid peaks in intensity at 48 h and lasts for 1–4 weeks, depending on the amount of subarachnoid blood.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3354, 3355.

choices.text: Scalp EEG is diagnostic of frontal lobe epilepsy
10% of healthy people have epileptiform waves on EEG
EEG is mandatory for diagnosis of epilepsy
In progressive multi-focal Leucoencephalopathy lateralised epileptiform waves are seen

questions.text: Which of the following assertions about EEG is correct?
questions.solution:
5-10% of healthy people can have epileptiform waves on EEG.

Option 1 : Scalp EEG is used in the diagnosis of frontal lobe epilepsy, it is not diagnostic for frontal lobe epilepsy.

Option 3 : EEG is not mandatory for diagnosis of epilepsy. 

Option 4 : In progressive multi-focal leucoencephalopathy, diffuse slow waves are seen on EEG.

 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3063
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK563295/

questions.text: Which of the following gives rise to fibers that directly connect to the Purkinje cell of the cerebellum?
questions.solution:
Fibers reaching directly to the Purkinje cell of cerebellum arise from inferior olivary nuclei.
 
  • The inferior olivary nuclei are the sole source of the ascending fibers.
  •  Each one projects to a Purkinje cell's major dendrites, where it intertwines like a climbing plant. The inferior olivary nuclei receive proprioceptive information from everywhere across the body.
  • On the other hand, the mossy fibers deliver direct proprioceptive input to the cerebellar cortex from every area of the body as well as input from the cerebral cortex via the pontine nuclei.

Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 243

questions.text: Which receptor induces development of glioma on neuronal membrane?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) CD-133

Receptors on neuronal membrane that induces development of glioma are CD-133
CD-133 is a common marker used for leukemia and glioblastoma.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1293.

questions.text: Which receptors are affected by tricyclic antidepressants, causing side effects like dry mouth and urinary retention?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) Muscarinic receptors

  • Tricyclic antidepressants produce side effects like dry mouth, urinary retention due to action on Muscarinic receptors.
  • Muscarinic receptors are the most widespread receptors of the parasympathetic nervous system bringing about associated changes in the body.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 485.

questions.text: A patient with fever and a headache arrives at the emergency room. On examination, he has stiffness in his neck. A CSF analysis was performed The opening pressure was increased, proteins were mild, glucose was normal, and lymphocytes were increased. What is the most likely organism responsible for this?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Coxsackie virus
 
  • The presence of chronic headaches and stiff neck signify meningitis, according to medical history.
  • Elevated opening pressure, slightly increased proteins, normal glucose, and increased lymphocytes in the CSF assay results are strongly suggestive of viral (Coxsackie virus) meningitis.
Meningitis accompanied by normal glucose levels strongly suggests viral meningitis.


CSF findings in Meningitis:
 
Appearance Opening Pressure mmHg WBC (cell/\(\mu\)L) Protein (mg/dl) Glucose (mg/dL)
Normal Clear 90-180 < 8 15-45 50-80
Bacterial Meningitis Turbid Elevated > 1000-2000 >200 <40
Viral meningitis Clear Normal <300; Lymphocytic predominance <200 Normal
Fungal Meningitis Clear Normal-elevated <500 >200 Normal-Low



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 946.

questions.text: Neonatal seizures can be induced by which vitamin deficiency:
questions.solution:
Vitamin deficiency causing neonatal seizure is Pyridoxine.
  • Glutamate is an excitatory neurotransmitter increases the chances of seizure.
  • It is metabolized into GABA, which is inhibitory for the seizure by an enzyme called GAD (glutamic acid decarboxylase)
  • Vitamin B6 or pyridoxine is a coenzyme for GAD.
  • Therefore deficiency of pyridoxine can lead to accumulation of glutamate, which causes neonatal seizure.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 118,119,553

questions.text: What mainly regulates CSF pressure?
questions.solution:
Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pressure is regulated by the balance between production and absorption of CSF.

The rate of CSF absorption is predominantly determined by the movement of CSF across the arachnoid granulations (AGs) into the dural venous sinuses.

The absorption of CSF into the venous sinuses is driven by higher pressure in the CSF space as compared to that in the capillaries of the venous sinuses.

The rate of CSF then determines the hydrostatic pressure of CSF in the cranial vault, thereby regulating the intracranial pressure.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 591

questions.text: The inclusion bodies found in Alzheimer's are:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Hirano bodies
 
  • Hirano bodies are intracellular inclusion bodies typically observed in the neurons of individuals with Alzheimer's disease.
  • Hirano bodies are considered to be a hallmark pathological feature of Alzheimer's disease.
  • In contrast, Buschino bodies are eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions found in hepatocytes, and Lewy bodies and Lafora bodies are associated with other neurodegenerative disorders.

IMPORTANT INCLUSION BODIES



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1275.

questions.text: Which receptor mediates dysphoria caused by opiates?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) kappa

Kappa receptors for opioids cause dysphoria.

* [Extra Edge]: Functions of Opioid Receptor



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 507.

questions.text: Which sort of spinocerebellar ataxia is most prevalent in India?
questions.solution:
Spinocerebellar ataxia (SCA) is a group of inherited neurological disorders that cause problems with coordination and balance. These disorders are caused by changes in certain genes that control the movement of proteins, which are essential for proper functioning of the brain and nerves.
 
  • SCA2 is the most common form of SCA in India, caused by a mutation of a protein called ataxin-2. This protein is responsible for the functioning of nerve cells and for the proper formation of connections between nerve cells in the brain and spine.
 
  • Individuals with SCA2 experience difficulty with balance, coordination of movements, and speech. They may also experience muscle weakness and involuntary twitching of the body.
 
  • Treatment of SCA2 usually involves medications to improve coordination and maintain muscle strength, as well as physical and occupational therapy.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3424.

questions.text: A 7-day-old infant has a leaky meningomyelocele. Which of the following is the most useful for the diagnosis and management of this condition?
questions.solution:
• Infants with leaking meningomyelocele are at risk of meningitis.
  • Ideally CSF study should be done, since its not given in the option, the best answer would be wound culture.
  • Open meningomyelocele and with leaking CSF provides a portal of entry for bacteria and predispose the patient to the development of infection.


Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3066-3068

choices.text: Continue with a cycle length of 24 hours
Continue with a cycle length of less than 24 hours
Continue with a cycle length of more than 24 hours

questions.text: Without outside stimuli, the human sleep-wake cycle:
questions.solution:
If external cues such as light and darkness are taken away, humans are still compelled to follow a 24-hour sleep-wake cycle - commonly referred to as the circadian rhythm - which has a tendency to lengthen to 25-30 hours. In the absence of environmental factors, the sleep-wakefulness cycle will still follow this circadian pattern.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 273

questions.text: Astrocytes of the Alzheimer type II are not present in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Alzheimer's disease 
 
  • Astrocytes of the Alzheimer type II are reactive astrocytes observed in certain conditions but not in Alzheimer's disease.
  • They are typically seen in hepatic encephalopathy, Wilson's disease, and urea cycle disorders.
  • Alzheimer's disease is characterized by the presence of neuritic plaques, neurofibrillary tangles, and neuronal loss, but astrocytes of the Alzheimer type II are not a characteristic feature of this disease.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1275.

questions.text: Which of the following medications can effectively treat juvenile myoclonic epilepsy in a female of childbearing age group in substitution of sodium valproate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Levetiracetam
 
  • Levetiracetam can be prescribed as monotherapy in a female patient of childbearing age as a replacement of valproate for JME, because of no known significant drug interactions. Rest options have their fare risk of adverse effects associated.
  • Carbamazepine and phenytoin are in fact contraindicated in JME. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 401.

questions.text: Which structure is most likely to be compressed in a posterior intercommunicating artery aneurysm?
questions.solution:
An aneurysm of the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) or Posterior communicating artery is likely to affect the oculomotor nerve due to its close proximity to the artery. The oculomotor nerve is responsible for controlling the medial and lateral movement of the eye, as well as pupil size and shape.

Aneurysms can cause damage to the oculomotor nerve, resulting in ocular motor dysfunction including ophthalmoplegia (paralysis of eye muscles), impaired vision and abnormal pupil responses. 



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 931, 937.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 229.

questions.text: A newborn presents with congestive heart failure and, on examination, has bulging anterior fontanelle with a bruit on auscultation. Transfontanellar USG shows a hypoechoic midline mass with dilated lateral ventricles. What will be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• I’m Midline hypoechoic mass with dilated lateral ventricles (on USG), bruit on auscultation, hydrocephalus and high output cardiac failure in neonates/infants is diagnostic of vein of Galen malformation.
  • Vein of Galen malformation is characterized by aneurysmal dilatation and arteriovenous malformation of Galen. 
  • It most commonly presents in the neonatal period.

choices.text: Loss of fine movements in fingers and hand

questions.text: Corticospinal damage is linked to all except:
questions.solution:
Superficial reflexes disappear in both upper and lower motor neuron damage.
Clasp-Knife Effect: When the muscles are hypertonic, as in a UMN lesion, the sequence of moderate stretch- strong stretch muscle relaxation is seen. muscle contraction, Passive flexion of the elbow meets immediate resistance as a result of the stretch reflex in the triceps muscle. Further stretch activates the inverse stretch reflex. The resistance to flexion suddenly collapses, and the arm flexes. Continued passive flexion stretches the muscle again, and the sequence is repeated. This sequence of resistance followed by a 'give' when a limb is moved passively is known as the clasp-knife effect because of its resemblance to the closing of a pocket knife. It is also known as lengthening reaction because it is the response of a spastic muscle to lengthening. Clasp knife rigidity occurs due to involvement of Extrapyramidal tracts.
Rest all the 3 are associated with corticospinal tract.

Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 234,235

questions.text: All of the following, with one exception, display the Zellballen Pattern which is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Acoustic neuroma
 
  • The Zellballen pattern refers to the histological appearance of nests or clusters of cells separated by an abundant vascular stroma.
  • Conditions that display the Zellballen pattern include:
    • Pheochromocytoma: A catecholamine-producing tumor arising from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla.
    • Carotid Body Tumor: A neoplasm arising from the carotid body, a chemoreceptor organ located at the carotid bifurcation.
    • Glomus Jugulare: A tumor arising from the paraganglia of the jugular bulb.
    • Paraganglioma
Acoustic neuroma, also known as vestibular schwannoma, does not display the Zellballen pattern as it arises from Schwann cells rather than neuroendocrine cells.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1237.

questions.text: The newest medication for Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Edaravone
 
  • The recently sanctioned medicine for Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) is Edaravone. The US FDA authorized it on the grounds of a six-month test including a specific set of ALS sufferers, which showed a small decline in their disability rate.
  • Edavarone acts as an antioxidant, however the actual mechanism of action is not known.
  • This drug, thought to act as an antioxidant, is administered through a 10-day cycle of daily intravenous infusions, each month. Previously, Riluzole was approved, albeit with a mild survival extension benefit. However, survival was not an inspected factor in the Edaravone trial.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 423.
Online Reference:
Cruz MP. Edaravone (Radicava): A Novel Neuroprotective Agent for the Treatment of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. P T. 2018 Jan;43(1):25-28. PMID: 29290672; PMCID: PMC5737249.

questions.text: A patient has hypotonia and unilateral ptosis in the same eye. After receiving an IV shot, his symptoms vanished for a breif duration. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Clinical findings of unilateral ptosis and hypotonia in the eye with improvement after an IV injection (most probably
edrophonium) indicates Myasthenia gravis.

Clinical features of Myasthenia Gravis:

Muscle weakness and fatiguability are its defining characteristics.

• Weakness may worsen late in the day or after prolonged use (fatigue), although it may also become better after rest or sleep.
• There is a recognizable pattern to how muscular weakness is distributed.

Early on in the course of MG, the cranial muscles (lids and extraocular muscles) are frequently affected.
Ptosis and diplopia are frequent early complaints.

• The patient's attempt to grin is met with a "snarling" face due to facial weakness.
• Chewing weakness is most obvious after exerting a lot of effort, like when chewing meat.

Speech timbre: nasal (due to weakness of palate) Dissonant "mushy" quality (due ot tongue weakness)
• Difficulty swallowing due to pharyngeal, tongue, or palate paralysis, resulting in aspiration or nasal regurgitation.

The edrophonium (Tensilon) test is sometimes of value in distinguishing botulism (usually a negative result) from myasthenia gravis (usually a positive result), which was performed in the question.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1275.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3510, 3511.

Types of neuronal migration disorders- •Schizencephaly
•Lissencephaly (Agyria): Smooth brain; characterized by the absence of cerebral convolutions.
•Pachygyria
•Polymicrogyria

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a Neuronal tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Ependymoma 
 
  • Ependymoma is a type of primary central nervous system tumor that arises from ependymal cells lining the ventricles of the brain or the central canal of the spinal cord.
  • Ependymoma is derived from glial cells and is classified as a glioma rather than a neuronal tumor.
  • Neuronal tumors arise from neuronal cells and include various types, such as gangliocytoma, ganglioglioma, and neurocytoma.
  • Ependymoma is characterized by a range of clinical presentations depending on the location and size of the tumor and can cause symptoms related to increased intracranial pressure or local mass effect.

NEURONAL TUMORS

questions.text: Which of the following is not a side effect of escitalopram?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Sialorrhea 
 
  • Escitalopram is selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI).
  • SSRIs have side effects, including insomnia, increased anxiety, irritability, decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, anorgasmia, ejaculatory delay and gastrointestinal effects.
  • Some patients also experience increased anxiety during the initial dosing, and dullness of intellectual ability and concentration with continued treatment.
  • Paroxetine in particular is linked to higher levels of sexual side effects. Sialorrhea is not the side-effect of SSRIs.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 489.

questions.text: Pseudotumor Cerebri is usually seen in:
questions.solution:
• Pseudotumor cerebri, also known as idiopathic intracranial hypertension, is a neurological disorder characterized by increased pressure in the cranial cavity which can result in severe headaches, blurred or double vision, or even vision loss.
 
  • It is most commonly seen in obese women between the ages of 20 and 45. This is because increased pressure in the brain is more likely to occur in those with a higher amount of intra-abdominal fat, which pushes up on the diaphragm and therefore increases pressure on the cranial cavity.
 
  • Age also plays a role because it is more common in this age range among women.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 116.

questions.text: You have been contacted to declare a 12-year-old child in the PICU brain dead. All of the following indicate brain death, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Guidelines to determine brain death
 1)Clinical criteria- Complete loss of consciousness, vocalization and volitional activity.
 2)Absent brainstem reflexes- Absence of papillary responses of light, oculocephalic
  reflexes, oculovestibular response, corneal reflex, jaw reflex, facial grimacing to deep      
  pressure on supraorbital ridge or temporomandibular joint, pharyngeal gagreflex, coughing    
 in response to tracheal suctioning, sucking and rooting reflexes.
  3)Apnea- Absence of respiratory drive at paCO2 of 60 mm Hg or 20 mm Hg above 
   baseline. 
  Prerequisites:a)Clinical and/or neuro imaging evidence of acute catastrophe severe enough to explain the condition.   
   b)Core temperature more than 32°C",No drug (sedatives, narcotics) or alcohol intoxication, poisoning
   or neuromuscular blockade

    c)Normal blood pressure
     d)No confounding conditions such as severe electrolyte, acid-base, metabolic or endocrine
  disturbances
                Two evaluations, separated by a time interval of 48 hours, if <2 month  old; 24 hours, if 2-12 months old; 12 hours, if 1-18 years old; and at any  interval, if > 18 years old.
  Ancillary Test:Two tests required if <2-month-old; one test if 2-12-month-old;
 tests optional if >1 year old.
                   1)Cerebral angiography
                   2)Electroencephalography
                   3)Transcranial Doppler ultrasonography
                   4)Cerebral scintigraphy

 
  • Decorticate and decerebrate posturing are not signs of brain death because they are reflexive responses that can be present in brain-injured patients who remain clinically alive.
  • Decorticate posturing is an abnormal flexed posture of the arms, hands and legs that can occur during a coma or vegetative state due to brain damage or diseases that cause a coma.
 
  • Decerebrate posturing is an abnormal posture of the arms, legs and trunk in which the arms are held outward and the legs are extended and held rigid. Both of these posturing responses occur when the neural pathways connecting the brain to the pyramidal tracts are disrupted, which can occur in the absence of death.


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 580

choices.text: It has control centers for all motor actions and sensory inputs
Its functions can be profoundly affected by the external environment
Every cell of the brain has a specific function
It acts as a closed system, responding to internal stimuli but not the external stimuli

questions.text: Why is it believed that the brain is responsive?
questions.solution:
In humans, the brain is considered to be "responsive" because its functions are affected by changes in the external environment.

For example, changes in the environment (such as a loud noise) can cause the brain to activate certain areas in an attempt to process the change.

The brain is also affected by changes in emotional arousal, where different areas of the brain become more active depending on the emotional context.

Additionally, changes in learning patterns can also cause the brain to rewire itself as new connections are formed and strengthened through repetition.

Finally, when exposed to certain types of drugs or hormones, the brain can make adjustments to its chemistry in order to cope with the changes in the external environment.

Ultimately, the brain is widely seen as being highly responsive to many types of changes in the environment, both physical and emotional.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 151

choices.text: No fade on train of four stimulation

questions.text: The statements concerning succinylcholine causing neuromuscular blockade are all accurate, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Fade on tetanic stimulation

On tetanic stimulation, Sch undergoes post-tetanic potentiation instead of fade.
Succinyl choline is a depolarizing muscle relaxant. It has a TOF>0.4

* [Extra Edge]: Clinical assessment of neuromuscular block


FIG: TOF protocol
  • During partial competitive block (as occurs during onset and recovery or reversal) the degree of block corresponds to the decrease in TOF-ratio, because competitive blockers exhibit ‘fade’ phenomenon.
  • As the muscles recover, the TOF-ratio improves and becomes 1.0 at complete recovery.
  • Spontaneous breathing may be resumed when TOF-ratio recovers to > 0.7.
  • On the other hand, classical or phase-I depolarizing block does not exhibit fade; the TOF-ratio remains 1.0, though all the 4 twitches are depressed equally depending on the degree of block.
  • Fade is again seen when phase II or desensitization block occurs with prolonged use of a depolarizing agent and TOF-ratio is depressed as in the case of competitive block. However, SCh generally requires no monitoring.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 379.
Online Reference:
Xue L, Wu LG. Post-tetanic potentiation is caused by two signalling mechanisms affecting quantal size and quantal content. J Physiol. 2010 Dec 15;588(Pt 24):4987-94. doi: 10.1113/jphysiol.2010.196964. Epub 2010 Nov 1. PMID: 21041528; PMCID: PMC3036192.

questions.text: Since two years ago, a 60-year-movements old's have been gradually slowing down. She moves in a rectangular, slow wave jerking fashion and exhibits rigidity. The likelihood of a diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is a neurological disorder that affects movement and causes stiffness, decreased movement, and an inability to control eye movements. The cause of PSP is unknown. It typically affects individuals over the age of 60 and its symptoms are progressive.

Clinical features and progression: 
 
  • Clinically, PSP-RS begins with falls and executive or subtle personality changes (such as mental rigidity, impulsivity, or apathy).
  • Shortly thereafter, a progressive oculomotor syndrome ensues that begins with square wave jerks, followed by slowed saccades (vertical worse than horizontal) before resulting in progressive supranuclear ophthalmoparesis.
  • Dysarthria, dysphagia, and symmetric axial rigidity can be prominent features that emerge at any point in the illness. A stiff, unstable posture with hyperextension of the neck and a slow, jerky, toppling gait are characteristic.
  • Frequent unexplained and sometimes spectacular falls are common secondary to a combination of axial rigidity, inability to look down, and impaired judgment.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3380.

questions.text: Which of the following is the endo-cochlear potential?
questions.solution:
Between endolymph and perilymph, there is a constant electrical potential of roughly +80–100 millivolts, with positivity inside the scala media and negative outside. This is known as the endocochlear potential, and it is produced by the stria vascularis' ongoing release of positive potassium ions into the scala media.

questions.text:
Symptoms of a 56-year-old male include a unilateral headache, diplopia, and fever. He found it challenging to chew. ESR was higher and the brain MRI results were normal.
What is the treatment advisable?
questions.solution:
• This individual is likely to be suffering from temporal (giant cell) arteritis, which is an inflammatory disorder often affecting the large  arteries, usually those found in the head, including those leading to the eyes and the temples.

 
  • In order to confirm the diagnosis, the patient's erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) must be persistently high along with normal results on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans. As this condition is highly serious and can cause permanent damage to the arteries, treatment needs to start before confirmation of the diagnosis.

 
  • The initial treatment plan consists of high-dose prednisolone or corticosteroid therapy which helps reduce the inflammation in the arteries. This can help to slow or stop the progression of the condition and possibly reverse any damage caused.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2812.

questions.text: The cause of Fetal Hydantoin Syndrome is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Phenytoin 

Fetal hydantoin syndrome is a characteristic pattern of mental and physical birth defects that results from maternal use of the anti-seizure (anticonvulsant) drug phenytoin (Dilantin) during pregnancy.
  • The range and severity of associated abnormalities will vary greatly from one infant to another. However, characteristic features may include distinctive skull and facial features, growth deficiencies, underdeveloped (hypoplastic) nails of the fingers and toes, and/or mild developmental delays.
  • Other findings occasionally associated with this syndrome include cleft lip and palate, a head circumference that is smaller than would be expected based upon an infant’s age and gender (microcephaly), and skeletal malformations particularly of the fingers or hands.

* [Extra Edge]: Teratogenic Drugs


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 441.

choices.text: Amyloid Angiopathy is associated with Small Vessel Disease
Alzheimer's Disease is associated with Amyloid Angiopathy
Alzheimer's Disease is related to small vessel Disease
Alzheimer's Disease is not related to small vessel Disease

questions.text: All are true EXCEPT
questions.solution:
It has been seen that deposition of amyloid is aggravated in patients with cerebral small-vessel disease, especially in apolipoprotein E4 carriers, providing evidence for pathophysiological synergy between these three biological factors
 
  • The accumulation of Aβ in cerebral arterioles is termed amyloid angiopathy. Thus, amyloid angiopathy is a small vessel disease whi is also seen in patients with Alzheimer's disease.
  • In Alzheimer's disease Microscopically, there are widespread neuritic plaques containing amyloid beta (Aβ), neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs) composed of hyperphosphorylated tau filaments, and Aβ accumulation in blood vessel walls in cortex and leptomeninges (amyloid angiopathy).
  • Also, in many patients with AD, amyloid angiopathy can lead to microhemorrhages, large lobar hemorrhages, ischemic infarctions most often in the subcortical white matter, or in rare cases an inflammatory leukoencephalopathy.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3349, 3370-3372.

questions.text: Which of the following matches is incorrect?
questions.solution:
• Moya Moya disease is a progressive neurological disorder which is characterized by narrowing or blockage of the blood vessels leading to the brain.
  • Moyamoya disease is a poorly understood occlusive disease involving large intracranial arteries, especially the distal internal carotid artery and the stem of the MCA and ACA. Vascular inflammation is absent.
  • The lenticulostriate arteries develop a rich collateral circulation around the occlusive lesion, which gives the impression of a “puff of smoke” (moyamoya in Japanese) on conventional x-ray angiography.
  • It is most commonly diagnosed in children and is associated with the narrowing and occlusion of the circle of Willis and arteries that feed it, as well as the presence of abnormal and collateral vessels within the brain.
  • It is not associated with aortic aneurysms, which are conditions where a weakened area in the aorta bulges out, forming a balloon-like structure, and can be life-threatening if the aneurysm ruptures.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3343.

questions.text: Pick the incorrect statement regarding Opioid receptor antagonists.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Naloxone is more potent than Naltrexone

Option 1, 2 and 4 are regarding Naltrexone and Naloxone
  • Naltrexone differs from naloxone in being orally active and having a long duration of action (1–2 days) which makes it suitable for ‘opioid blockade’ therapy of postaddicts. 
  • Naltrexone is more potent than naloxone.
  • There is evidence that naltrexone decreases the craving for alcohol in chronic alcoholics by increasing baseline β-endorphin release, and it has been approved by the FDA for this purpose.
  • Methylnaltrexone bromide and Naloxone is approved for the treatment of constipation in patients with opioid-induced constipation (OIC) with chronic noncancer pain.
  • late-stage advanced illness naloxegol, alvimopan approved for the treatment of postoperative ileus following bowel resection surgery.
Option 3 Nalmefene pure opioid antagonist lacks hepatotoxicity of naltrexone, has higher oral bioavailability and is longer acting than Naloxone.

questions.text: A 42-year-old lady from a dry state who had consumed rye for an extended period of time complained of exhaustion, nausea, and weakness in both lower limbs. She eventually loses the ability to walk altogether. What is the most probable reason?
questions.solution:
• The reason for developing this illness is consuming Lathyrus sativus (Khesari dal), which contains the ODAP/BOAA toxin.
  • It produces pyramidal tract injury, which manifests as paralysis with evidence of higher motor neuron damage in the lower limbs and a lack of strength in or inability to move those limbs.
  • Ingestion of legumes containing the toxin occurs despite an awareness of the means to detoxify Lathyrus.
  • Drought conditions can lead to shortages of both fuel and water, preventing the necessary detoxification steps from being taken, particularly in impoverished countries.
  • When certain legumes from the genus Lathyrus are consumed, it can lead to a neurological disorder known as neurolathyrism in humans.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, page no 759.

questions.text: When an excitable tissue, such as a nerve or muscle, is exposed to supramaximal stimulation and a response is produced, in what state is the tissue?
questions.solution:
The absolute refractory period begins once the firing level is reached and continues until repolarization is around one-third complete. Following this is the relative refractory period, in which stronger than usual stimuli can still elicit a response while weaker stimuli will not. During the absolute refractory period, no matter how powerful a stimulus is, the nerve cannot be excited.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 91

choices.text: Inhibit conversion of levodopa to dopamine in the CNS

questions.text: The reason why L-Dopa is combined with Carbidopa in the treatment of parkinsonism is to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Inhibit peripheral decarboxylation of levodopa

Levodopa is metabolized by dopa decarboxylase in the whole body. 90% of levodopa gets metabolized into dopamine in the periphery and only a small amount reaches the brain

Carbidopa is an analog of levodopa. It does not cross the blood brain barrier. So if carbidopa is given with levodopa , it competitively blocks dopa decarboxylase in the periphery preventing peripheral metabolism of levodopa. Thus, it helps in reducing the dopamine related peripheral side effects and increase central concentration of dopamine. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 457.

questions.text: A 59-year-old male patient complains of right-sided palatal paralysis and loss of sensation on face. questions.solution:
The given symptoms are compliant with a case of Lateral Medullary Syndrome, most common cause of which is the occlusion of Vertebral artery > posterior inferior cerebellar artery.

 

Symptoms of Lateral Medullary Syndrome:

  • Contralateral sensory deficits from the body
  • Ipsilateral Cerebellar signs like Ataxia
  • Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation from the face
  • Ipsilateral palatal, pharyngeal and laryngeal hemiparesis.
  • Ipsilateral Horner Syndrome.

questions.text: What are nuclear bag fibres related to?
questions.solution:
When a muscle is stretched and has its nerve intact, the response it produces is known as the stretch reflex. The muscle spindle, a small enclosed fusiform structure within the muscle, is the sensory organ that detects the stretch stimuli. It consists of two subtypes of Nuclear bag fibres which are responsible for detecting both the velocity of the stretch (dynamic) and the steady-state length of the muscle (static).


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 225,226

questions.text: The following statement about Phenytoin is false:
questions.solution:

Phenytoin follows Michaelis Menten kinetics, elimination changes from first order to zero order kinetics when dose is increased beyond saturation levels.

Option 2 :  Causes foetal hydantoin syndrome – microcephaly, cleft lip/palate, hypoplastic phalanges

Option 3 : Phenytoin is highly bound to plasma protien and thus has low volume of distribution.

Option 4 : This is a false statement, phenytoin inhibits glucose-stimulated insulin secretion by interfering with Ca2+ uptake via voltage-gated Ca2+ channels.

questions.text: A patient with altered sensorium arrives at the emergency room. The test that could be done at last is:
questions.solution:
• For patients with altered sensorium, it is generally recommended that an imaging study be performed prior to lumbar puncture to exclude the causes of raised ICP (large intracranial mass lesion) and to prevent herniation. “Lumbar puncture is performed less frequently  for coma diagnosis because neuroimaging effectively excludes intracerebral & extensive subarachnoid hemorrhage. 
 
  • The metabolic aberrations commonly encountered in clinical practice are usually revealed by measurement of electrolytes, glucose, calcium, magnesium, osmolarity, and renal (blood urea nitrogen) and hepatic (NH3) function.
 
  • Lumbar puncture should be performed if no cause is readily apparent, as examination of the CSF remains indispensable in the diagnosis of various forms of meningitis and encephalitis.


NOTE: An imaging study should be performed prior to lumbar puncture to exclude a large intracranial mass lesion, which could lead to herniation with lumbar puncture.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 187.

questions.text: It is prohibited to use MAO inhibitors with:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Pethidine
 
  • Pethidine undergoes hydrolysis and is excreted in the kidney. Some amount (1%) is metabolized by Dealkylation into Normeperidine which then undergoes hydrolysis.
  • MAO inhibitors block this hydrolysis leading to accumulation of toxic Normeperidine which is neurotoxic.
Thus, MAO inhibitors are contraindicated with Pethidine.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 482.

questions.text: A and B were instructed to create a square from the empty and filled circles, respectively. A drew a square that isn't really a square. What could be the potential reason?
questions.solution:
Image A shows the phenomenon of past-pointing and intentional tremor while joining the empty and filled circles, seen in case of cerebellar lesions. 




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3280, 3400.

questions.text: When are fast fatigue fibres recruited during walking?
questions.solution:
The motor units are classified according to the type of muscle fibres they innervate, and this categorization is based on the duration of the muscle twitches they produce.

Additionally, the recruitment of motor units during muscle contraction follows a general process known as the Size Principle, where certain types of motor units are recruited to produce specific responses.

Slow S motor units are recruited to initiate a muscle action, followed by faster FR motor units for more powerful responses over shorter time periods, and finally the most fatigable FF motor units for the most demanding tasks.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 110

questions.text: Serotonin syndrome cannot be precipitated by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Chlorpromazine
 
  • The typical antipsychotic drugs have potent dopamine D2 receptor blocking property and produce extrapyramidal motor side effects.
  • CPZ produces indifference to surroundings, paucity of thought, psychomotor slowing, emotional quietening, reduction in initiative and tendency to go off to sleep from which the subject is easily arousable.
  • Spontaneous movements are minimized but slurring of speech, ataxia or motor incoordination does not occur.
  • This is mostly perceived to be unpleasant and has been referred to as the ‘neuroleptic syndrome’.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 464, 488.

questions.text: A 7-year-old kid arrives with a right-sided hemangioma and left-sided focal convulsions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Sturge-Weber syndrome, or encephalotrigeminal angiomatosis, is a phakomatosis characterized by facial port wine stains and pial angiomas. 

  • The diagnosis is usually obvious on account of a congenital facial cutaneous capillary malformation (also known as port wine stain or facial nevus flammeus). This feature is almost always present and usually involves the ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve ; if this territory is not involved, Sturge-Weber syndrome is unlikely.
 
  • In ~5%, it has intracranial involvement present without associated cutaneous nevus. In the majority of cases (~70%) the nevus is unilateral and ipsilateral to the intracranial abnormality. 
 
  • The most common clinical manifestation is with childhood focal seizures, present in 71-89% of cases, which is often refractory to medical therapy. These usually begin in the first few years of life and are often associated with developmental delay and hemispheric symptoms including hemiplegia/hemiparesis and hemianopsia.
 
  • Approximately a third of patients have choroidal or scleral angiomatous involvement, which may be complicated by retinal detachment, buphthalmos or glaucoma. 




Reference: Essential Pediatrics by OP Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 558, 559.

choices.text: Change in angle of joint during motion
Change in length of muscle before and after the movement

questions.text: The Golgi tendon organ plays a significant role in voluntary movements because it constantly transmits to the efferent neurons:
questions.solution:
The golgi tendon organ is the sense organ that tells how much tension the muscle is exerting. If there is too much muscle tension the golgi tendon organ will inhibit the muscle from creating any force (via a reflex arc), thus protecting from injury.



Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 158

questions.text: Which is the most common congenital anomaly associated with lithium use in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) Cardiac Malformations

Cardiac Malformations (especially Ebstein Anomaly) are most commonly associated with using Lithium in pregnancy.
 
  • Valproate and carbamazepine have been linked to NTDs, especially spina bifida. 
  • Fetal hydantoin syndrome is a characteristic pattern of mental and physical birth defects that results from maternal use of the anti-seizure (anticonvulsant) drug phenytoin (Dilantin) during pregnancy.
* [Extra Edge]: Lithium



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 476.

questions.text: What is the first indication of cord compression in a case of thoracic spine tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
The first signs of spinal cord compression in thoracic spine tuberculosis are usually pain, weakness, and numbness in the upper and lower extremities. These symptoms may progress over time, leading to paraplegia.

Other symptoms of spinal cord compression include: 
  • Loss of bladder and bowel control 
  • Loss of sensation in the limbs and trunk 
  • Difficulty walking 
  • Tightness in the lower limbs 
  • Loss of dexterity and weakness in hand grip 
  • Loss of balance and spasticity in legs 



Reference: Garg, Ravindra Kumar, and Dilip Singh Somvanshi. “Spinal tuberculosis: a review.” The journal of spinal cord medicine vol. 34,5 (2011): 440-54. doi:10.1179/2045772311Y.0000000023. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3184481/

questions.text: Mediators of ganglionic transmission include:
questions.solution:
Ganglionic transmission is mediated by nicotinic receptors present postsynaptically. In both divisions of the autonomic nervous system, postganglionic neurons express nicotinic acetylcholine receptors to receive signals from preganglionic neurons. The neurotransmitters of postganglionic fibers differ. In the parasympathetic division, neurons are cholinergic (that is, acetylcholine is the primary neurotransmitter).

In the sympathetic division, neurons are mostly adrenergic (that is, epinephrine and norepinephrine function as the primary neurotransmitters). 


Reference:https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10864965/

questions.text: What is the name of the centrally acting alpha 2 agonist muscle relaxant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Tizanidine

Tizanidine is an FDA-approved drug for managing spasticity. It is a centrally acting alpha-2 receptor agonist. Tizanidine effectively works with spasticity caused by multiple sclerosis, an acquired brain injury, or a spinal cord injury.

* [Extra Edge]: Muscle Relaxant



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 384.

questions.text: A patient using ATT on a regular basis had tubercular meningitis. At the end of one month of consistent drug use, the patient's condition has deteriorated despite good drug compliance. Which of the following inquiries is not necessary for an emergency assessment?
questions.solution:
CSF examination in this case is not required in emergency evaluation.
 
  • Blood cultures should be acquired right away when there is a suspicion of bacterial meningitis, and supplementary dexamethasone therapy should also be started.
  • NCCT followed by MRI and LFT will be useful for immediate diagnosis or status of the patient.
  • However CSF analysis will not provide with any new information after 1 month of ATT.



Reference: Davis, Angharad et al. “Treatment of Tuberculous Meningitis and Its Complications in Adults.” Current treatment options in neurology vol. 20,3 5. 28 Feb. 2018, doi:10.1007/s11940-018-0490-9. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5830467/

questions.text: What does the given EEG suggest?
questions.solution:
Given EEG is suggestive of polyspike and wave, seen in myoclonic epilepsy.

Myoclonic Seizures:

Myoclonic seizures are short-lived, shock-like muscular contractions, and even when they are widespread, they don't cause any discernible impairments in consciousness. 

Myoclonic seizures mostly affect the shoulders, upper extremities, and face and can happen as separate episodes or in clusters, in which case they are typically not rhythmic.



Reference:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK570566/

questions.text: Which medication was recently approved by the FDA for the treatment of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome?
questions.solution:
Recently approved drug by FDA for treatment of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome is Rufinamide.

  • Rufinamide is an anticonvulsant medication that is used to treat Lennox-Gastaut syndrome and other seizure disorders in combination with other medications and therapy. 
  • On November 14, 2008, the US Food and Drug Administration approved rufinamide as an adjunctive treatment for seizures associated with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome in children 4 years of age and older, as well as adults.



Other drugs used in Lennox-Gestaut syndrome: 

  1. Clobazam
  2. Felbamate
  3. Lamotrigine
  4. Topiramate
  5. Cannabidiol



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3307, 3312, 3319.

questions.text: Where does sympathetic stimulation cause the blood flow to decrease?
questions.solution:
Sympathetic stimulation decreases blood flow in skin. Sympathetic Stimulation: Stimulation of sympathetic fibers causes vasoconstriction but it is not important, as the vasocontricor system is not Sympathetic.stimulation increases myocardial blood flow through an increased metabolic demand and a predominance of beta-receptor activation. Sympathetic system doesn't change the cerebral and renal blood flow as they are managed by auto-regulation. 


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 262
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441980/

questions.text: Which of the following medications' withdrawal can result in anxiety and insomnia leading to discontinuation syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Venlafaxine
 
  • Venlafaxine is an SNRI, a type of medication that can cause anxiety, insomnia and other adverse reactions if stopped suddenly.
  • SNRIs have similar side effects to SSRIs, including nausea, constipation, insomnia, headaches, and sexual dysfunction.
  • Higher doses of the immediate release form of venlafaxine can cause high blood pressure, but this is lowered when taken in extended-release form.
  • Venlafaxine is the shortest acting SNRI therefore has withdrawal symptoms.
  • Duloxetine, another SNRI, does not have this same side effect.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 489.

choices.text: One dose of low molecular weight heparin subcutaneously followed by dual antiplatelet therapy

questions.text: A patient with aortic valve disease who also had right hemiparesis was admitted. What steps will you take to stop further strokes?
questions.solution:
• Aspirin is the only antiplatelet agent that has been shown to be effective in the acute treatment of ischemic stroke; however, there are several antiplatelet agents that have been shown to be effective in the secondary prevention of stroke.
 
  • Two large trials, the International Stroke Trial (IST) and the Chinese Acute Stroke Trial (CAST), found that the use of aspirin within 48 h of stroke onset reduced both stroke recurrence risk and mortality.

  • Numerous clinical trials have failed to demonstrate any benefit of routine anticoagulation in the primary treatment of atherothrombotic cerebral ischemia and have also shown an increase in the risk of brain and systemic hemorrhage. Therefore, the routine use of heparin or other anticoagulants for patients with atherothrombotic stroke is not warranted.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3338.

questions.text: What is the basis for transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation?
questions.solution:
Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) is based on gate-controlled theory of pain.

The working of the spinal pain suppression mechanism is explained by the gate control hypothesis. This theory holds that the dorsal grey horn serves as a gate for the transmission of pain sensation, and that segmental suppression and supraspinal suppression can partially or completely seal this gate.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 169

questions.text: Identify the additional mechanism of action of tramadol apart from its regular function like all opioids, where it acts as an analgesic drug by stimulating M opioid receptors.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) Serotonin and nor-adrenaline reuptake inhibitor

  • A synthetic codeine analogue called tramadol is used to relieve mild to moderate acute pain.
  • In an FDC format, it is combined with acetaminophen to provide analgesia.
  • As a result, it is ineffective for treating persistent or severe pain.
* It is an enantiomer racemic combination. In addition to µ receptor agonism, it is an agonist at the alpha 2 receptor and prevents serotonin and norepinephrine from being reabsorbed.
  • Dextro (+) enantiomer--- µ agonist and inhibits serotonin reuptake
  • Levo (-) enantiomer ----Alpha 2 agonist and inhibits norepinephrine reuptake

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 504.

questions.text: Except for____________all exhibit coarse tongue tremors.
questions.solution:
Thyrotoxicosis leads to fine tongue tremors, not the coarse tongue tremors.

Causes of coarse tremors include:

  • Alcoholism
  • Drug addiction
  • Anxiety Disorder
  • Tongue Paralysis
  • Parkinsonism

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about Kluver-Bucy syndrome?
questions.solution:
Hyperactivity is not seen in Klüver-Bucy syndrome. Features of the syndrome include: Visual agnosia Increased oral tendency Decreased emotional reaction Hypersexuality, Hypermetamorphosis( increased curosity and tendency to explore the surrounding), Placidity is decreased emotional reaction.

Kluver Bucky syndrome is associated with fro to temporal dementia where decision making, empathy and emotional compromise is present . The patient presents with hyperphagia, hyperorality (no inhibitions, says what comes to mind), hyper sexuality.


Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK544221/

questions.text: Which of these are the clinical features of a patient who was on 3 ml of Morphine epidurally until one day, when the nurse accidentally gave 12 ml of morphine epidurally
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 4) Urinary retention
 
  • When morphine is injected epidurally, it first settles in the epidural space around sacral segments due to gravity.
  • This phenomenon will occur even if the dose is increased from 3 ml to 12 ml.
  • Therefore, urinary retention will always be seen as urinary bladder is innervated by sacral spinal nerves.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 501.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with right hemiparesis and 2.5 hours of speech loss presented to emergency. BP is 180/100. What is the best course of action for managing this patient moving forward?
questions.solution:
The next best step in the management of this patient is go for NCCT Brain.

  • Following the clinical diagnosis of stroke, a sequential process of evaluation and treatment should ensue. The first objective is to prevent or reverse brain injury.
  • Attend to the patient's airway, breathing, and circulation (ABCs) and, if hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia is detected, treat it.
  • Perform an emergency noncontrast head CT scan to distinguish between ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke.



Management of Acute Stroke: 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3336, 3337.

choices.text: The person appears confused to the onlooks
Remote memory is relatively intact during the blackout
It is a discrete episode of anterograde amnesia

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about blackouts?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: The person appears confused to the onlooks 

A blackout is defined as temporary loss of consciousness due to fainting, drug intoxication or injury. A person more often loses consciousness than looks confused
Option 2 : is true as the person only experiences short term anterograde amnesia, retrograde and remote memories stay intact.
Option 3 and 4 are also true.

   


Reference-: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition 3315,3558

questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) 5HT and NE uptake inhibitor
  • A synthetic codeine analogue called tramadol is used to relieve mild to moderate acute pain. In an FDC, it is combined with acetaminophen to provide analgesia.
  • As a result, it is ineffective for treating persistent or severe pain.
* It is an enantiomer racemic combination. In addition to µ receptor agonism, it is an agonist at the alpha 2 receptor and prevents serotonin and norepinephrine from being reabsorbed.
 
  • Dextro (+) enantiomer -- µ agonist and inhibits serotonin reuptake
  • Levo(-) enantiomer -- Alpha 2 agonist and inhibits norepinephrine reuptake

questions.text: A 32-year-old Bengali woman presented with a 48-hour fever, a history of meaningless chatter, and two occurrences of tonic-clonic seizures that occurred back-to-back on the way to the hospital. She also had bizarre behaviour and memory disturbances. Before, she had been fine. Which medication from the list below can be administered while the other investigations are ongoing?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. IV acyclovir

The above clinical scenario with meaningless chatter, GTCS, abnormal behaviour and memory disturbances point the diagnosis towards HSV (viral) encephalitis.
 
  • The patient with encephalitis commonly has an altered level of consciousness (confusion, behavioral abnormalities), or a depressed level of consciousness ranging from mild lethargy to coma, and evidence of either focal or diffuse neurologic signs and symptoms.
  • Patients with encephalitis may have hallucinations, agitation, personality change, behavioral disorders, and, at times, a frankly psychotic state.
 
  • HSV encephalitis should be considered when clinical features suggest involvement of the inferomedial frontotemporal regions of the brain, including prominent olfactory or gustatory hallucinations, anosmia, unusual or bizarre behavior or personality alterations, or memory disturbance.
  • HSV encephalitis should always be suspected in patients with signs and symptoms consistent with acute encephalitis with focal findings on clinical examination, neuroimaging studies, or EEG.
 
  • Diagnosis: The diagnostic procedure of choice in these patients is CSF PCR analysis for HSV. A positive CSF PCR establishes the diagnosis.
 
  • Treatment: Acyclovir is of benefit in the treatment of HSV and should be started empirically in patients with suspected viral encephalitis, especially if focal features are present, while awaiting viral diagnostic studies.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1094, 1097.

choices.text: The root value for this reflex is L1, L2 and L3
The guy is performing it in the wrong way
Deep tendon reflexes are always brisk in motor neuron disease
