questions.text: Topiramate is used to treat which of the following conditions:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 3) Lennox-Gastaut syndrome
 
  • FDA approved it as initial monotherapy (in patients at least 10 years old) and as adjunctive therapy (for patients as young as 2 years) for focal-onset or primary generalized tonic-clonic seizures, for Lennox-Gastaut syndrome in patients 2 years of age and older, and for migraine prophylaxis in adults.
  • MOA- It activates a hyperpolarizing K+ current, decreases voltage-gated Na+ currents in cerebellar granule cells, enhances postsynaptic GABA-A receptor currents, and restricts activation of the AMPA-kainate subtype(s) of glutamate receptors. Carbonic anhydrase's weak inhibitor.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 447.

choices.text: Sequential nerve demyelination followed by inflammatory myopathy during course of disease
Cranial nerves are involved more commonly than peripheral nerve
Diaphragmatic atony due to prolonged intubation may cause it

questions.text: What is true regarding the critical illness myoneuropathy?
questions.solution:
Diaphragmatic atony due to prolonged intubation may cause critical illness myoneuropathy.
 
  • Critical illness polyneuropathy (CIP) or critical illness myopathy (CIM) are the most common causes of weakness in critically ill patients in the ICU due to prolonged neuromuscular blockade. 
  • Both CIM and CIP develop as a complication of sepsis and multiple organ failure. They usually present as an inability to wean a patient from a ventilator.
 
  • Serum creatine kinase (CK) levels are usually normal; an elevated serum CK level indicates CIM rather than CIP.
  • In CIP, nerve conduction studies show that motor and sensory studies are absent or have significantly reduced amplitudes, whereas sensory studies are relatively preserved in CIM.
 
  • Improvement takes weeks in mild cases and months in severe cases. Over 50% of patients have reported complete recovery.
  • In more severe cases, however, recovery may be incomplete or may not occur at all.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3490.

questions.text: Which of the following sensations is not felt by the trigeminal nerve's spinal nucleus?
questions.solution:
Proprioception is not perceived by the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve. Rather, it is perceived by the mesencephalic nucleus of trigeminal nerve present in midbrain.

Spinal nucleus is continuous superiorly with the main sensory nucleus in the pons and extends inferiorly through the whole length of medulla oblongata° and into the upper part of the spinal cord as far as the second cervical segment.

Sensations of pain, temperature touch and pressure from the skin of face and mucous membranes travel along axons whose cell bodies are situated in semilunar or trigeminal sensory ganglion.

 

Reference- Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition Page no 3437

choices.text: Can be initiated in minimally motivated person
When used with alcohol, the patient feels drowsiness, chest discomfort and respiratory depression
It’s action persists for 2~3 days after stopping the drug

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Disulfiram is correct
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 3) When used with alcohol, the patient feels drowsiness, chest discomfort and respiratory depression
 
  • Disulfiram used with alcohol causes patient to feel drowsiness, chest discomfort & respiratory depression.
  • Disulfiram is given to highly motivated patients. It is an aversive agent. It inhibits aldehyde dehydrogenase leading to increase in concentration of acetaldehyde which causes: Drowsiness Chest discomfort Respiratory depression.
  • Its action persists for upto 2 weeks after stopping it.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 421.

questions.text: A patient fell unconscious two hours ago after experiencing a sudden, acute headache which he describes as the worst headache of life. He later became conscious but has neck rigidity and photophobia. What should be done after that?
questions.solution:
Most probable diagnosis in this case is subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).
 
  • In SAH, sudden loss of consciousness may be preceded by a brief moment of excruciating headache, but most patients first complain of headache upon regaining consciousness.
 
  • The patient often calls the headache “the worst headache of my life”; however, the most important characteristic is sudden onset.
 
  • NCCT head should be done in this case to confirm the diagnosis. On CT scans, subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) appears as a high-attenuating, amorphous substance that fills the normally dark, CSF-filled subarachnoid spaces around the brain. The normally black subarachnoid cisterns and sulci may appear white in acute hemorrhage.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3354, 3355.

questions.text: Which type of feedback is Baroreceptor reflex?
questions.solution:
The baroreceptor reflex is a rapid negative feedback system which results in the heart rate falling and blood pressure decreasing after an increase in such is detected. If a decrease in blood pressure is detected, the baroreflex is deactivated, which leads to an increase in heart rate and returns the blood pressure back to its typical levels.

 

Reference- Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition Page nos: 8-10

questions.text: Which of the following antidepressants is the least likely to cause sexual dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 2) Mirtazapine
 
  • The antidepressant Mirtazapine causes the least sexual dysfunction.
  • SSRIs cause increase in serotonin that stimulates 5HT-2 receptor present in spinal cord and leads to sexual dysfunction such as erectile dysfunction and anorgasmia.
  • 5HT-2 receptor blockers such as mirtazapine do not have this action and hence, are associated with  decreased sexual side effects.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 490.

questions.text: An elderly patient with hypertension who developed a sudden onset headache, nausea, and neck stiffness but no localised neurological deficit. What will be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An elderly, hypertensive patient presented with sudden onset headache, vomiting, neck rigidity without focal neurological deficit, diagnosis in this case is subarachnoid hemorrhage.

NCCT is done to confirm diagnosis.

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
 
  • MC cause: Trauma >Spontaneous rupture of Berry aneurysm
  • Clinical Features: Sudden transient loss of consciousness, Complaint of Severe headache in 45% of cases and is more commonly on regaining consciousness. Neck stiffness and vomiting without Focal neurological deficit and Sudden headache in the absence of focal neurological deficit is the hallmark sign.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3354.

questions.text: Receptors that are blocked in Myasthenia Gravis are:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Ach receptors

Anti-postsynaptic ACh receptor are blocked in MG. Most common NMJ disorder

Pre-synaptic Ca++ receptors are blocked in Lambert-Eaton syndrome. 




 

Reference-:Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition Page no 345

questions.text: Which one of the following medications is an opioid antitussive
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Levopropoxyphene
 
  • Levopropoxyphene is derived from propoxyphene which is an opioid.
  • Propoxyphene is a racemic mixture of Levo - propoxyphene and dextro - propoxyphene. Levo - propoxyphene is used as an antitussive while dextro - propoxyphene is used as an analgesic.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 239.

choices.text: Replacement of stylet prior to removal of needle

questions.text: Which of the following is not an effective strategy to decrease the risk of post-puncture dural headache?
questions.solution:
Supplementation, of fluid does not prevent post-dura/ puncture headache (PDPH). 

Techniques for prevention of Post-dural Puncture Headache are: 

Use of atraumatic pencil-point spinal needle, Direction of bevel insertion parallel to the longitudinal dural fibers for cutting needles, smaller needle size, replacement of stylet before withdrawing the spinal needle, Ultrasound guided neuraxial blocks, lesser number of lumbar puncture attempts.

POST DURAL PUNCTURE HEADACHE:

  • May follow lumbar puncture, spinal anesthesia, wet epidural tap (in which epidural needle pierced dura).
  • Onset 12-72hrs and last for 1-2 weeks.
  • Aggravated by sitting and relieved by lying down.
  • Incidence increases with the larger needle, cutting point (in comparison to pencil point) needle, young age, females, pregnancy.
  • Prevention by thinner needle 

Management: 

  1. Supine position
  2. IV fluids
  3. Caffeine and analgesia
  4. Epidural blood patch 



Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 8th edition, Page no 1712.
Morgan and Mikhail's Clinical Anesthesiology, 5th edition, Page no 969.

choices.text: C/L loss of joint sense and position

questions.text: What pattern is seen in Brown sequard syndrome?
questions.solution:
In Brown Sequard syndrome i.e. hemisection of spinal cord there is ipsilateral touch, propioception loss due to involvement of dorsal column, ipsilateral motor loss due to involvement of pyramidal tract and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation because these fibres cross over to form the lateral spinothalmic tract.

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 168

questions.text:
Which of the following is used in treatment of both seizures as well as neuropathic pain?
(i) Gabapentin
(ii) Lamotrigine
(iii) Carbamazepine
(iv) Pregabalin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) i, iii, iv

  • Among the given options, Gabapentin, Pregabalin and Carbamazepine are used in the treatment of neuropathic pain and seizures.
  • Gabapentin and pregabalin act by increasing GABA release at synapse by binding to presynaptic calcium channels and blocking endocytosis of calcium.
  • Carbamazepine is a sodium channel blocker. It is the drug of choice in the treatment of partial seizures and trigeminal neuralgia.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 446.

questions.text:
A patient with a history of alcoholism is brought to the emergency room by his wife. Due to religious obligations, the person has abstained from alcohol for the past two days.
The participant reported feeling queasy, nauseated, and dizzy. He began having seizures on the second day, which later turned into widespread tonic-clonic seizures (GTCS).
Which of the following would be the most effective medication to treat the patient's seizure?
questions.solution:
The seizures in this patient and above clinical features are suggestive of Delirium tremens, due to acute alcohol withdrawal.

  • Delirium tremens (DTs), where the withdrawal includes delirium (mental confusion, agitation, and fluctuating levels of consciousness) associated with a tremor, seizure and autonomic overactivity (e.g., marked increases in pulse, blood pressure, and respirations).
  • Diazepam would can be used to manage the seizure of the patient. 
 
  • Although most depressants are effective, benzodiazepines have the most supportive data for use in this situation, combining a high level of safety and low cost.
  • To treat mild-moderate, uncomplicated alcohol withdrawal, either long acting benzodiazepines like chlordiazepoxide or diazepam or short-acting ones like lorazepam can be taken.
  • Chlordiazepoxide is favoured over diazepam for this purpose.
  • Liver disease is associated frequently with alcohol use. 
Benzodiazepines safe in Liver disease-
LOve The liver
L- Lorazepam
O- Oxazepam
T- Temazepam




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3561.

questions.text: Alpha waves are seen during which wave?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Relaxed state

   


 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 271,272

questions.text: A patient who had suffered a pelvic fracture and head injuries was given morphine for pain. As a result, he started having trouble breathing. What might be the reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) CO2 retention due to opioid use

CO2 retention due to opioid use is the cause for respiratory difficulty.

* Morphine use in head injury causes:
  • i. Respiratory depression
  • ii. Increases CO2
  • iii. Increases ICT
  • iv. Miosis
Therefore, use of morphine in cases of head injury is contraindicated.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 499.

questions.text: What is a cognitive remediation used for?
questions.solution:
Cognitive remediation is used for cognitive restructuring. 

  • Cognitive remediation therapy (CRT), also known as cognitive enhancement therapy (CET), is a type of cognitive rehabilitation therapy developed at Kings College in London with the goal of enhancing neurocognitive skills like executive functioning, planning, flexibility, attention, and working memory.
 
  • These skills all contribute to social functioning.




Reference: Fan, Qing et al. “The Application of Cognitive Remediation Therapy in The Treatment of Mental Disorders.” Shanghai archives of psychiatry vol. 29,6 (2017): 373-375. doi:10.11919/j.issn.1002-0829.217079. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5925589/

questions.text: What exactly is prosopagnosia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Difficulty in identifying known faces

        Anosognosia – being unaware of own’s problems
        Prosopagnosia – difficulty in identifying known faces
        Agnosia – failure to identify objects
 Prosopagnosia occurs due to involvement of Dominant Temporal Lobe. 
 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no287

questions.text:
Which of the following medications are used to treat absence seizures?
A. Carbamazepine
B. Valproate
C. Ethosuximide
D. Gabapentin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) B and C only
 
  • Valproate and ethosuximide are the drugs used for absence seizures.
  • Most preferred drugs in absence seizures are those which have calcium channel blocking property. 
  • Valproate is used for atypical absence seizure
  • Ethosuximide is used for Typical absence seizure

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 390.

questions.text: An older, hypertensive patient is experiencing sudden onset headache, vomiting, and neck rigidity without a specific neurological abnormality. What is the correct diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An elderly, hypertensive patient presented with sudden onset headache, vomiting, neck rigidity without focal neurological deficit, diagnosis in this case is subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Features of SAH would include- 

1. Sudden, severe headache
2. Stiff neck
3. Nausea and vomiting
4. Decreased alertness, confusion
5. Seizures
6. Vision changes, such as blurred or double vision
7. Loss of consciousness
8. Facial weakness
9. Weakness or numbness in an arm or leg
10. Difficulty speaking or understanding speech



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3354.

questions.text: Abdominal spasm discomfort is reduced by using a hot water bottle via:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Stimulation of adrenergic fibers

Gate Control Theory of pain suggests that the spinal cord has a neurological 'gate' that controls pain signals to the brain. It asserts that non-painful input closes the nerve "gates" to painful input, which prevents pain sensation from traveling to the central nervous system
  • Visceral pain from the gastrointestinal tract is largely mediated by pain relaying ‘C’ fibers that run almost exclusively in the sympathetic (adrenergic) system
  • Heat impulses from hot water bottles are transmitted through larger A fibers and C fibers which have higher velocity
  • Relief of pain with a hot water bottle involves modulation of sympathetic pathways through stimulation of the ‘A’ and ‘C’ fibers thereby blocking the pain sensation carried by small ‘C’ fibers.

   


 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 164

Match the following drugs with their antidotes.
A. Heparin 1. Levocarnitine
B. Ethylene glycol 2. Protamine
C. Hydrofluoric acid 3. Fomepizole
D. Valproate 4. Calcium gluconate
questions.solution:

  • Heparin Excessive Bleeding = Protamine
  • Ethylene glycol Metabolic Acidosis= Fomepizole
  • Hydrofluoric Acid Electrolyte Abnormality = Calcium gluconate

questions.text: Which part of the brain is most likely to experience atrophy in Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Temporoparietal

  • In Alzheimer's disease, the part of the brain most likely to experience atrophy is the temporoparietal region.
  • This area is involved in cognitive functions such as memory, language, and spatial orientation, which are commonly affected in Alzheimer's disease.
 
  • In typical amnestic AD, brain atrophy begins in the medial temporal lobes before spreading to the inferior temporal, lateral, medial parietal, and dorsolateral frontal cortices.
  • The pattern of binding is largely consistent with Braak neuropathologic staging of NFTs, with early retention in medial temporal regions, followed by spread into temporoparietal and cingulate cortices, dorsolateral prefrontal regions, and, ultimately, primary sensory and motor areas.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3370, 3371.

questions.text: Lesions of the lateral cerebellum do not cause:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Resting tremor

Resting tremors are a typical feature of Parkinson’s disease.

Parts of cerebellum



Cerebellar lesions will show the following-
  • Ataxia/drunken gait
  • Dysdiadekokinesia
  • Nystagmus
  • Intention tremor
  • Past pointing
  • Pendular knee jerk
 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no245,246,247

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct
A. Morphine used in pulmonary oedema
B. Pethidine used in biliary colic
C. Indomethacin is used in headache
D. Aspirin used in peptic ulcer
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) A, B, & C

* Morphine
  • i. Used in pulmonary oedema as it transfers blood from pulmonary to systemic circulation.
  • ii. Used in MI as it decreases preload as well as pain.
  • iii. Decreases sympathetic outflow
  • iv. Contraindicated in biliary colic.
* Pethidine
  • i. Has anticholinergic properties.
  • ii. Used in colicky abdominal pains
  • iii. Relaxes the spasm of biliary sphincter
* Indomethacin
  • i. Preferred for paroxysmal hemicrania
  • ii. Side effect causes frontal headache Aspirin is not used in peptic ulcer cases.
* Aspirin causes peptic ulcer due to COX-1 inhibition-> less prostaglandin production, which act as barrier against gastric acid.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 213.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is bumping into things and is experiencing acute onset amnesia. Upon assessment, she displayed normal comprehension, fluency of speaking, and alertness. Additional testing found difficulties identifying the fingers, right-left confusion, impaired arithmetic skills, and impaired writing (acalculia). MRI results showed leptomeningeal augmentation and foci of increased cortical and subcortical T2 signals. The following is the likely cause:
questions.solution:
• Gerstman syndrome is a neurological disorder caused by damage to the dominant hemisphere of the Parietal lobe which results in symptoms including difficulty with simple arithmetic, difficulty with writing, difficulty naming individual fingers, and difficulty telling the difference between the right and left side of the body.
 
  • It is commonly associated with damage to the inferior parietal lobule, specifically the angular gyrus of the dominant parietal lobe. 


Principal features of Gerstman syndrome:
 
  1. Acalculia
  2. Alexia
  3. Finger agnosia
  4. Right-left confusion



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3326.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the Motor Neuron Disease lesion site?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Anterior Horn cells 

The lesion site associated with MND is primarily the anterior horn cells. These cells are responsible for transmitting motor signals from the central nervous system to the skeletal muscles.
 Spinothalamic and spinocerebellar tracts are sensory tracts and therefore unrelated to MND.

      

 

Reference- Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition 165

questions.text:
Which of the following medications will aggravate myasthenia gravis?
A. Lidocaine
B. Meropenem
C. Phenytoin
D. Digene
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) A & D only
 
  • Drugs that will worsen myasthenia gravis are lidocaine and digene.
  • Lidocaine decreases the sensitivity of the postsynaptic membrane to acetylcholine and Antacids like digene may interfere with neuromuscular transmission and hence may lead to worsening of MG.
* Drugs which aggravate myasthenia gravis include:

Aminoglycosides, beta-blockers, LAs, Magnesium (present in digene ), non-depolarizing muscle relaxants and quinine.
 

Here’s a simplified table of drugs to avoid in Myasthenia Gravis along with a mnemonic to remember them:

Drug Class/Example Drugs to Avoid
Aminoglycosides - Gentamicin- Tobramycin
Beta-blockers - Propranolol- Atenolol
Calcium Channel Blockers - Verapamil- Diltiazem
Chloroquine/Hydroxychloroquine - Chloroquine- Hydroxychloroquine
Magnesium Salts - Magnesium sulfate
Quinidine (Antiarrhythmic) - Quinidine
Phenytoin (Anticonvulsant) - Phenytoin
Sedatives (Benzodiazepines) - Diazepam- Lorazepam

Mnemonic: "ABC's Can Cause Myasthenic Problems Quickly"

  • A = Aminoglycosides
  • B = Beta-blockers
  • C = Calcium channel blockers
  • C = Chloroquine/Hydroxychloroquine
  • M = Magnesium salts
  • P = Phenytoin
  • Q = Quinidine
  • S = Sedatives (Benzodiazepines)
Online Reference:
Sheikh S, Alvi U, Soliven B, Rezania K. Drugs That Induce or Cause Deterioration of Myasthenia Gravis: An Update. J Clin Med. 2021 Apr 6;10(7):1537. doi: 10.3390/jcm10071537. PMID: 33917535; PMCID: PMC8038781.

questions.text: A glass factory worker presented with complaints of numbness in hands and feet, generalized weakness and constipation. Radiograph showed linear lines on metaphyses of knee and wrist joints. How will you diagnose this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical features are suggestive of exposure to lead. 

Main causes for the pathology of lead is that it interferes with the activity of an essential enzyme called Delta aminolevulinic acid dehydratase, which is important in the biosynthesis of heme, the cofactor found in hemoglobin.

  • Lead also inhibits the enzyme ferrochelatase, another enzyme involved in the formation of heme.
  • Ferrochelatase catalyzes the joining of protoporphyrin and Fe2+ plus to form heme.
  • Another effect of lead's interference with heme synthesis is the buildup of heme precursors, such as aminolevulinic acid, which may be directly or indirectly harmful to neurons and which are excreted in urine.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3580.

questions.text:
Release of ACh is enhanced by blocking which of the following?
1. Voltage gated Na+ channel block presynaptically
2. Cl- channel block presynaptically 
3. K+ channel block presynaptically 
4. Ca2+ channel block presynaptically
questions.solution:
Blocking the potassium channels on presynaptic membrane enhances acetylcholine release. Blocking potassium channel pre-synaptically leads to depolarisation that leads to Ca++ channel opening and Ca++ ion entry that leads to release of neurotransmitters.

Acetylcholine (ACh) is a neurotransmitter that is stored in vesicles and is released when an action potential in the motor neuron opens Ca2+ channels in the presynaptic terminal. Each vesicle contains 10,000 molecules of ACh and 60 to 125 vesicles are released with each nerve impulse.

Ach diffuses across the synaptic cleft, allowing Na+ and K+ channels to open and depolarizing the muscle end plate (but not producing an action potential). Local currents in the membrane are induced by depolarization of the muscular end plate, depolarizing the membrane to the threshold and generating action potentials.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 132

questions.solution:
• LP in adults is done at the level of L3-L4 because spinal cord ends at a level above that.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics makes it easier to tell seizures as compared to syncope?
questions.solution:
The characteristic that makes it easier to distinguish seizures from syncope is Urinary incontinence (option 3).

Here's why:

  • Seizures often involve involuntary movements, loss of motor control, and autonomic disturbances like urinary incontinence. It's not uncommon for someone to lose bladder control during a seizure, particularly in generalized tonic-clonic seizures.

  • Syncope, on the other hand, typically involves a transient loss of consciousness due to a sudden drop in blood flow to the brain, but urinary incontinence is much less common in syncope.

Let's quickly review the other options:

  1. Loss of consciousness: Both seizures and syncope involve a loss of consciousness, so this is not a distinguishing factor.
  2. Injury due to fall: Both seizures and syncope can result in a fall and injury, though the mechanisms differ (seizures due to uncontrolled movement, syncope due to collapse from a sudden drop in blood pressure). This doesn't reliably distinguish between the two.
  3. Urinary incontinence: As explained above, this is more commonly seen in seizures than syncope, making it a helpful distinguishing feature.
  4. Physical weakness with clear sensorium: This is more suggestive of syncope, as people usually regain full awareness shortly after syncope. In seizures, the postictal state (after the seizure) often involves confusion or altered consciousness.

So, urinary incontinence is the key feature that points more toward seizures than syncope.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3315.

questions.text: A monkey has increased sexual activity, greater appetite, aggression, and no fear. This could be due to damage to which of the following structures
questions.solution:
Klüver-Bucy Syndrome, which is caused by bilateral amygdala ablation, is the most likely diagnosis. Amygdala is a group of several small nuclei that are situated close to the medial anterior pole of each temporal lobe. The monkey exhibits the following behavioural changes when the anterior portions of both temporal lobes are destroyed: is not afraid of anything, has extreme curiosity about everything, forgets things easily, has a propensity to put everything in its mouth and occasionally tries to eat solid objects frequently has a sex drive so strong that it tries to copulate with young animals, animals of the wrong sex, or even animals.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 105

questions.text: Anti-emetics were administered to the patient who was vomiting. After the patient's symptoms were eased, strange motions later developed. What medication is recommended to lessen the movements?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Benzhexol

The given clinical vignette describes the condition called Drug induced Parkinsonism. Here in the question it has been mentioned that the patient was administered an anti emetic drug following which he/ she developed movements. This implies that the person was given D2 receptor antagonist ( Eg PROCHLORPERAZINE, METOCLOPRAMIDE ) as Anti emetic drug following which he developed extra pyramidal symptoms.

A general rule is that when the dopamine levels in brain falls as a reflex the cholinergic levels rise in our bodies. Hence the treatment of Drug induced parkinsonism involves the administration of drugs which can reduce the excess cholinergic activity.

* DOC FOR DRUG INDUCED PARKINSONISM/DRUG INDUCED DEVELOPMENT OF EXTRAPYRAMIDAL SYMPTOMS :- Benztropine, Trihexyphenidyl

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 460.

questions.text: Which of the following modes of treatment has demonstrated the best seizure-free duration in medically untreatable seizures?
questions.solution:
The most effective treatment for medically intractable seizures that shows best seizure-free period includes Resective epilepsy surgery. 
 
  • Advances in presurgical evaluation and microsurgical techniques have led to a steady increase in the success of epilepsy surgery. For example, ~70% of well-selected patients treated with temporal lobectomy will become seizure free, and another 15–25% will have at least a 90% reduction in seizure frequency.
  • Marked improvement is also usually seen in patients treated with hemispherectomy for catastrophic seizure disorders due to large hemispheric abnormalities.
  • Postoperatively, patients generally need to remain on antiseizure drug therapy, but the marked reduction of seizures following resective surgery can have a very beneficial effect on quality of life.

Additional treatments that may improve seizure control include corticosteroids, antiepileptic drugs, and gamma ray radiosurgery. However, these treatments may only reduce seizure frequency or severity, but may not achieve complete seizure freedom.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3321.

questions.text:
Which of the following assertions about the mechanisms of depolarization, repolarization, and hyperpolarization in the skeletal muscle action potential is correct?
A. Depolarisation due to influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels
B. Depolarisation due to influx of Na+ through ligand- gated channels
C. Repolarisation due to efflux of K+through voltage - gated channels
D. Repolarisation due to efflux of K+ through ligand - gated channel
E. Hyperpolarization due to efflux of K+
questions.solution:
Skeletal muscle action potential:
  1. Resting membrane potential.
  2. Some voltage gated sodium channels open and sodium enters cell - Threshold potential.
  3. Opening of more voltage gated sodium channels, rapid upstroke - Depolarisation.
  4. Reached to peak level
  5. Sodium channels close with opening of voltage gated potassium channels - Repolarisation
  6. Slow return of potassium channels to closed state - Hyperpolarisation.
  7. Return to resting membrane potential.
 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 105

questions.text: Which of these is Bilateral Babinski sign a characteristic of?
questions.solution:
• The bilateral Babinski sign is an important sign of pontine haemorrhage due to damage to nerve tracts that run through the pons. This typically presents as an extensor response of the toes (upward) when the sole of the foot is firmly stroked.
  • It is essential for clinicians to be aware of this sign as it can indicate the severity of the pontine haemorrhage and may provide important information on the patient's neurological prognosis.
  • In cases of pontine hemorrhage, the presence of a bilateral Babinski sign should be an alarm for clinicians to consider an urgent intervention such as a surgical evacuation of the hematoma.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 165.
Rao, Gurukanth; Vaibhav, S.; Belle, Jayaprakash. A Case of Resolving Pontine Hemorrhage. APIK Journal of Internal Medicine 12(3):p 186-188, Jul–Sep 2024. | DOI: 10.4103/ajim.ajim_34_22. URL: https://journals.lww.com/joim/fulltext/2024/12030/a_case_of_resolving_pontine_hemorrhage.11.aspx

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is correct about skeletal muscle contraction
A. Extracellular Ca++ not important for contraction
B. Ca++ released from mitochondria
C. Ca++ releases from sarcoplasmic reticulum
D. Voltage gated Ca++ channel on sarcolemma has no role in EC coupling
E. Ca++ channel on sarcoplasmic reticulum has no role in EC coupling
questions.solution:
The true statements are- C. Storehouse of Ca++ ions in skeletal muscle is Sarcoplasmic reticulum A. Extracellular Ca++ is not important for contraction On receiving signal from the nerve terminal, changes in the sarcolemma’s resting potential cause release of calcium from its stores present in the sarcoplasmic reticulum. Hence, the skeletal muscle is not dependent on extracellular calcium for contraction.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 105

questions.text: Which medication from the list below can be applied as a transcranial patch to treat Parkinson's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Rotigotine
 
  • Rotigotine can be used as a transcranial patch for the treatment of Parkinson’s disease.
  • It is a dopamine agonist that works on the nervous system to help treat the symptoms of Parkinson disease.
  • Rotigotine is also used to treat a condition called Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS).
  • Rotigotine should not be stopped abruptly because sudden withdrawal of Dopaminergic agonists has been associated with a syndrome resembling neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 418.

choices.text: As anti-ACHR is negative you will consider an alternative diagnosis

questions.text: A 50-year-old man complained of ptosis, chewing difficulties, and occasionally had trouble swallowing. No prior instances of vision loss exist. With a finger abduction test at a 60° angle, there is symmetric ptosis and a slight restriction of extraocular muscle movement causing diplopia. Only the orbicularis exhibits a decreasing response in a nerve conduction examination. An ERG pattern was myopathic. Radioimmunoassay for anti-AchR proved ineffective. The following is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Generalized myasthenia gravis is the most likely diagnosis. This condition commonly causes ptosis and diplopia as initial complaints and reveals a characteristic pattern of muscle weakness.


Clinical features:
 
  • The distribution of muscle weakness often has a characteristic pattern. The cranial muscles, particularly the lids and extraocular muscles (EOMs), are typically involved early in the course of MG; diplopia and ptosis are common initial complaints.
  • Facial weakness produces a“snarling” expression when the patient attempts to smile.
  • Weakness in chewing is most noticeable after prolonged effort, as in chewing meat
  • Difficulty in swallowing may occur as a result of weakness of the palate, tongue, or pharynx, giving rise to nasal regurgitation or aspiration of liquids or food.

Autoantibodies Associated with MG:
  • Anti-AChR antibodies are detectable in the serum of ~85% of all myasthenic patients but in only ~50% of patients with weakness confined to the ocular muscles.
  • The presence of anti-AChR antibodies is virtually diagnostic of MG, but a negative test does not exclude the disease.
  • The measured level of anti-AChR antibody does not correspond well with the severity of MG in different patients.
  • Antibodies to MuSK are present in ~40% of AChR antibody–negative patients with generalized MG.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3510, 3511.

questions.text: The diagram shows a time trace of a basic muscle twitch in the gastrocnemius of a frog. What is the minimum tetanizing frequency of this muscle
questions.solution:
In the given diagram, time tracing is recorded with vibrating tunning fork. Calculation: Frequency of tunning fork- 100Hz 100 times per sec 1 wave is of 0.01 secs Number of waves in contraction period is 5 Minimal tetanizing frequency = 1/0.05 = 20/sec.

Formula: Tetanizing Frequency = 1/ contraction period

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 107

questions.text: A 50-year-old man who first had weakness in his right lower limb then, within a year, in his left lower limb. He has been experiencing distal upper limb weakness, increased tone, and rapid reflexes in the last two months. Neither sensory loss nor bladder dysfunction have a history. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) ALS

 
* CLINICAL MANIFESTATIONS:
 
  • Asymmetric weakness that slowly develops and usually manifests itself distally in one of the limbs. 
  • Sudden onset of cramping during voluntary movements, usually in the early morning (e.g., while stretching in bed). 
  • Muscle atrophy and progressive muscular withering.
  • fasciculations, or the spontaneous twitching of motor units, early in the illness. 
  • Extensor weakness predominates over flexor weakness in the hands. 
  • Early denervation affects bulbar muscles as opposed to limb muscles, and the condition initially manifests as difficulty chewing, swallowing, and moving the face and tongue. 
  • Muscle-stretch reflexes are overactive (tendon jerks), and there is frequently spastic resistance to passive motions of the affected limbs. 
  • Muscle stiffness frequently outweighs weakness. 
  • Cognitive, digestive and bladder, and sensory functioning are unaffected.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 3410.

questions.text: What course of treatment is recommended for intractable Sydenham’s Chorea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2): Valproate
 
  • Intractable Sydenham's Chorea is a neurological disorder characterized by involuntary movements.
  • It is typically associated with rheumatic fever. When symptoms are severe and do not respond to other treatments, Valproate is recommended.
  • Valproate is an antiepileptic medication, works by increasing the levels of GABA, a neurotransmitter that helps regulate neuronal activity.
The Modified Jones Criteria is used for the diagnosis of Rheumatic Fever,
          
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2768.

questions.text: Calculate the tetanizing frequency of the skeletal muscle from the given data: Latent period - 10msec, Contraction period - 40msec, Relaxation period - 50msec.
questions.solution:
Tetany is defined as the sustained contraction of a muscle due to increased frequency of stimuli. Tetanising frequency (Tf) of a muscle is inversely proportional to the contraction period. Tf= 1/40=25 per sec.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 107

questions.text: Which of the following causes discriminative touch sensation
questions.solution:
Merkel disc - Two point discrimination, sustained pressure, used by blind people for reading braille 
meisseners - slow vibrations 
pacinian - fast vibrations
ruffini - deep pressure
krause- cold 
Free nerve endings - pain, temperature, itching and sexual sensations

questions.text: A young man with known history of heroin addiction is brought in the emergency in an unconscious state by friends. On examination his pupil are pin point. What will be the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) IV naloxone
 
  • Heroine is diacetylmorphine. In case of opioid overdose IV Naloxone is used as treatment of choice.
  • Naloxone is the drug of choice for morphine poisoning (0.4–0.8 mg i.v. every 2–3 min: max 10 mg) and for reversing neonatal asphyxia due to opioid use during labor (10 µg/kg in the cord).
  • It is also used to treat overdose with other opioids and agonist-antagonists (except buprenorphine). Repeated doses of naloxone are needed because of its short duration of action.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 512.

questions.text: Which drug is best for resistant rheumatic chorea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1): Valproate
 
  • Intractable Sydenham's Chorea is a neurological disorder characterized by involuntary movements.
  • It is typically associated with rheumatic fever. When symptoms are severe and do not respond to other treatments, Valproate is recommended.
  • Valproate is an antiepileptic medication, works by increasing the levels of GABA, a neurotransmitter that helps regulate neuronal activity.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2768.

questions.text: Pacinian Corpuscle detects which of the following sensations?
questions.solution:
Pacinian corpuscles are present deep in dermis.  They are a type of touch receptor and detect high frequency pressure.

Other types of touch receptors—

—Meissners’s Corpuscles- Detects fine touch, low frequency vibration.

—Merkel Cells-  Sensitive to sharp edges

—Ruffini’s Endings- Detects Pressure Sensation.

Trick:- 
Pacinian- Pressure 
Pacinian- Piano- Piano produces music by vibration- Vibration sense


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 158

questions.text: Which antiepileptic medicine among the following works by opening the Cl- channel?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Tiagabine 
 
  • Tiagabine is an antiepileptic medication that works by selectively inhibiting the reuptake of GABA by the GABA transporter-1 (GAT-1) in the brain.
  • By inhibiting GABA reuptake, tiagabine increases the concentration of GABA in the synaptic cleft, leading to enhanced GABAergic neurotransmission.
  • Increased GABA levels can result in the opening of Cl- channels, hyperpolarization of neurons, and overall inhibition of neuronal activity, which can help prevent seizures.
Trick: -
TiaGABINe- meaning GABA reuptake INhibitor



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 429.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with dementia, incontinence, and ataxia. It is most likely due to:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Normal pressure hydrocephalus 
 
  • Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus(NPH) is a condition characterized by the accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in the brain's ventricles, leading to enlarged ventricles and increased intracranial pressure.
 
  • The classic triad of symptoms in NPH includes gait disturbance (ataxia), cognitive decline (dementia), and urinary incontinence. "Wet, wacky, wobbly" is a phrase commonly used to describe the classic triad of symptoms
 
  • While Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease are common causes of dementia, they do not typically present with the combination of incontinence and ataxia as seen in NPH.

Steel Richardson syndrome, also known as progressive supranuclear palsy, primarily presents with motor symptoms and is not associated with incontinence.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 175, 194.

questions.text: How long does short-term memory last
questions.solution:
1) short-term memory, which includes memories that last for only a few seconds or at most minutes( 30s-300s) unless they are transformed into longer-term memories; 2) intermediate long-term memories, which last for a few days to a few weeks before fading; 3) long-term memory, which, once stored, can be recalled up to years or even a lifetime later.


 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 280

questions.text: Which of the following behaviours is exclusive to opioid receptors of the \(\mu\)[mu] type?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Pupillary constriction
 
  • Pupillary constriction (miosis) is primarily associated with the activation of opioid receptors of the mu type.
  • When mu opioid receptors are activated by opioid medications or endogenous opioids, they can cause the muscles in the iris of the eye to constrict, resulting in pupillary constriction.
  • This effect is commonly observed with mu opioid agonists, such as morphine and other opioids.
  • Supraspinal analgesia, dysphoria, and constipation can be associated with the activation of both mu (μ) and other opioid receptor types, such as delta (δ) and kappa (κ) receptors.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 507.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with acute left upper limb weakness, mitral stenosis, and atrial fibrillation. The weakness subsided completely in two weeks. The following is the likely cause:
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario points towards the diagnosis of Acute ischemic stroke (AIS) due to cardioembolism from cardiac thrombus in a case of Atrial fibrillation.
 
  • Cardioembolism is responsible for ~20% of all ischemic strokes. Stroke caused by heart disease is primarily due to embolism of thrombotic material forming on the atrial or ventricular wall or the left heart valves. These thrombi then detach and embolize into the arterial circulation. The thrombus may fragment or lyse quickly, producing only a TIA. Alternatively, the arterial occlusion may last longer, producing stroke.
 
  • Atrial fibrillation is the most common cause of cardioembolic AIS.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3339, 3340

questions.text: DHPR and RyR receptors are linked in skeletal muscle by:
questions.solution:
In skeletal muscle, the dihydropyridine receptors (DHPR) and ryanodine receptors (RyR) are linked mechanically. This coupling occurs through a physical interaction between the two types of receptors, allowing DHPR, which senses the voltage change, to trigger the release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum via RyR.

So, the correct answer is 2. Mechanically.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 102,103

questions.text: Except for______, all of the following are known side effects of Phenytoin at therapeutic dosages.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Hypoglycemia
 
  • Phenytoin primarily affects the central nervous system and does not directly interfere with blood glucose regulation or the production and release of insulin.
  • While phenytoin can have various effects on the body, hypoglycemia is not a commonly reported side effect of the phenytoin at therapeutic dosages.
* Other options:
  • Long-term use of Phenytoin can interfere with folic acid metabolism, leading to megaloblastic anemia.
  • Phenytoin can cause gingival overgrowth or hypertrophy, leading to swollen and enlarged gums.
  • Prolonged use of Phenytoin has been associated with an increased risk of osteoporosis and decreased bone mineral density.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 441.

questions.text: A 25-year-old develops focal seizures and a sudden onset of fever. The frontal lobe and temporal lobe of the brain are enhanced and hyperintense in the MRI image. The following is the likely cause:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Herpes simplex encephalitis
 
  • Herpes simplex encephalitis (HSE) is a viral infection of the brain caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV).
  • It typically presents with focal neurological symptoms, such as seizures, altered mental status, and fever.
  • The involvement of the frontal and temporal lobes is characteristic of HSE and can be observed in MRI imaging as enhanced and hyperintense regions.
  • IOC- PCR of CSF for HSV 
 
  • Meningococcal meningitis (option 1) is a bacterial infection caused by Neisseria meningitidis and primarily affects the meninges. While it can cause neurological symptoms, the MRI findings described in the scenario are not typically associated with this condition.
  • Japanese encephalitis (option 3) is a viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes and primarily affects the brain. However, the MRI findings mentioned in the scenario are not consistent with Japanese encephalitis.
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV, option 4) is a common viral infection that can affect various organs, including the brain. However, the specific MRI findings described in the scenario are not commonly associated with CMV encephalitis.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1095, 1096.

questions.text: Transcutaneous electrical stimulation (TENS) for the treatment of pain involves:
questions.solution:
Mechanism of Transcutaneous electrical stimulation TENS for pain management is gating at spinal cord.

Transcutaneous electric nerve stimulation (TENS) is used to treat pain because it modulates and controls the pain signal. A(alpha) and A(beta) fibres close to the injury are activated using electrodes in this technique.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 169

questions.text: What is an inverse agonist of the benzodiazepine receptor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Beta-carboline
 
  • Benzodiazepine receptors are found in the central nervous system and are targets for medications such as benzodiazepines, which are commonly used as sedatives, anxiolytics, and anticonvulsants.
  • An inverse agonist is a type of ligand that binds to the same receptor as an agonist but produces the opposite effect, reducing the constitutive activity of the receptor.
  • Beta-carbolines, including compounds such as Hermine and harmaline, act as inverse agonists of the benzodiazepine receptor.
  • They can produce anxiogenic (anxiety-promoting) effects and counteract the sedative and anxiolytic effects of benzodiazepines.
  • Beta-carbolines can be found in certain plants and are structurally different from benzodiazepines, but they interact with the same receptor.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 429.

questions.text: Damage to the brain caused by a head injury in a patient is made worse by
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  Hyperglycemia 
 
  • Hyperglycemia, can exacerbate brain damage caused by a head injury.
  • Elevated blood glucose levels can lead to increased inflammation, oxidative stress, and cell death in the brain.
  • It can also impair the brain's ability to regulate cerebral blood flow and worsen cerebral edema (swelling).
  • Hyperglycemia is associated with poorer outcomes and increased mortality in patients with traumatic brain injury.
 
  • Hypothermia (Option 2) is actually used as a therapeutic intervention in some cases of severe head injury to reduce brain metabolism and protect against further damage.
  • Hypocapnia (Option 3), or low levels of carbon dioxide in the blood, can cause cerebral vasoconstriction and decrease cerebral blood flow, potentially leading to ischemia and further brain injury. However, it is not a major factor in worsening brain damage compared to hyperglycemia.
  • Serum osmolality (Option 4) refers to the concentration of solutes in the blood. While severe disturbances in serum osmolality can have adverse effects on brain function, it is not directly implicated in worsening brain damage caused by a head injury.

TBI- Exacerbating and relieving factors:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3456-3458.

questions.text: Who recorded the first human EEG, the examiner questioned the student during the physiology viva. I'm not sure, the pupil said in response. Examiner decided to offer him a hint since he felt awful, saying that "the name rhymes with what you get at McDonald's". The kid then responded correctly. Which kind of memory does the learner use here?
questions.solution:
The learner in this scenario is using priming. Priming is a type of implicit memory that facilitates the retrieval of information through cues or hints. In this case, the hint about the name rhyming with something associated with McDonald's helped the student recall the name of the person who recorded the first human EEG, which is Hans Berger.

So, the correct answer is 1. Priming.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 279

questions.text: Which of the following statements about pethidine or meperidine is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Has pronounced Antitussive action
 
  • Pethidine or meperidine is an opioid analgesic commonly used for pain relief.
  • While pethidine does have antimuscarinic effects (option A), meaning it can block the actions of acetylcholine, leading to potential side effects such as dry mouth, urinary retention, and blurred vision
  •  It does not have pronounced antitussive action (option C).
  • Antitussive medications are used to suppress or relieve coughing.
  • Pethidine is known for its analgesic properties and its ability to relieve pain, but it is not considered a primary antitussive medication.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 503.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent techniques of grading is used to assess the prognosis or outcome following a subarachnoid hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Hess and hunt scale  
 
  • The Hess and Hunt scale is a grading system used to assess the prognosis or outcome following a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).
  • It evaluates the severity of SAH based on the patient's clinical presentation and the amount of blood observed on imaging studies, such as computed tomography (CT) scans.
  • The scale ranges from grade 0 to grade 5, with higher grades indicating a worse prognosis.
  • This scale helps in predicting the risk of complications and guiding the management of SAH patients.


Here's a summary table of commonly used scales in emergency medicine scenarios:






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3354.

questions.text: Which structure is impacted in the most prevalent GBS subtypes?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is option 3, b- which represents the myelin sheath of the nerve.

 GBS is a rapid onset muscle weakness caused by immune system damaging the peripheral nervous system

It is an Autoimmune disorder where the body mistakenly attacks Myelin Sheath (MOLECULAR MIMICRY).

Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy ( AIDP ) is the most common type of GBS.

In AIDP, the immune response damages myelin, which is the covering that protects axons and promotes the efficient transmission of nerve impulses.

questions.text: The likelihood of developing epilepsy following febrile convulsions is significantly increased by all of the following, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Early age of onset (age <1 year) is a risk factor for recurrence of febrile seizures, NOT Late age of onset.

The other risk factors for such recurrences are as follows:

Major:
  • Age <1 yr
  • Duration of fever <24 hours
  • Fever 38-39°C

Minor:
  • Family history of febrile seizures
  • Family history of epilepsy
  • Complex febrile seizure
  • Male gender
  • Lower serum sodium at the time of presentation



Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 3092, 3093.

questions.text: The term for a nerve injury that results in the severing of axons while leaving the outer nerve sheath intact is:
questions.solution:
In axonotmesis, the axon of nerve is injured but with intact nerve sheath.

Can heal spontaneously but sometimes require surgical repair depending on the injury. Neuropraxia occurs due to prolonged nerve compression. No injury to nerve structure. Healing occurs spontaneously.  In neurotmesis complete transection of nerve occurs. Almost always require surgical repair.




Preference : https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/22608-neuropraxia

questions.text: Several times per day, a youngster has brief moments of vacant staring. The youngster is unresponsive during the entire vacant episode, which starts out abruptly. The youngster is otherwise normal, and there is no history of aura or postictal disorientation to go along with it. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Absence seizures 

Absence seizures, also known as petit mal seizures, are a type of generalized seizure characterized by brief episodes of vacant staring and unresponsiveness. These episodes can occur multiple times per day and typically last for a few seconds. The onset of absence seizures is abrupt, and the child may appear to be "daydreaming" during the episode.

Key features of absence seizures include:
 
  • Brief duration: Episodes typically last for a few seconds and resolve spontaneously.
  • Vacant staring: The child appears to be inattentive and unresponsive during the episode, often with a blank facial expression.
  • Abrupt onset and termination: The episodes start and end suddenly, without any warning signs or postictal confusion/disorientation.
  • No aura or postictal period: Unlike other seizure types, absence seizures are not typically preceded by an aura (warning sign) or followed by a postictal period of confusion or disorientation.

Other options: 
 
  • Grand mal seizures (Option 1) are generalized tonic-clonic seizures characterized by loss of consciousness, muscle rigidity, and convulsions.
  • Complex partial seizures (Option 3) involve impaired consciousness with repetitive movements and may have associated aura or postictal confusion.
  • Daydreaming (Option 4) is a normal state of mind characterized by being lost in thoughts but does not involve altered consciousness or staring episodes.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3306, 3307.

questions.text: A teacher demonstrated how to wash your hands. Students studied at home and practised. What domain of learning does it fit under?
questions.solution:
Hand hygiene is a psychomotor skill that requires thinking and making motor movements to achieve a task.

Cognitive- deals with learning skills
Affective- deals with emotions


Reference: https://www.britannica.com/science/psychomotor-learning

questions.text: A youngster was seen with 5,000 CPK value, positive Gower's sign, calf hypertrophy, and lower limb weakness. The following diagnosis is most likely:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Duchenne muscular dystrophy 
 
  • Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is an X-linked recessive disorder characterized by progressive muscle weakness and wasting.
  • It primarily affects boys and typically presents in early childhood.
  • The clinical features described in the question, including elevated CPK levels, positive Gower's sign, calf hypertrophy, and lower limb weakness, are classic findings seen in DMD.

Other options:
 
  • Spinal muscular atrophy (Option 2) is a different neuromuscular disorder characterized by progressive degeneration of the spinal motor neurons, resulting in muscle weakness.
  • Myotonia congenita (Option 3) is a genetic disorder that leads to muscle stiffness and delayed relaxation after contraction.
  • Myotonic dystrophy (Option 4) is a multisystem disorder characterized by myotonia, muscle wasting, and involvement of various organs.







Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3519-3521.

questions.text: A RTA patient who can't speak arrives in an emergency. While being examined, the patient was wailing and unable to talk, yet he could understand what he wanted to say. Which of the marked brain regions following is relevant here?
questions.solution:
The signs of Broca's Aphasia are present in this patient, involving impaired fluency, word-finding pauses, abnormal word order and deployment of bound morphemes, telegraphic speech, reduced output and impaired naming and repetition. Area B' is associated with Broca's area, which is related to speech production difficulties. 

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 286

JUVENILE MYOCLONIC EPILEPSY (JME):

questions.text: A patient is suffering from hand and arm pain. She feels discomfort from the cascading water on her fingers even while cleaning dishes. On MRI, a lacunar infarct is discovered. Which of the aforementioned structures is most likely to experience an infarction?
questions.solution:
According to the history provided and the MRI results, thalamic pain syndrome is most likely to be responsible (a.k.a Dejerine–Roussy syndrome). is a condition brought on by thalamic damage from a stroke. Thalamic lesions can result from ischemic and hemorrhagic strokes.    

Clinical traits:Is frequently preceded by numbness on the side being affected. Hypersensitivity can also cause burning and tingling, typically in the form of allodynia or dysaesthesia.
 
Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition page no 173

questions.text: A young youngster with a history of seizures and mental impairment arrives at the clinic. On clinical inspection, many hypopigmented macules are seen. What plausible diagnosis is there?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Tuberous sclerosis 
 
  • Tuberous Sclerosis (Bourneville disease) is a genetic disorder characterized by the growth of benign tumors in various organs, including the brain, skin, kidneys, heart, and lungs.
 
  • It is commonly associated with seizures, intellectual disability, and developmental delays.
 
  • The hypopigmented macules, known as ash-leaf spots, are a characteristic feature of Tuberous Sclerosis and can be observed on the skin.Other clinical features may include facial angiofibromas, shagreen patches, and renal angiomyolipomas.

Other options: 
 
  • Neurofibromatosis (Option 2) is characterized by the development of neurofibromas and café-au-lait macules but is not typically associated with seizures and mental impairment.
  • Sturge-Weber Syndrome (Option 3) is characterized by facial port-wine stains and may cause neurological symptoms such as seizures, but it does not commonly present with hypopigmented macules.
  • Linear Epidermal Nevus Syndrome (Option 4) is characterized by linear epidermal nevi but is not typically associated with seizures and mental impairment.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 388.

questions.text: From which area of the brain does experimental self-stimulation occur?
questions.solution:
Self-stimulation is experimentally done from medial forebrain bundle.
The points where stimulation leads to induction or increase in the level of arousal in oneself(self -stimulation) are located in a medial band of tissue extending from ventral tegmentum to the frontal cortex.


Reference: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/medial-forebrain-bundle

questions.text: Select the artery thrombosis that can lead to a patient presenting with clinical features of vertigo, nystagmus.
questions.solution:
Obstruction of the superior cerebellar artery (SCA), located more rostrally, tends to produce more ataxia, dysarthria, and nystagmus, with less frequent vertigo, headache, and vomiting occurrences.
Obstruction of SCA causes Lateral superior pontine syndrome (a.k.a syndrome of superior cerebellar artery)
Clinical features of Syndrome of SCA:

On side of lesion
  • Ataxia of limbs and gait, falling to side of lesion: Middle and superior cerebellar peduncles, superior surface of cerebellum, dentate nucleus
  • Dizziness, nausea, vomiting; horizontal nystagmus: Vestibular nucleus
  • Paresis of conjugate gaze (ipsilateral): Pontine contralateral gaze
  • Skew deviation: Uncertain
  • Miosis, ptosis, decreased sweating over face (Horner’s syndrome): Descending sympathetic fibers
  • Tremor: Localization unclear—Dentate nucleus, superior cerebellar peduncle
On side opposite lesion
  • Impaired pain and thermal sense on face, limbs, and trunk: Spinothalamic tract
  • Impaired touch, vibration, and position sense, more in leg than arm (there is a tendency to incongruity of pain and touch deficits): Medial lemniscus (lateral portion)



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3332.

questions.text: Which of the following brain regions is being stimulated in an experiment to control intractable pain?
questions.solution:
Stimulation of periaqueductal grey matter of brain is experimentally used to control intractable pain

During periaqueductal grey matter stimulation, serotonin (5-HT) is released from ascending and descending axons in subcortical nuclei in spinal trigeminal nuclei and in the spinal cord. This release of 5-HT modulates pain transmission by inhibiting incoming sensory activity.



Reference:https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/neuroscience/periaqueductal-gray

questions.text: Pick the cause when there is no h/o trauma involved in a 45 years old female with sudden onset headache and neck rigidity.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: SAH , as in the CT scan hemorrhage is seen in the fissures that is the subarachnoid space. 
  • Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is a medical emergency that occurs due to bleeding into the subarachnoid space, characterized by a sudden and severe headache, sometimes described as "the worst headache of life."
  • Neck rigidity (stiff neck) is a common symptom of SAH, as the bleeding can irritate the meninges, the protective membranes around the brain and spinal cord.
  • SAH can occur spontaneously, and in many cases, there may be no history of trauma or injury involved.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3355.

questions.solution:
Stimulation of periaqueductal grey matter of brain is experimentally used to control intractable pain
During periaqueductal grey matter stimulation, serotonin (5-HT) is released from ascending and descending axons in subcortical nuclei in spinal trigeminal nuclei and in the spinal cord. This release of 5-HT modulates pain transmission by inhibiting incoming sensory activity.

questions.text: What is U/L proptosis with B/L sixth nerve palsy?
questions.solution:
Unilateral Proptosis with bilateral abducent Nerve Palsy is seen in cavernous sinus thrombosis.
 

  • It is a condition in which the abducens nerves on both sides of the head become paralyzed, resulting in one eye remaining turned outwards.
  • This is due to compression of the cavernous sinus, a blood-filled channel located in the skull, because of a blood clot.
  • Symptoms include facial pain, double vision and drooping of one of the eyelids.
  • Treatment typically involves anticoagulation therapy to dissolve the clot. In some cases, neurosurgical intervention or radiation therapy may also be helpful.


Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 439.

questions.text: After a 3-day CT revealed an SDH, the patient with h/o RTA presented to the OPD. Fundoscopy revealed B/L papilledema. What is the likelihood of this happening?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Raised ICT
  • Papilledema is a swelling of the optic disc, caused by increased intracranial pressure (ICP), which is the pressure of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) inside the skull.
  • In the case, the patient has a history of RTA, and a CT scan has revealed an SDH. 
  • SDH is a collection of blood between the dura mater, meninges, and the arachnoid mater. This collection of blood can increase ICP, which can lead to papilledema.

Other options : 
  • Meningitis, Optic neuritis, and Glaucoma are less likely causes, as they are not directly related to the history of RTA and SDH.



Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 323-325.

questions.text: What is kinemyography used for?
questions.solution:
Kinemyography is used for monitoring of neuromuscular function.

It utilizes a bending sensor that is placed between thumb and forefinger and the core of sensor is a piezoelectric material.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man with ataxia and urine incontinence was brought to the OPD by his daughter.  He struggles with simple maths calculations and suffers from memory loss. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH) is a form of communicating hydrocephalus, characterized by an enlarged ventricular system and normal opening pressures on lumbar puncture.
  • It is associated with a classic set of symptoms including a triad of dementia, gait disturbance and urinary incontinence.
  • Idiopathic NPH may be caused by decompensated congenital hydrocephalus or impaired absorption of cerebrospinal fluid.
  • Secondary NPH is caused by intraventricular or subarachnoid hemorrhage, acute or chronic meningitis, Paget disease at the skull base or other rare conditions.
  • The most prominent symptom is gait difficulty, which is distinguished from Parkinsonian gait by a wide base, small steps and postural instability.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 175, 194.

questions.text: Contralateral loss of pain and temperature is caused by injury to:

questions.text: Seizures are being experienced by a patient. Multiple parenchymal cysts are visible on his CT head.  Which of the following statements about management are correct in this case?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the given clinical scenario is neurocysticercosis caused by larvae of T. Solium. 
 
  • The drug of choice for treatment is albendazole. However, steroids are started before initiating albendazole to reduce the incidence of inflammatory reactions to dead and dying parasitic products. 
 
  • For the treatment of patients with brain parenchymal cysticerci, most authorities favor antiparasitic drugs, including Albendazole (15 mg/kg per day for 8–28 days) and/or praziquantel (50–100 mg/kg daily in three divided doses for 15–30 days). A combination of albendazole and praziquantel (50 mg/kg per day) is more effective in patients with more than two cystic lesions.
 
  • For patients with subarachnoid cysts or giant cysticerci, antiinflammatory medications such as glucocorticoids are needed to reduce arachnoiditis and accompanying vasculitis.
 
  • In patients with diffuse cerebral edema and elevated intracranial pressure due to multiple inflamed lesions, glucocorticoids are the mainstay of therapy, and antiparasitic drugs should be avoided



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1792, 1793.

questions.text: The following is not true about features of cerebellar damage:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Contralateral sensory loss
 
  • Cerebellum modulates movement and helps in maintenance of coordination and balance
  • Cerebellar damage affects the following :-
  • Voluntary movement of extremity – develops a propensity to fall to the ipsilateral side
  • Dysarthria
  • Truncal ataxia
  • Nystagmus
  • Head tilting
  • Intention tremor
  • Tests of cerebellar damage –

questions.text: Difficulty seeing nearby things may be caused by an inability to contract which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Ciliary body
 
  • The process by which certain  structures of eye function to change the focal length of the eyes so that the image is clearly formed on the retina is called the ACCOMODATION.
  • Accommodation Reflex plays a very important role in seeing nearby objects.
  • The ocular structures involved in the process of Accommodation include the following :-
    • Ciliary muscle
    • Lens
    • Pupil
  • Ciliary Muscle  Smooth muscle that is  located in the middle of the eyes. It holds the lens with the suspensory ligaments and also adjusts the optical power or shape of the lens during accommodation.
  • Lens -  Transparent, biconvex in shape . It is bordered anteriorly (in front) by a ring it forms with the posterior side of the iris. The lens is held by the suspensory ligament  .  
  • Pupil - The pupil is located in the middle of the eyes, it is black in colour and constricts to prevent light rays that have diverged from touching the retina and causing blurred vision

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 190

questions.text: A 35-year-old man has been experiencing headaches for the past two months and had a seizure a day ago. AED was started, and the patient is stable. A head MRI reveals several calcified lesions in the parietal lobe as well as cystic lesions with scolex and perilesional edoema. Which statement concerning how this case should be handled is true
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the given clinical scenario is neurocysticercosis caused by larvae of T. Solium. 
 
  • The drug of choice for treatment is albendazole. However, steroids are started before initiating albendazole to reduce the incidence of inflammatory reactions to dead and dying parasitic products. 
 
  • For the treatment of patients with brain parenchymal cysticerci, most authorities favor antiparasitic drugs, including Albendazole (15 mg/kg per day for 8–28 days) and/or praziquantel (50–100 mg/kg daily in three divided doses for 15–30 days). A combination of albendazole and praziquantel (50 mg/kg per day) is more effective in patients with more than two cystic lesions.
 
  • For patients with subarachnoid cysts or giant cysticerci, antiinflammatory medications such as glucocorticoids are needed to reduce arachnoiditis and accompanying vasculitis.
 
  • In patients with diffuse cerebral edema and elevated intracranial pressure due to multiple inflamed lesions, glucocorticoids are the mainstay of therapy, and antiparasitic drugs should be avoided



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1792, 1793.

questions.text:
When a 25-year-old woman's hand is submerged in cold water, she experiences redness followed by digit cyanosis. Which of the following may be the cause of this symptom?
A. Sumatriptan
B. Migraine
C. Cryoglobulinemia
D. Hyperthyroidism
questions.solution:
The patient is experiencing Raynaud's syndrome.

People who suffer from migraines are more likely to develop Raynaud's phenomenon.

Triptans and beta blockers should not be taken because they cause more vasoconstriction.

Along with Raynaud's syndrome, cryoglobulinemia (cold-sensitive antibodies) is related to the condition.

The conditions responsible for this manifestation are:

  • Migraine
  • Cryoglobulin
