Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2155

questions.text: A patient inhales 500 mL of tidal volume. Before inspiration, the intrapleural pressure was 4 cm of water, and after inspiration, it was 9 cm of water. Calculate the patient's pulmonary compliance?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: 0.1 L/cm


 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 617

questions.text: Which of the following does not usually cause a reduction in the diffusion lung capacity of carbon monoxide?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Asthma
 
  • During an episode of acute asthma, luminal narrowing due to smooth muscle constriction, inflammation, and thickening within the small- and medium-sized bronchi raise frictional resistance and reduce airflow. "Scooping" of the flow-volume loop is caused by a reduction of airflow, especially at lower lung volumes. 
  • DLCO decreases in diseases that i) thicken or destroy alveolar membranes (e.g. pulmonary fibrosis, emphysema); ii) curtail the pulmonary vasculature (e.g. pulmonary hypertension) or reduce alveolar capillary hemoglobin (eg. anemia). 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 684.

questions.text: Inhalers with a metering system are used to treat asthma. It is advised that you shake the MDI thoroughly before using it, exhale, bring the inhaler to your mouth, start to breathe in slowly, press the top of the inhaler once, and keep breathing in slowly until you have taken a full breath. After that, hold your breath for 10 seconds. A second MDI puff may be necessary for some patients to experience symptomatic relief. Which one of the following directions for using the MDI again is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) Wait for 1 minute between two puffs

It is recommended to wait for 15-30 seconds between 2 puffs.

Other options: -

  • MDI should be shaken well so that particles that are settled down also form uniform concentration.
  • Mouth should be rinsed to prevent oral mucocutaneous candidiasis.
  • Inhaler should be cleaned before use as it is exposed to oral mucosa.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 83.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is found to have chronic, productive cough associated with clubbing. Crackles and wheeze were heard during auscultation. Which investigation will be most helpful in confirming the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. HRCT
 
  • The above clinical scenario is suggestive of Bronchiectasis.
  • HRCT (High-Resolution Computed Tomography): HRCT is the gold standard for diagnosing bronchiectasis, which is a likely cause of chronic productive cough and clubbing

DIAGNOSIS: 
  • The diagnosis usually is based on presentation with a persistent chronic cough and sputum production accompanied by consistent radiographic features. Although chest radiographs lack sensitivity, the presence of “tram tracks” indicating dilated airways is consistent with bronchiectasis.
  • Chest CT is more specific for bronchiectasis and is the imaging modality of choice for confirming the diagnosis.
  • CT findings include airway dilation (detected as parallel “tram tracks” or as the “signet-ring sign”—a cross-sectional area of the airway with a diameter at least 1.5 times that of the adjacent vessel), lack of bronchial tapering (including the presence of tubular structures within 1 cm from the pleural surface), bronchial wall thickening in dilated airways, inspissated secretions (e.g., the “tree-in-bud” pattern), or cysts emanating from the bronchial wall (especially pronounced in cystic bronchiectasis).



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2174.

choices.text: Prescribe oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs and send them home
Give intravenous antibiotics and refer to a higher center

questions.text: An 18-month-old child weighing 11.5 kg arrives at the PHC with a fever and respiratory problems. The young child is lethargic/unable to feed. On examination, has a respiratory rate of 46 bpm and no chest retractions. What is the best course of action for this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Give intravenous antibiotics and refer to a higher center
  • In an 18 month old child, the respiratory rate of >40 is considered fast breathing. Additionally the child’s inability to feed and lethargy are danger signs.
  • If symptoms of pneumonia like fever and fast breathing are present along with danger signs then according to IMNCI this child is considered to have Severe pneumonia.
  • This should be managed by giving first dose of IV antibiotics and then referring to a higher centre.

IMNCI guidelines for assessment of severity of pneumonia:


Fast breathing is defined as :


Danger signs :  
  1. Lethargy
  2. inability to feed,
  3. vomiting
  4. convulsions


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 380
 Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 29

questions.text: What is an 18-year-old patient's oxygen carrying capacity with a hemoglobin of 14 g/dL?
questions.solution:
Each g/dL of Hb can carry = 1.34ml of oxygen 
14 g/dL of Hb can carry = 1.34*14 = 18.76 ml
Hence answer is option 3


Reference- Online ResourceBMJ - https://academic.oup.com/bjaed/article/4/4/123/308019

questions.text: Which of the following diseases does the given graph most likely represent?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is (Option 3) Interstitial lung disease
 
  • The compliance curve is shown by the pressure-volume loop above, and its decreased slope suggests decreased compliance.
  • Interstitial lung disease is a common example of a restrictive lung disease in which this is commonly observed. Increased compliance is a symptom of obstructive lung disease like emphysema.
   
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 688.

questions.text: Pick the injection that is available for subcutaneous administration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Terbutaline 
 
  • Amongst the given options - option (2) can be given subcutaneously. 
  • Subcutaneous injections of Terbutaline (Beta 2 adrenergic agonist) are utilized in patients who have acute asthma flare-ups and cannot cooperate with nebulized therapy with beta 2 agonists.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 243.

questions.text: A woman in her 70s had an influenza illness but resisted getting the vaccine. After contracting pneumonia, she passed away within 5 days. What  of the following organisms cause post-influenza pneumonia most frequently?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  Staphylococcus aureus
 
  • Following an influenza illness, secondary bacterial pneumonia is a common complication, and Staphylococcus aureus is one of the predominant bacteria associated with this condition. Influenza infection weakens the respiratory tract, making it more susceptible to bacterial invasion. Staphylococcus aureus is a bacterium that can cause severe pneumonia, particularly in individuals with underlying health conditions or weakened immune systems.
  • Legionella pneumophila, a bacterium responsible for Legionnaires' disease, can also cause pneumonia. However, it is not typically associated with post-influenza pneumonia.
  • Measles and cytomegalovirus (CMV) are viral infections that can lead to pneumonia but are not commonly seen as direct complications following influenza.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1011, 1519.

questions.text: A 4-year-old appeared with a fever and cough with expectoration. On the hemogram, the total leukocyte count was elevated. The chest X-ray has been presented below. What is the most likely causing organism?
questions.solution:
Fever and cough with expectoration and elevated total leukocyte count point towards Pneumonia. 

The given CXR shows pneumatoceles which are thin-walled, air-filled cysts that typically occur within the lung parenchyma when having Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia.




 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 378,379

questions.text: The lung's compliance curve is shown below: Which of the following does Curve A represent?
questions.solution:
This curve represents compliance.
 
  • The graph (A)left and up arrows denote higher compliance.
  •  Reduced compliance is shown in the graph(B) on the right and down.
  • Thus, emphysema is the cause (Increased compliance). All of the additional disorders have decreased compliance.

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 619

questions.text: Which of the following is not performed prior to ABG?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Flexion of wrist
 
  • While taking ABG, wrist is generally kept in hyperextension. This is to make the vessel straight and to fix the position (because of tension in hyperextension).
  • Flexion will make the vessel loose and the vessel will slip easily while poking.
  • Other steps are performed while doing ABG.
ABG steps:- 
  • Heparin rinse of syringe
  • Modified Allen's test performed 
  • Wrist extension 
  • Needle pierced at 45 degrees angle 
Online Reference: Castro D, Patil SM, Zubair M, et al. Arterial Blood Gas. [Updated 2024 Jan 8]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK536919/

questions.text: Which of the following is not a side effect of salbutamol?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Hypoglycemia
 
  • The use of Beta-2 agonists, such as salbutamol, can cause an increase in plasma glucose as a result of stimulating the processes of gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis.
  • This usually leads to hyperglycemia, but in large doses it can also lead to metabolic side effects including a rise in fatty acids, insulin, glucose, pyruvate, and lactate.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 242.

choices.text: Early appearance of honey combing on CT
Males are affected more commonly than female

questions.text: Pick the statement that is correct regarding non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP):
questions.solution:
• NSIP is a form of interstitial lung disease that typically has a better prognosis compared to other types, such as usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP).
  • Early appearance of honeycombing is more characteristic of UIP.
  • Males are not necessarily more commonly affected than females in NSIP, and NSIP is not specifically common in the elderly age group; it can affect a wide age range

Different types of ILD are summarised below: 





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2190, 2193, 2194.

questions.text: At 2:30 a.m., a 2-year-old child who had been coughing (cough was barking-like) for the previous two days was reported to the pediatric emergency room. On inspection, the patient's temperature was 39 °C, and the only time stridor was audible was when the patient was crying. There was no additional abnormality discovered. Which is the most appropriate management in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is option(1)
The scenario described above(barking cough with stridor) is diagnostic of laryngotracheobronchitis (LTB) or croup. Hence, Dexa­methasone will be the treatment of choice.

Other options
  • Option 2 -Racemic epinephrine can be added for symptomatic relief in moderate/severe LTB but it is not the management of choice. Drug of choice is always Dexamethasone.
  • Option 4- IV Antibiotics are indicated for Epiglottitis. LTB is a viral disease(caused by parainfluenza or influenza virus) - hence, antibiotics are not indicated. 


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 376,377

questions.text: Which of the following techniques is employed to determine anatomical dead space?
questions.solution:
Bohr's equation, which employs the single-breath nitrogen inhalation technique, is used to calculate the amount of anatomical dead space.
The functional residual capacity of the lung is measured using the Xenon/Helium dilution technique. The residual or dead space volumes cannot be determined by spirometry.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 622

questions.text: The following causes death from smoke inhalation:
questions.solution:
he correct answer is 4. All of the above.

Death from smoke inhalation can occur due to multiple mechanisms, including:

  1. Hypoxemia: Reduced oxygen availability in the blood due to the presence of smoke and toxic gases.
  2. Anemic hypoxia: Carbon monoxide in smoke can bind to hemoglobin more effectively than oxygen, reducing the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood.
  3. Ischemic hypoxia: Inflammation and damage to lung tissue can impair blood flow and oxygen delivery to tissues.

All of these factors can contribute to the lethal effects of smoke inhalation.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 699.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of Theophylline in Bronchial Asthma does not include:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Beta-2 receptor stimulation
 
  • Theophylline acts both as a bronchodilator and an anti-inflammatory -agent.
  • It is used in acute attacks of asthma.
  • Following are the Mechanisms of action of theophylline Phosphodiesterase block Adenosine receptor antagonism Apoptosis of neutrophils Deacetylase histone stimulation

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 245.

questions.text: Choose the pulmonary symptom that is NOT correctly matched with the corresponding non-pulmonary association:
questions.solution:
1. Cyanosis-Anxiety is the wrong match
 
  • Cyanosis is seen in hypoxemic respiratory disorders that result in >5 g of deoxygenated hemoglobin/dL. It is NOT seen in Anxiety or Panic attacks.
 
  • Option 2: Wheezing and rhonchi can occur in CHF with congestion of the bronchial mucosa and sometimes lead to a misdiagnosis (and inappropriate treatment) of asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
 
  • Option 3: Tachypnea occurs in metabolic acidosis as a compensatory mechanism to promote CO2 washout.
 
  • Option 4: Chest pain is the most common symptom of Acute pericarditis. The pain of acute pericarditis is often severe, retrosternal and/or left precordial, and referred to the neck, arms, or left shoulder.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1937, 2019, 2132, 3115.

choices.text: 5-kg male baby delivered at term experiences respiratory difficulty shortly after birth and needs artificial ventilation.

questions.text:
After a straightforward pregnancy and delivery, a 3.5-kg male baby delivered at term experiences respiratory difficulty shortly after birth and needs artificial ventilation.
The lung fields on the chest radiograph appear like diffuse ground glass, despite the normal cardiothymic silhouette. Replacement of the surfactant does not
enhance gas exchange. The hypoxemia gets worse throughout the first week of life. Both echocardiographic findings and routing culture results are negative.
A female sibling who had respiratory trouble passed away at the age of one month. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history suggestive of no response to surfactant therapy and a family history of sibling death points towards a diagnosis of pulmonary alveolar proteinosis.
  • Pulmonary Alveolar Proteinosis (PAP) is characterized by pulmonary surfactant building up intra-alveolarly.
  • A granular, eosinophilic substance that is diastase-resistant and stains positively with periodic acid-Schiff reagent occupying the distal air spaces is seen on histopathologic examination.


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2304

choices.text: Volume at the end of forceful expiration
Volume at the end of forceful inspiration
Volume remaining after Functional Residual Capacity is measured

questions.text: What is the Critical Closing volume?
questions.solution:
The closing capacity (CC) is the volume in the lungs at which its smallest airways, the respiratory bronchioles, collapse. It is defined mathematically as the sum of the closing volume and the residual volume. Option A- Volume at the end of forceful expiration is residual volume. Option B- Volume at the end of forceful inspiration is total lung capacity. Adult critical closing volume is close to residual volume. "Critical closing volume is the minimum volume and pressure of gas necessary to prevent small airway collapse. It is somewhat near to residual volume. Under pathological conditions when critical closing volume exceeds functional residual capacity, alveolar collapse occurs."

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 564

questions.text:
A patient who was depressed and had a history of the rapid onset of dyspnea arrived. An X-ray of the chest reveals bilateral diffuse infiltrates, with the right middle
and lower lobes being more heavily affected. Despite treatment, he was not able to be saved, and an autopsy revealed that his lungs looked grossly normal.
The following was revealed through histopathology: What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Vegetative matter aspiration pneumonia
 
  • The given histological slides depict a granuloma with multinucleated giant cells reacting to acellular debris that could be foreign matter that has been inhaled, similar to what is seen in vegetative matter aspiration pneumonia.
  • Depressed patient, history of rapid start of dyspnea, and chest X-ray revealing bilateral diffuse infiltrates with predominance of involvement of the middle and lower lobes suggest the diagnosis of aspiration pneumonia.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 711.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of Theophylline in bronchial asthma in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Phosphodiesterase Inhibition
 
  • Theophylline acts both as a bronchodilator and an anti-inflammatory agent.
  • Following are the Mechanisms of action of theophylline Phosphodiesterase block Adenosine receptor antagonism Apoptosis of neutrophils Deacetylase histone stimulation.
  • Theophylline causes PDE-3 and PDE-4 inhibition.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 245.

choices.text: Diagnosis can be made on the basis of history
CT scan is the investigation of choice
It is a type I hypersensitivity reaction

questions.text: A man who has a history of exposure to pigeon excrement is experiencing bilateral crepitations in the base of the lungs as well as symptoms of pneumonitis. Which statement about this condition is accurate?
questions.solution:
The given case fits the description of Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis. 
Amongst the given options - option (2) is best answer. 

Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis 
 
It is a chronic lung inflammatory illness that affects the alveolar walls and terminal airways in a susceptible host and is brought on by repeated inhalation of a range of organic substances.

Common types and causative agents are: 
1. Farmer's lungs.  --   Moldy hay --- Thermophilic actinomycetes(Putative antigen)
2. Bird Fancier's lungs -- Various birds --- Protein in avian feces (Putative antigen)
3. Cheese Workers' lungs -- Moldy cheese --- Penicillium

Surprisingly, cigarette smoking has been known to decrease its incidence. 

Pathogenesis:
Its both an immune complex­ mediated reaction (Type III) and cell-mediated hypersensitivity (Type IV) reaction.

Clinical Presentation:
It can manifest as acute, subacute, or chronic disease.
  • Acute:  Symptoms including coughing, fever, chills, and dyspnea may appear 6 to 8 hours after antigen exposure. If there is no further exposure to the antigen, the symptoms often go away in a few days.
  • Subacute: The subacute type frequently develops slowly over a few weeks and is characterized by coughing and dyspnea. If left untreated, it can proceed to cyanosis and severe dyspnea, which necessitates hospitalization.
  • Chronic: In its later stages, the chronic type of HP may be clinically indistinguishable from pulmonary fibrosis. Cough, weight loss, lethargy, and a progressive increase in dyspnea are among the symptoms. Physical examination may demonstrate digital clubbing and inspiratory crackles.

Diagnosis:
  • A combination of CT findings, history of exposure, BAL lymphocytosis and histopathology is used to know the likelihood of HSP (Hence, option 1 is incorrect - diagnosis is not based only on clinical history) 
  • CT in particular HRCT Chest is considered the investigation of choice. (option 2)

CT findings:
  • Acute HP appears with diffuse "ground-glass" infiltrates a reticulonodular pattern, or confluent alveolar opacification.
  • In subacute disease, centrilobular nodules and "ground-glass" changes predominate.
  • In chronic HP, changes include emphysema and interstitial fibrosis; honeycombing and subpleural linear opacities are common.


X ray findings:
They are not characteristic and can occur in other diseases as well. (hence, option 3 is incorrect).
They include-
1. B/L lungs have numerous tiny, poorly defined opacities (5 mm), sometimes sparing the apices and bases.
2. Ground-glass opacities, which can be patchy or diffuse.
3. Pattern of fine reticulation.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2160, 2161.

questions.text: A 6-month-old baby who has had a cough and cold for the past three days presents to the OPD. The rate of respiration is 48/min. The patient has wheezing but no chest indrawing when examined. Which of the statements below is false?
questions.solution:
Due to the absence of fast breathing for the age and any other serious symptoms, the child can be said to not have pneumonia. Hence, option (1) is a false statement. 

Criteria for fast breathing -
  • 0-2 months   >60 bpm
  • 2 months-1year  >50 bpm
  • 1- 5 yrs   >40 bpm

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 380

questions.text: When pO2 is 100 mm Hg, curve A in the following graph depicts the typical relation between alveolar ventilation and pCO2. In which direction would the original curve shift if the pH is altered from 7.4 to 7.3?
questions.solution:
Curves shift to the left on lower pH and to the right on Higher pH

questions.text: 85-year-old man was involved in a car accident and visited the hospital. He sustained multiple lower-limb fractures, rib fractures, and lung contusions. He eventually passed away from his wounds. An autopsy lung biopsy revealed the following characteristics. What is the most probable reason for his demise?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Fat embolism

  • Fat embolism is the most probable reason for his demise.
  • The patient has a history of a traffic accident with a lower limb fracture, which results in fat embolism since lengthy bone fractures cause microscopic fat globules to leak.
  • The small pulmonary artery branch in this region of the lung has distinct, circular holes (fat globules) that are typical of a fat embolism.



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 131.

questions.text: Which of the following claims regarding lung cancer is accurate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Oat cell variant is typically associated with hilar adenopathy

+LUNG CANCER :- It is the leading cause of death
+CLINICAL FEATURES :- Cough Hemoptysis
+INVESTIGATIONS :- CXR – Coin lesion CT – Non calcified nodule
+SITE OF METASTASES :- Liver Adrenals Bone Brain In the lungs metastases are more common than primary neoplasm
+COMPLICATIONS :- [ MNEMONIC – SPHERE ] Superior Vena Cava Syndrome Pancoast tumour Horner syndrome Endocrine paraneoplastic syndromes Recurrent Laryngeal nerve compression Effusions

questions.text: How is a tension pneumothorax immediately managed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Insert needle in 2nd intercostal space
 
  • In the case of a tension pneumothorax, the immediate management involves the insertion of a needle or catheter into the affected side of the chest to relieve the pressure buildup.
  • This procedure, known as needle decompression or needle thoracostomy, is typically performed in the 2nd intercostal space along the midclavicular line. It is done to rapidly release the trapped air and relieve the tension within the pleural space.
  • Once the initial needle decompression is performed, it is typically followed by the placement of a chest tube (tube thoracostomy) in the 5th intercostal space to allow for continued drainage and re-expansion of the lung.



NOTE- Previously, needle insertion was done @2nd ICS but nowadays, maximum literature recommend Needle thoracostomy @ 5th ICS in mid-axillary line through triangle of safety. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2200.
Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 374.

questions.text: A six-month-old baby has been complaining of a cough and a cold for the past three days. The rate of respiration is 48/min. The patient is having low grade fever, with no chest indrawing but wheezing. Which of the following is not correct?
questions.solution:
A 6 month old baby has been coughing and cold for the last three days. Respiratory rate is 48/min.
Patient is having low grade fever, there are no chest retractions but wheezing is present. This child is not suffering from pneumonia, as respiratory rate is <50/ minute and there is no chest indrawing/no high grade fever or any feature suggestive of severe pneumonia. 

In children under 2 months old, children between 2 months and 1 year old, and children between 1 and 5 years old, a high respiratory rate/fast breathing pneumonia is defined as >60 breaths per minute, >50 breaths per minute, or >40 breaths per minute respectively. 

As per IMNCI - for no pneumonia - only symptomatic management is required (salbutamol if wheezing/PCM for fever) - there is no need for antibiotics.
 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 377-380

questions.text: All of the following decreases in carbon monoxide's ability to diffuse except?
questions.solution:
The diffusion capacity of CO depends upon the alveolar surface area and thickness of the alveolar membrane.

Any factor which leads to decrease in the surface area will lead to decrease in the diffusion capacity.

  • Interstitial Lung Disease
  • Emphysema

Since, in case of polycythemia, more blood cells are available for CO uptake, its diffusion capacity increases.


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 623,624

questions.text: What is the cause of ARDS?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer Is Option (4) Damage to Endothelial cells > Option(2) - Answer confirmed by consulting with SRs/Assistant Professor at AIIMS, Delhi. 

ARDS is a progressive condition that includes three stages:
1. Exudative
2. Proliferative
3. Fibrotic.

The exudative stage involves injury to the alveolar-capillary endothelial cells and type II pneumocytes(endothelial-epithelial barrier damage) While the initial insult damages both endothelial cells and type II pneumocytes - the primary inciting event is the damage to endothelial cells which results in the secretion of multiple inflammatory cytokines(TNF-alpha/IL-1/IL-8) that cause Neutrophil activation and migration - causing further endothelial-epithelial damage - causes fluid accumulation leading to non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema which is characteristic of ARDS. 

The endothelial injury also leads to microthrombi and results in ischemic injury too.

The proliferative stage involves the proliferation of type II pneumocytes and the synthesis of new pulmonary surfactant. (Hence, option 1 is incorrect - there is proliferation of type 2 pneumocytes)

In the fibrotic phase, the alveolar edema and inflammatory exudates are converted to extensive alveolar duct and interstitial fibrosis, necessitating long-term support with mechanical ventilation and/or supplemental oxygen.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 676.

questions.text: Pick from the option the  antimicrobial which shouldn't be given to a c/c asthmatic patient being managed on theophylline therapy.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Erythromycin

  • Erythromycin and theophylline should not be given together because they can cause serious drug interactions.
  • Erythromycin is a strong inhibitor of cytochrome P450-3A4 enzyme, which is responsible for the metabolism of theophylline.
  • When taken together, erythromycin will inhibit the action of cytochrome P450-3A4 and cause an elevation of theophylline levels in the blood, leading to the risk of theophylline toxicity.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 246.

questions.text: A 5 kilogramme, 65 cm-long baby who is 10 months old has a cough and cold. He was discovered to have a respiratory rate of 48 breaths per minute with no cyanosis, retraction, or grunting. There is no previous history of seizures. Which statement regarding this child is accurate?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: No pneumonia, only cough and cold
 
  • As the child is between 2 and 12 months, the cut-off for tachypnea- which in turn directly means Pneumonia, is 50/min.
  • In this case, the child is not tachypneic and cannot be said to be having Pneumonia.
  • The child also doesn't have any danger signs.



Classification of Fast breathing/ Tachypnea:
  • <2 months: >60 breaths/min
  • 2-11 months: > 50 breaths/min
  • 12-59 months: > 40 breaths/min


Reference: Essential Pediatrics by OP Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 380.

choices.text: Nasal washings for Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) and influenza

questions.text: A 2-year-old child was brought to the emergency department at 3 AM. The child presented with a fever and cough. On examination, respiratory rate was 36/min, temperature was 39°C, and saturation on pulse oximetry was 96%. The child has a barking cough and stridor only on crying. Otherwise, the child was hydrated, able to drink and consolable. The next step in management would be:
questions.solution:
• The above clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of mild croup as the patient has stridor only on crying with normal sPO2.
  • . A single dose of dexamethasone (oral or intramuscular) is typically the first-line treatment for mild croup, even if the symptoms are not severe. It helps reduce airway swelling and improve symptoms.
  •   Single dose of dexamethasone- 015-0.6 mg/kg.


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 376,377

questions.text: Which of the following can be increased and result in a leftward shift in the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve?
questions.solution:
Physiological factors have an effect on the oxygen haemoglobin dissociation curve, resulting in a shift either to the left or the right. A leftward shift implies that a decrease in temperature, fall in blood PCO2, decrease in 2,3-DPG and rise in pH, would increase the affinity of haemoglobin to oxygen, i.e. less oxygen is released in the tissues. On the other hand, a rightward shift implies that an increase in temperature, rise in PCO2, decrease in 2,3-DPG and a fall in pH, would decrease the affinity of haemoglobin to oxygen, i.e. more oxygen would be released in the tissues. The alkalosis causes increae in H+ ions resulting in loading of oxygen and unloading of CO2 which leads to left shift of the curve.


 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 631

questions.text: The largest difference in alveolar-arterial oxygen is observed in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) Pulmonary embolism

  • In Pulmonary embolism gradient increases to very high level.
  • The Alveolar-arterial gradient is a measure of the difference between the alveolar concentration and the arterial concentration of oxygen.
  • It helps to assess the integrity of alveolar capillary unit. In states of ventilation-perfusion mismatch, such as pulmonary embolism or right-to-left shunt, oxygen is not effectively transferred from the alveoli to the blood which results in elevated gradient.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 701.

questions.text: What causes ipratropium's paradoxical bronchoconstriction mechanism
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Benzalkonium chloride
 
  • Ipratropium bromide's paradoxical bronchoconstriction, especially when administered via nebulizer, was primarily attributed to the hypotonic nebulizer solution and antibacterial additions such benzalkonium chloride and EDTA.
  • Benzalkonium chloride is irritant and causes inflammation in airways, thereby causing bronchoconstriction. It can also cause bronchoconstriction by allergic reaction. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 128.

questions.text: A newborn with a displaced mediastinum to the right and an enlarged left upper lung lobe is experiencing respiratory difficulties. Which diagnosis is more likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Congenital lobar emphysema
  • Congenital lobar emphysema is a rare congenital condition characterized by overinflation and hyperexpansion of one or more lobes of the lung.
  • It is typically caused by the narrowing or obstruction of the bronchus leading to the affected lobe, resulting in air trapping and overinflation of the lung segment or lobe. This can lead to displacement of the mediastinum towards the opposite side and compression of the unaffected lung.
  • The scenario mentions a displaced mediastinum to the right and an enlarged left upper lung lobe. This finding is consistent with the clinical presentation of congenital lobar emphysema. The respiratory difficulties experienced by the newborn can be attributed to the compression of the unaffected lung and the associated ventilation-perfusion mismatch.
  • While the other conditions listed in the options (Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, pneumonia, and cystic fibrosis) can also present with respiratory difficulties, the specific features described in the scenario, such as the displaced mediastinum and enlarged left upper lung lobe, are more characteristic of congenital lobar emphysema.






Reference: Demir, Omer Faruk et al. “Congenital lobar emphysema: diagnosis and treatment options.” International journal of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease vol. 14 921-928. 1 May. 2019, doi:10.2147/COPD.S170581. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6507121/

questions.text: A 4-year-old with pneumonia is admitted to the ICU and intubated for the same. Later, he experiences a sudden unexpected respiratory difficulty. The next chest X-ray done is displayed. What is your next step?
questions.solution:
• In the above chest X-Ray , we can see hyperinflated left lung with increased cardiac shadow and bilateral diffuse haziness.
  • In a patient of pneumonia on mechanical ventilation with the above clinical picture, it is indicative of the child developing Acute Respiratory Distress syndrome as a result of volutrauma.
  • Hence, decreasing mechanical ventilator settings is the management of choice.


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 377-380,393

questions.text: Where is the respiratory rhythm generation center located?
questions.solution:
Prebotzinger complex. It acts as the pacemaker of respiration. 

A specialized area, called the pre-Botzinger complex (PBC), is located in the rostral part of the VRG( Ventral respiratory group) and appears to be the centre of respiratory rhythm generation.


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 646

questions.text: A patient presented with a 4 months’ history of cough with diarrheal episodes. Bronchoscopy revealed an intrabronchial polyp. Biopsy from the polyp showed atypical cells with microscopic necrosis and 5 mitotic figures per 10 high-power fields as shown below. Chromogranin staining was positive. What is the diagnosis and grade of the lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 2) Atypical carcinoid grade 2

  • The patient has carcinoid syndrome, according to this clinical situation.
  • Chromogranin positivity supports the tumor's neuroendocrine origin. The difference between typical and atypical carcinoids is that typical carcinoids have less than two mitoses per ten high-power fields and do not exhibit necrosis, whereas atypical carcinoids have between two and ten mitoses per ten high-power fields and/or necrotic foci.
  • These have been categorized as grade 2 carcinoids.
  • As a result, the patient has a Grade 2 Atypical Carcinoid. Atypical carcinoids also show increased pleomorphism, have more prominent nucleoli, and are more likely to grow in a disorganized fashion and invade lymphatics.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 723.

questions.text: What is the most common drawback of the given device?
questions.solution:
Correct Anwer is (Option 1) Drug deposited in the oropharynx
 
  • The given device is pMDI (Pressurised metered dose inhaler).
  • Most common drawback of pMDI is drug deposition in oropharynx.
  • Gas used is HFA (Hydroxyfluoro-alkaline gas which propels the drug out.
  • Another disadvantage is difficulty in coordinating press with inspiration.
  • Hence, cannot be used in small children without use of spacer. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 9.

questions.text: Chronic sinusitis, nasopharyngeal ulcers, cavitary lung nodules, and renal failure are all present in a 65-year-old male adult patient. What should the next diagnostic step be?
questions.solution:
This is a classical description of Granulomatosis with Polyangitis a.k.a Wegener's Granulomatosis.
  • cANCA levels are required for diagnosis.
 
  • GPA is characterized by glomerulonephritis and granulomatous vasculitis of the upper and lower respiratory tracts.
 
  • Additionally, disseminated vasculitis in varying degrees that affects both small arteries and veins may manifest.
ANCA Memorizing trick:- 
PCM- p-ANCA- Churg's Strauss, Microscopic polyangitis 
c-ANCA- Wegener's 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2806, 2807.

choices.text: Respiratory failure not fully explained by fluid overload

questions.text: Which of the following is a part of the criteria for diagnosis of ARDS in children?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: All of the above

Berlin's criteria is used to make the diagnosis of ARDS in children




 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 587

questions.text: Chest wall and lung recoil are balanced in a relaxed condition at:
questions.solution:
FRC( functional residual capacity)

Elastic recoil is defined as the ability of a stretched or inflated Lung to return to its resting volume (FRC).

Elastic recoil of the lung is directly related to lung stiffness, that is, the stiffer the lung, the greater the elastic recoil (but lower compliance).

The lung volume at which elastic recoil of lung and elastic recoil of chest wall are at equilibrium (i.e. equal elastic recoil force but in opposite directions) is represented by FRC.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 617,619

questions.text: What does indoor air pollution not result in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Impaired neurological development

Indoor air pollution does not lead to Impaired neurological development.

* Indoor air pollution

  • Chronic lung disease (1.7x increased risk as compared to unexposed) 
  • Adverse pregnancy outcome
  • Pneumonia in children (2x increased risk as compared to unexposed).
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 410.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with asthma arrives in respiratory distress at the emergency room. Epinephrine is administered by the attending physician to cause bronchodilation. Epinephrine will alleviate the symptoms since it activates B-adrenergic receptors. Which enzyme is responsible for its action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Adenylate cyclase

Beta adrenergic receptors are associated with stimulatory G protein of adenylyl cyclase.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 144.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient was seen with a history of back discomfort, which was worse in the morning and was helped by taking a warm bath. What is the most likely next finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The clinical scenario in the above question with morning stiffness is character­istic of spondyloarthropathy, like AS.
  • The initial symptom is pain that can be either sharp or dull, insidious in onset, felt deep in the lower lumbar or gluteal region, and accompanied by low-back morning stiffness of up to a few hours’ duration that improves with activity and returns following inactivity.
 
  • Such patients also commonly have  decreased chest wall expansion. 
  • Chest expansion is measured as the difference between maximal inspiration and maximal forced expiration at the levels of either the fourth intercostal space or the xiphisternum, with the patient’s hands resting on or just behind the head. Normal chest expansion is ≥2.5 cm. The value is less than 2.5 cm in SpA.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2793.

choices.text: not an emergency, give oral antibiotics and follow up
refer urgently to a tertiary care center
give antibiotics and refer to a tertiary care center

questions.text: A 3-year-old with fever arrives at PHC. His breathing was shallow, the child lethargic and his breathing rate was 48 breaths per minute with chest indrawing. Which of the following is the next management step
questions.solution:

questions.text: Pick the option that is correct regarding tracheobronchial luminal neuroendocrine cells.
questions.solution:
Neuroendocrine cells also known as APUD cells (Amine Precursor Uptake and Decarboxylase), can be found in the lungs and GIT (Gastrointestinal Tract). These cells contain serotonin, synthesize amines as well as polypeptides, and have been known to cause carcinoid tumors.

questions.text: In a 70 years old man who was working in asbestos factory for 10-15 years. On routine X-ray, a mass was seen in right apical region of the lung. Biopsy was taken from the mass. Which of the following is seen on electron microscopic examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Numerous long slender microvilli
 
  • Most likely diagnosis on the basis of description is malignant mesothelioma.
  • Numerous long, slender microvilli will be seen on electron microscopy in malignant mesothelioma.
  • Contrast this with short stubby microvilli seen in Adeno carcinoma. Mesotheliomas are the most specific neoplasms associated with asbestosis. They can develop 1-2 years after exposure, but the incidence is highest 20-35 years after exposure.
  • Displays a strong male preference (3:1) The presence of long microvilli and abundant tonofilaments on electron microscopy, but absent microvillous rootlets and lamellar bodies, favors the diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 726.

questions.text:
A more recent monoclonal antibody used to treat rheumatoid arthritis is tocilizumab.
It is effective against:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) IL-6
 
  • A new monoclonal antibody called tocilizumab blocks interleukin-6 (IL-6) from binding to its receptor in a competitive manner (IL-6R).
  • To stop IL-6 signal transduction to inflammatory mediators that call for B and T cells, the complete receptor complex must be inhibited. A nonlinear pharmacokinetic profile characterises tocilizumab.
  • Those with RA who do not react to methotrexate or other disease-modifying antirheumatic medications may find it helpful.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 782.

questions.text: What causes infertility in Kartagener's syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Sperm motility is said to be lost or reduced in asthenozoospermia.
  • As a primary ciliary condition, Kartagener's syndrome causes aberrant or decreased motility in sperms (Asthenozoospermia).
  • Asthenozoospermia is the cause of infertility in people with Kartagener's syndrome.



Reference: Mishra, Mayank et al. “Kartagener's syndrome: A case series.” Lung India : official organ of Indian Chest Society vol. 29,4 (2012): 366-9. doi:10.4103/0970-2113.102831.URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3519024/

questions.text: Following an accident, a motorcyclist experiences elevated arterial pCO2. on ABG. Possible reasons include:
questions.solution:
Elevated arterial pCO2 points towards Respiratory acidosis.

In this case of RTA(road traffic accident)-Respiratory acidosis can be caused by depression of the respiratory center due to injury and the same accident would be causing damage to the respiratory apparatus(that is lungs/ribs/chest wall) which also would be contributing to respiratory acidosis and high arterial pCO2.


Hence, option (3) is correct.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man who smoked 5 packs a day for 11 years has been diagnosed with lung cancer. The tumor was shown to have tiny, highly mitotic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei through histologic analysis. Which of the following clinical manifestations could the patient experience while they are ill?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Thin limbs and obese trunks
 
  • The biopsy of the patient, who is a 60-year-old male with a history of 55 pack years and presented with chronic cough, revealed small hyperchromatic nuclei and highly mitotic cells–findings which are suggestive of Small Cell Lung Cancer (SCLC).
  • Small cell carcinoma is comprised of relatively small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin (salt and pepper pattern), and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli (see Fig. 15.43C). The cells are round, oval, or spindle shaped, and nuclear molding is prominent.
  • Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with small cell cancer lungs- SIADH, Cushing's syndrome(given in the question), Lambert-Eaton syndrome, anemia, etc. 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 721.

questions.text: Which enzyme does aminophylline inhibit?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Phosphodiesterase
 
  • Aminophylline group of drugs does Inhibition of phosphodiesterase (PDE) which degrades cyclic nucleotides intracellularly.
  • Consequently, the concentration of cyclic nucleotides is increased. Bronchodilatation, cardiac stimulation and vasodilatation occur and mediator release is inhibited when cAMP level rises in the bronchial/cardiac/vascular smooth muscle and in inflammatory cells, respectively.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 245.

questions.text: The most vital factor in the "Pneumonia Severity Scale" is:
questions.solution:
• Age is one of the most important factors in assessing the risk of fatality among adults from the Pneumonia Severity Index (PSI). It is well established that the older a patient is, the higher the risk of fatality.
 
  • Other important factors assessed by the PSI include the presence of other medical conditions, laboratory findings, and the patient’s vital signs.
 
  • However, age is the most reliable predictor of the potential severity of a pneumonia case, and is therefore the most important factor when assessing risk.

Pneumonia Severity Index (PSI):




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1012.

questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Given oral antibiotics and follow up

Here the respiratory rate of a 2 year old child is >40 which is classified as fast breathing.
  • Fast breathing without fever or chest indrawing is classified as non-severe pneumonia and should be treated with oral antibiotics with follow up after 2 days.

IMNCI guidelines for assessment of severity of pneumonia:



Fast breathing is defined as



Danger signs :  
  1. Lethargy
  2. inability to feed,
  3. vomiting
  4. convulsions

questions.text:
The value of Va / Q becomes zero when
1. Partial pressure of O2 becomes zero
2. No exchange of O2 & CO2 is taking place
3. Partial pressure of CO2 alone becomes zero
4. Partial pressure of both CO2 and O2 is normal
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: No exchange of O2 & CO2 is taking place V/Q = 0 is seen in airway obstruction V/Q = ∞ is seen in blood flow obstruction The ratio of pulmonary ventilation to pulmonary blood flow for the whole lung at rest is about 0.8. If the ventilation to an alveolus is reduced relative to its perfusion, the PO2 in the alveolus falls because less O2 is delivered to it and the PCO2 rises because less CO2 is expired. Conversely, if perfusion is reduced relative to ventilation, the PCO2 falls because less CO2 is delivered and the PO2 rises because less O2 enters the blood.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 639

questions.text: A middle-aged immunocompromised man arrived with a fever and shortness of breath. A middle lobe lesion with infiltration was seen on HRCT. The image displays a lung biopsy taken from the lesion. The following is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) CMV pneumonia 
 
  • This diagnosis was suggested due to a middle-aged immunocompromised male presenting with a history of fever and breathlessness, and HRCT showing a middle lobe lesion with infiltration.
  • Analysis of the lung biopsy image revealed many cells with intranuclear inclusions, suggesting CMV pneumonia as the likely diagnosis.
  • In immunosuppressed individuals, such as transplant recipients and HIV-infected individuals, CMV infection can lead to severe, life-threatening problems, particularly of the lungs and gastrointestinal tract.
  • Pneumonia caused by CMV is characterized by an interstitial mononuclear infiltrate with foci of necrosis along with enlarged cells with intranuclear inclusions. This can result in acute respiratory distress syndrome.
  • The intestinal infection can lead to intestinal necrosis and ulceration which can cause pseudo membranes and debilitating diarrhea.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 1139.

questions.text: With which of the following receptors does theophylline interact antagonistically?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Adenosine receptors
 
  • Theophylline is a medication used as a bronchodilator to treat respiratory conditions such as asthma and COPD.
  • Theophylline, a medication used as a bronchodilator, acts as a non-selective adenosine receptor antagonist.
  • Adenosine receptors are G protein-coupled receptors that bind to the endogenous neurotransmitter adenosine.
  • By antagonizing adenosine receptors, theophylline inhibits their activity and produces various effects, including bronchodilation.

mechanism of action (MOA) of theophylline:

Action Effect
Phosphodiesterase (PDE) inhibition Increases cAMP, causing bronchodilation and reducing inflammation.
Adenosine receptor antagonism Prevents bronchoconstriction and reduces airway reactivity.
Enhances histone deacetylase activity Decreases release of inflammatory mediators.

Outcome: Promotes bronchodilation and anti-inflammatory effects, used in asthma and COPD management.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 245.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient reports postural changes along with dyspnea and a productive cough. The patient had smoked for 20 pack-years in the past. Additionally, the patient has a recent history of binge drinking. The chest X-ray is displayed below. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Clinical features with history of smoking & binge drinking (increases risk of aspiration) and chest X-ray findings showing cavitation & necrosis are suggestive of lung abscess.

Most common cause of primary lung abscess is anaerobes. So, Next step in management is Intravenous clindamycin and fluids.
 
  • Primary lung abscesses is thought to originate when chiefly anaerobic bacteria (as well as microaerophilic streptococci) in the gingival crevices are aspirated into the lung parenchyma in a susceptible host.
  • Thus, patients who develop primary lung abscesses usually carry an overwhelming burden of aspirated material or are unable to clear the bacterial load.
  • Pneumonitis develops initially (exacerbated in part by tissue damage caused by gastric acid); then, over a period of 7–14 days, the anaerobic bacteria produce parenchymal necrosis and cavitation whose extent depends on the host–pathogen interaction. Anaerobes are thought to produce more extensive tissue necrosis in polymicrobial infections in which virulence factors of the various bacteria can act synergistically to cause more significant tissue destruction.

For primary lung abscesses, the recommended regimens are:

(1) Clindamycin (600 mg IV three times daily; then, with the disappearance of fever and clinical improvement, 300 mg PO four times daily) or
(2) an IV-administered β-lactam/β- lactamase combination, followed—once the patient’s condition is stable—by orally administered amoxicillin-clavulanate. 

This therapy should be continued until imaging demonstrates that the lung abscess has cleared or regressed to a small scar. Treatment duration may range from 3–4 weeks to as long as 14 weeks



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1020-1022.

choices.text: Cotrimoxazole is the drug of choice, but the patient is allergic to sulpha drugs.
Ceftriaxone is the better IV drug compared to ampicillin
Some strains of H. influenza have developed modified penicillin-binding proteins

questions.text: Following a diagnosis of H. influenza pneumonia in a 14-month-old kid, ampicillin was originally prescribed, followed by ceftriaxone. What are the reasons for this decision
questions.solution:
• Earlier, the drug of choice in H. Influenza pneumonia used to be Ampicillin. But in recent years, there has been increasing reports of resistance to ampicillin among H. influenzae bacteria due to production of beta lactamase and alteration in the penicillin binding protein. 
  • In such cases, the most effective drug to treat such an infection is Ceftriaxone.
  • Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin, remains effective against most β-lactamase-producing and PBP-modified strains of H. influenzae and is often used when resistance is suspected or when initial empirical therapy with ampicillin fails. It offers broad-spectrum activity and has excellent central nervous system penetration. 



Reference- Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 379

questions.text: The following is a crucial lung non-respiratory function of the lungs?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1. Anion balance.

The lungs play a crucial role in maintaining acid-base balance, which is related to anion balance. Specifically, the lungs help regulate the levels of bicarbonate (HCO) and carbon dioxide (CO) in the blood. Through the process of ventilation, the lungs help remove CO, which can combine with water to form carbonic acid. This indirectly affects the balance of anions like bicarbonate.

While other balances (sodium, potassium, calcium) are primarily managed by other organs like the kidneys, the lungs have a significant impact on maintaining anion balance, especially related to the bicarbonate buffer system in the blood

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 626,641

questions.text: A worker who had spent the previous 20 years working in a manufacturing suddenly had pleural thickening and fibrosis. The graphic below depicts the lesion's histopathology. Most likely medical condition is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Asbestosis 

The diagnosis of asbestosis is suggested due to the presence of pleural thickening, fibrosis, and asbestos bodies found on the image.
  • Asbestos bodies are golden brown, fusiform or beaded rods with a translucent center which are formed when macrophages phagocytize asbestos fibers, and the iron is derived from phagocyte ferritin.
  • In addition, other inorganic particulates may become coated with similar iron-protein complexes which are known as ferruginous bodies. This diagnosis is further supported by the history of working in an asbestos factory for 20 years.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 695.

Steroids have a doubtful role in the management

questions.text: Which of these is false about Transfusion Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI)?
questions.solution:
In TRALI (Transfusion Related Acute Lung Injury), symptoms tend to resolve within 3-4 days from the onset - not 3-4 weeks as given in option 1 - hence it is a false statement.

questions.text: Identify the one which does not indicate Pediatric asthma:
questions.solution:
All are indicator of Paediatric asthma except option B- AM:PM variation > 15%

In case of Paediatric asthma the AM:PM variation is >= 20%

Features of Paediatric asthma are-
  1. Spirometry showing limitation of air flow- FEV1:FVC ratio < 0.8
  2. Bronchodilator response with improvement in FEV1 to >/= 12% and >/= 200 ml.
  3. Exercise Challenge- Worsening in FEV1 >/= 15%
  4. Daily peak flow- AM to PM variation of >/= 20%

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 382,383

questions.text: Identify the lipid with deficiency in a preterm baby having respiratory distress syndrome?
questions.solution:
Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS) in preterm babies is caused by a deficiency of surfactant, a complex mixture of phospholipids mainly dipalmitoyphosphatidyIcholine, proteins, neutral lipids and cholesterol. Cardiolipin (Culcutta antigens) is a phospholipid which is a component of the inner mitochondrial membrane and plays an important role in mitochondrial enzyme metabolism. Sphingomyelin are also phosphosphingolipids which are found in increased concentrations in nervous tissues, red blood cells and lens of the eyes. The lack of or insufficient surfactant production in the respiratory system of preterm babies is responsible for the alveolar collapse and leads to the onset of RDS.


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 620

questions.text: What condition does the picture represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Lobar Pneumonia
 
  • The image shows uniform involvement of whole lobe and therefore it is a case of lobar pneumonia.
  • Patchy consolidation of the lung is the dominant characteristic of bronchopneumonia, while consolidation of a large portion of a lobe or of an entire lobe defines lobar pneumonia.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 708.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy who was injured in a bike accident is brought to the emergency room complaining of coughing, dyspnea, and chest pain. At the time of evaluation, the patient's blood pressure was 130/80 mm Hg, his heart rate was 88 beats per minute, and his respiration rate was 22 beats per minute. On auscultation, there was less air entry and no breath sounds on one side. An oximeter reading of 98% indicates saturation. Below is an X-ray of the chest. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
In the image above, we can see Hyperlucent left lung field with collapsed lung near the left heart border.

  • Pneumothorax is suspected because the surrounding hemithorax is found to be more translucent than usual with absence of broncho-vascular markings.
  • The central, non deviated location of the trachea is another indication that there is a pneumothorax with collapse.
  • When air leaves from the lung, it collapses. The area between the lung and the chest wall that is external to the lung is then filled with air.
  • The diagnosis is made by physical examination showing an enlarged hemithorax with no breath sounds, hyperresonance to percussion, and shift of the mediastinum to the contralateral side.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2200.
Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 373, 374.

questions.text: A child presents with recurrent chest infections and recurrent sinusitis. An X-ray of the chest reveals dextrocardia and situs inversus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in a child with history of recurrent chest infections and recurrent sinusitis with dextrocardia and situs inversus on chest X-ray is Kartagener 's syndrome.
  • It is also known as Primary ciliary dyskinesia.
  • It occurs due to mutation in dynein protein of cilia. 
  • Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) comprises those respiratory disorders having in common the malfunction of airway cilia.
  • About 50% of patients with PCD have Kartagener's syndrome: Situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, otitis and airway disease leading to bronchiectasis.
 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2298,2299

questions.text: Name the cell kind, baby with respiratory distress syndrome would lack with
questions.solution:
Alveolar capillary endothelial cells are part of the capillary wall that lines the inner surface of the vasculature. These cells help to maintain hemostasis by preventing the coagulation of the blood and ensuring that all blood flows smoothly through the capillaries. Type I alveolar cells form part of the air-blood barrier, and they are involved in the process of gas exchange between the alveoli and the blood. Type 2 cells contain secretory organelles known as lamellar bodies, which are responsible for the release of pulmonary surfactant. Alveolar macrophages are a type of immune cells that are responsible for clearing the air space. They can remove any infectious, toxic, or allergic particles, as well as secreting interleukin 4 and 10 to control any risk of uncontrolled inflammation.

Thus, a lack of Type 2 alveolar cells would lead to Respiratory Distress Syndrome in a newborn baby. 

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 611

questions.text: What condition does the picture represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Miliary tuberculosis
 
  • The picture represents miliary tuberculosis, which is characterized by widespread dissemination of Mycobacterium tuberculosis throughout the body.
  • Miliary tuberculosis appears as numerous small, millet seed-like granulomas in various organs, including the lungs.
  • These granulomas consist of central caseous necrosis surrounded by epithelioid macrophages, multinucleated giant cells, and lymphocytes.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 373.

questions.text: Polysomnography contains all of the following tests except:
questions.solution:

  • However, pCO2 measurement would require an invasive ABG (causing pain) resulting in disruption of sleep and is not performed.

questions.text: A female recounts a history of escalating shortness of breath. Histology reveals a patchy heterogeneous fibrosis with a number of fibroblastic foci. The following is the likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Usual interstitial pneumonia
 
  • The described histological findings of patchy heterogeneous fibrosis with fibroblastic foci are consistent with usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP).
  • UIP is the histological pattern seen in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), a chronic progressive lung disease characterized by fibrosis and architectural distortion of the lung parenchyma.
  • In UIP, there is a combination of areas of normal lung, fibrosis with honeycomb changes, and fibroblastic foci representing sites of active fibroblast proliferation.
  • Fibroblastic foci are aggregates of activated fibroblasts associated with myofibroblasts that contribute to the ongoing fibrotic process in UIP.
Other patterns of interstitial lung disease, such as non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP) and desquamative interstitial pneumonia (DIP), have distinct histological features and clinical associations.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2190.

choices.text: Aspiration of 20-30 mL of contents with pH <2.5 is required
Fungal infection is the most common cause of pneumonia
Posterior segment of the right upper lobe is most commonly affected in the recumbent position
Aspiration is responsible for 5-15% of community acquired pneumonia

questions.text: About aspiration pneumonia, all of the following are true, barring:
questions.solution:
Aspiration pneumonia is an infectious pulmonary condition triggered by entering bacteria-rich oropharyngeal fluids into the lower respiratory tract. The aspirated fluid may contain oropharyngeal secretions, particulate matter, or gastric content.

Most common causative organisms of Aspiration Pneumonia are Oral anaerobes and gram negative enteric bacteria.
 
  • Option 1: Aspiration pneumonia is more likely to occur when pH of the aspirated fluid is less than 2.5 and the volume of aspirate is greater than 0.3 mL/kg of body weight (20-25 mL in adults).
 
  • Option 3: In supine positions, the posterior segments of the right upper lobe and the right apical segment of the lower lobe are the areas most likely affected. In the standing and sitting positions, the basal segments of the lower lobes, particularly of the right lower lobe, are usually affected.
 
  • Option 4: The incidence of aspiration pneumonia among patients with CAP ranges between 5% and 15% in the US, United Kingdom, and Korea.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1010, 1011.
Jordi Almirall et al., Aspiration pneumonia: A renewed perspective and practical approach, Respiratory Medicine, Volume 185, 2021. doi: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.rmed.2021.106485. URL: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0954611121001918

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis in a child who is presented to the emergency department with fever and mild respiratory distress. He was started on oral antibiotics and showed initial improvement, but later deteriorated again with fever, wheeze and exaggerated breathlessness. Radiographs of chest showed hyperlucency and Pulmonary Function Tests showed an obstructive pattern?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Bronchiolitis Obliterans 

The given clinical vignette describes the clinical condition called Bronchiolitis Obliterans.
  • Causative organism is Respiratory Syncytial Virus
  • Clinical features include :
  1. Fever
  2. Respiratory Distress
  3. URTI
  4. Wheeze may be present
  • XRAY  shows Bilateral Hyperinflation / Hyperlucency of lung fields
  • Treatment : Inhaled Ribavirin

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2226,2227

questions.text:
What does it mean when it VA/Q is ∞
1. Partial pressure of alveolar gas is same as dead space
2. The pO2 of alveolar air is 159 mm Hg and PCO2 is 40 mm Hg
3. Partial pressure of O2 and CO2 are equal
4. No diffusion of O2 from alveoli to blood and CO2 from blood to alveolar gas
questions.solution:
VA/Q is a ratio used to describe the proportion of ventilation (V) to perfusion (Q) of air in the lungs. When no exchange of CO2 and O2 occurs, VA/Q is at infinity because there is no air moving between the two processes. In this case, the VA/Q ratio would be infinite because there is no exchange of gasses between the alveoli and pulmonary capillaries, causing infinite ventilation for every unit of perfusion (Q).

Statement 1 is also correct since if there is no perfusion then there is no gas exchange hence the partial pressure of the alveoli will be same as that of dead space.

This is a highly controversial question but option 4 seems the better answer.
 

Reference :Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition page no 525

questions.text: Cavitary lesions in lungs can be observed in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Staphylococcal pneumonia
 
  • Cavitary lesions in the lungs can be observed in Staphylococcal pneumonia.
  • Cavitary lesions refer to hollow spaces or cavities within the lung tissue.
  • Staphylococcal pneumonia is a type of bacterial pneumonia caused by Staphylococcus aureus bacteria, which can lead to the formation of cavitary lesions in the lungs. 
  • In x-ray Soap Bubble appearance is seen. 
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 270.

choices.text: Massive hemoptysis is bleeding >400 ml in 24 hours
CT chest is the next step in management
In an unstable patient, rigid bronchoscopy is done to identify the lesion

questions.text: What statement concerning hemoptysis is false?
questions.solution:
CT chest is the first investigation done that is a false statement for massive hemoptysis.
 
  • "Massive hemoptysis may be characterized as greater than 400 ml blood loss from the lungs in 24 hours (OR) >150 ml at a time.”
  • In 90% of cases, the bronchial circulation is the cause of massive hemoptysis.
  • The following step in the examination of hemoptysis should be a conventional chest radiograph for the majority of individuals.
  • If the cause of bleeding cannot be determined on plain film, a CT of the chest should be acquired. When these examinations are unrevealing, bronchoscopy should be taken into consideration. An 8.5-mm or bigger rigid bronchoscope is required.
  • As most large-volume hemoptysis results from an airway lesion, the location of the bleeding can be determined by either a chest x-ray or bronchoscopy.
  • Next step in management should be to secure the airway followed by identification of bleeding site. 

Approach to the management of Hemoptysis: 





 Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 270, 271.

questions.text: Which condition is associated with round pneumonia?

questions.text:
What will be the volume of lung remaining, if the chest wall recoil is eliminated
1, Residual volume
2. Functional residual capacity
3. Zero
4. Minimal volume
questions.solution:
If the chest wall recoil (expanding force) does not counteract the lung's elastic recoil (collapsing force), the lung will collapse to minimal lung volume (which is lower than residual volume).

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 619,620

questions.text: A 30 years old woman with dyspnea, cough, sputum production and wheezing dies of respiratory failure following a bout of lobar pneumonia. She was a non-smoker and alcoholic. The lung autopsy is portrayed. Which of the following conditions was most likely associated with the woman's death
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2)   \(\alpha~\)-1 antitrypsin deficiency
 
  • The Gross specimen suggest emphysematous lungs, it is a chronic lung disease that results in damage to alveoli, the small air sacs in the lungs- pan acinar emphysema.
  • When damaged, alveoli lose their flexibility and cannot feed enough oxygen into the bloodstream.
  • Emphysema is typically caused by long-term exposure to cigarette smoke, as well as environmental pollutants like car exhaust. Alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) is a protein produced in the liver that helps protect the lungs from damage caused by inflammation.
  • Individuals with emphysema are often low on AAT, leaving their lungs and alveoli vulnerable to the effects of smoking, air pollutants, and other irritants. Though is can be present without active smoking also.
  • Without the protection of AAT, the lung tissue gradually becomes damaged and scarred, leading to difficulty breathing, coughing, and a decreased quality of life.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 679.

questions.text: Which drug from the list below can be administered to people with primary pulmonary hypertension?
questions.solution:
Bosentan can be given in patients of primary pulmonary hypertension.

  • Bosentan is a FDA approved non-specific antagonist of endothelin receptors (ERA) of both ET-A & ET-B. 
 
  • ERAs prevent ET-1 from attaching to either endothelin receptor A (ET-A) or receptor B(ET-B). Vasoconstriction is mediated by ET-A receptors on the smooth muscle cells of the pulmonary artery. ET-B receptors are found on endothelial cells in the normal pulmonary vasculature, and they were found to mediate vasodilation by the synthesis of prostacyclin and nitric oxide as well as the clearance of ET-I.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2129.

questions.text: What is the respiratory quotient when oxygen is utilized at 250 and carbon dioxide is liberated at 200
questions.solution:
Respiratory quotient (RQ) = Volume of CO2 produced / Volume of O2 consumed RQ = 200/250 = 0.8


Reference :Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition page no 2136

questions.text: The electron microscopic image of alveoli is given below. Which among the following marked structure is inflamed and swollen in COVID-19 ARDS?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Endothelium
 
  • The endothelium of the alveoli is inflamed and swollen in COVID-19 ARDS.
  • Histopathological findings include diffuse alveolar damage, hyaline membrane formation, and inflammatory infiltrates.
  • The endothelial cells show signs of inflammation, such as cytoplasmic swelling and vacuolation.
  • The presence of viral particles within the endothelial cells and vascular endothelial damage contribute to vascular leakage and edema.
  • These histopathological changes lead to impaired gas exchange and respiratory failure in severe cases of COVID-19 ARDS.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2270.

questions.text: A 36-year-old overweight prominent smoker was snoring and had hypertension. Five apnea/hyperpnea events occurred during each hour of the sleep test. He was prescribed anti-hypertensives and told to give up smoking. What will be in the next line of action?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of an obese, hypertensive patient with 5 AHI episodes/hour and snoring episodes is suggestive of Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA).

Management of OSA: 
 
  • A comprehensive approach to the management of OSA is needed to reduce risk factors and comorbidities. The clinician should seek to identify and address lifestyle and behavioral factors as well as comorbidities that may be exacerbating OSA. As appropriate, treatment should aim to reduce weight; optimize sleep duration (7–9 h); regulate sleep schedules (with similar bedtimes and wake times across the week).
 
  • However, CPAP is the treatment of choice. CPAP is the standard medical therapy with the highest level of evidence for efficacy. Delivered through a nasal or nasal-oral mask, CPAP works as a mechanical splint to hold the airway open, thus maintaining airway patency during sleep.
 
  • Upper airway surgery for OSA is less efficacious than CPAP and is mostly reserved for the treatment of patients who snore, have mild OSA, or cannot tolerate CPAP. Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty (removal of the uvula and the margin of the soft palate) is the most commonly performed surgery for OSA


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2208, 2209.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is represented by the area highlighted with letters A and D in the following diagram?
questions.solution:
The given illustration is a davenport diagram.

The Davenport diagram shows shifts in pH at various levels of arterial carbon dioxide tension (PaCO2)

A: Chronic respiratory acidosis:
Fall in pH
Rise in pCO2
Rise in HCO3

D: Metabolic acidosis:
Fall in pH
Fall in HCO3

questions.text: A 50-year-old industrial worker arrives at the OPD with a cough and dyspnea. Upon examination, it was discovered that he had lung fibrosis and pleural thickening. The lung biopsy resulted in the following discovery. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Asbestosis

  • The given clinical history is suggestive of Asbestosis. It is an occupational lung disease especially seen in shipping industry. Occurs because of chronic exposure to Asbestos. Patient complaints of cough, dyspnea.
  • It usually affects the lower lobes of lung and presents as —Pleural plaque (Most Common Lesion), Lung Cancer or malignant mesothelioma (Most specific finding of asbestosis, needs about 25 years of exposure). H&E demonstrates asbestos/ferruginous bodies (dumbbell shaped bodies)

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 695.

choices.text: Pneumonia affecting medial zone of right middle lobe
Pneumonia affecting superior zone of right lower lobe
Pneumonia of anterior zone of right middle lobe

questions.text: A patient presents with cough and fever. On X-ray examination, a homogenous opacity silhouetting the right heart border with ill-defined lateral margins is seen. What would be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The cardiac silhouette on the right side of the lung with an ill-defined lateral border is indicative of pneumonia affecting the medial zone of the right middle lobe.
  • Cardiac silhouettes are be beneficial in identifying the location of pulmonary abnormalities, since all parts of the cardiac silhouette, including the heart border, ascending and descending aorta, aortic knob, and hemidiaphragm, are located adjacent to a certain area of the lung.


Image showing Pneumonia of Medial part of RML



Reference: Grainger & Alison's Diagnostic Radiology,7th edition, Page no 34.
