questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Decreased Chest Expansion.
 
  • Pneumothorax is a condition where air accumulates in the pleural space, causing partial or complete collapse of the lung.
  • A characteristic sign of a pneumothorax is decreased chest expansion on the affected side due to the collapsed lung's limited ability to expand during breathing.
  • Other signs include:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2200.
Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 373, 374.

questions.text: What results in tropical pulmonary eosinophilia?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Occult filariasis.
 
  • TPE is a hypersensitivity reaction to filarial parasites, Wuchereria bancrofti and Brugia malayi, transmitted through mosquito bites causing lymphatic filariasis.
  • Symptoms : Chronic cough, wheezing, and shortness of breath, often exacerbated at night (nocturnal).
  • Peripheral eosinophilia with an absolute eosinophil count > 5000 is a typical finding in TPE.
  • Treatment involves using diethylcarbamazine (DEC) to eliminate the microfilariae.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1781.

questions.text: Patients with severe kyphoscoliosis who get abnormal results on their preoperative pulmonary function tests include:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Increased RV/TLC
 
  • Patients with severe kyphoscoliosis often have restrictive lung disease due to the impaired movement of the chest wall and decreased lung expansion.
  • Kyphoscoliosisis a ventilation defect due to Chest wall abnormality. In such cases, RV remains unchanged, whereas TLC is unchanged or slightly reduced leading to an Normal to increased RV/TLC ratio on pulmonary function tests.
  • Rest all other options are false





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2137, 2138.

questions.text: Which of the following tests will confirm the diagnosis in a patient with asthmatic clinical symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Diurnal variation in PEF > 10 Percent
 
  • Asthma is a chronic respiratory condition characterized by airway inflammation and narrowing, leading to breathing difficulties.
  • Specific finding in asthma: Diurnal variation in PEF >10%, with lower values in the morning due to increased airway inflammation.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2154, 2155.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about chronic bronchitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Predominant symptom is Dyspnea
 
  • Chronic bronchitis is a type of COPD with airway inflammation and narrowing, leading to symptoms like cough, sputum production, dyspnea, wheezing, and chest tightness.
  • The predominant symptom in chronic bronchitis is a productive cough lasting at least three months per year for two consecutive years.
  • "Blue Bloaters" (Option 2) is a term used for chronic bronchitis patients with cyanosis and peripheral edema due to low oxygen levels in the blood. Pink Puffers is referred to patients with Emphysema.
  • DLCO (diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide) is  NORMAL or reduced in chronic bronchitis due to impaired oxygen transfer. (Option 3)
  • Patients with chronic bronchitis are not typically obese (Option 4); they are more likely to experience weight loss due to their breathing difficulties and reduced appetite. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2133, 2180, 2185.

questions.text: Daytime sleepiness and an apnea-hypopnea index (AHI) greater than ________ are symptoms of Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA).
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: >5
 
  • Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is diagnosed if the patient has either symptoms of nocturnal breathing disturbances or daytime sleepiness, and ≥ 5 episodes of obstructive apnea or hypopnea per hour of sleep.
 
  • This is known as the apnea-hypopnea index, and is calculated as: number of episodes ÷ number of hours of sleep.
 
  • Each such episode should last for at least 10 seconds, resulting in ≥ 3% drop in oxygen saturation or a brain cortical arousal. OSA is diagnosed by overnight polysomnogram (PSG)


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2205.

questions.text: Which of the following is the patient's primary disorder in case of a patient was admitted to the casualty with hysteria and anxiety. Estimation of arterial plasma showed PH of 7.53; HCO3 of 18 meq and PCO2 of 27 mm Hg.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Respiratory alkalosis
 
  • pH of 7.53= Alkalosis (higher than normal range of 7.35 to 7.45).
  • HCO3 of 18 = Alkalosis (higher than normal range of 22 to 26 meq).
  • PCO2 of 27= ↓ CO2 levels in blood  (lower than normal range of 35 to 45 mm Hg).
  • These findings collectively indicate respiratory alkalosis, which is caused by a decrease in the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PCO2) due to hyperventilation.
  • The patient's hysteria and anxiety likely triggered hyperventilation, leading to respiratory alkalosis.
  • Hyperventilation leads to excessive CO2 elimination, raising the blood pH.


Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 359, 360.

questions.text: Which diagnosis is suggested by Bilateral upper lobe bronchiectasis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Cystic Fibrosis
 
  • Bilateral upper lobe bronchiectasis strongly suggests cystic fibrosis.
  • Cystic fibrosis is a genetic disorder affecting the respiratory and digestive systems.
  • The condition leads to the production of thick, sticky mucus to build up in the lungs and other organs. This can lead to infections, inflammation, and damage to the lungs.
  • Bronchiectasis is characterized by permanently widened and thickened airways, making mucus clearance difficult.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2174, 2176.
Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 472.

questions.text: What is Brock's Syndrome ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Middle Lobe Bronchiectasis
 
  • Brock's syndrome, also known as Middle Lobe Syndrome, is a condition that affects the middle lobe of the lungs (other lobes are not affected).
  • It is characterized by the presence of bronchiectasis, which is a permanent dilation of the bronchi. This can lead to recurrent infections, inflammation, and damage to the lungs.
  • Symptoms: Chronic cough, sputum production, and recurrent respiratory infections.



Reference: Kunal, Shekhar et al. “Middle lobe syndrome: an intriguing presentation of tracheobronchial amyloidosis.” BMJ case reports vol. 2017 bcr2017219480. 22 May. 2017, doi:10.1136/bcr-2017-219480. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5753675/

questions.text: What is seen with Bronchiectasis Sicca?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Tuberculosis 
 
  • Bronchiectasis Sicca is a term used to describe a specific type of bronchiectasis that presents with dry, non-productive cough without significant sputum production.
  • The term "sicca" comes from Latin, meaning dry. In this condition, the characteristic bronchial dilation and airway damage are present, but the typical symptom of excessive sputum production is not observed.
  • Kartagener syndrome is a specific type of primary ciliary dyskinesia, which can be associated with bronchiectasis but is not the same as bronchiectasis sicca.



Reference: Butler, Marcus W., and Michael P. Keane. “Bronchitis, Bronchiectasis.” Infectious Diseases(2017): 243–250.e2. doi:10.1016/B978-0-7020-6285-8.00027-7. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7150028/

choices.text: Contralateral mediastinal nodes are a contraindication to surgical resection
Single Agent Chemotherapy is preferred for patients> 70 years with advanced disease
Squamous Cell Carcinoma is the most common NSCCL amongst Asian population
Gefitinib is most effective for female smokers with adenocarcinoma on histology

questions.text: The following descriptions of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCCL) are all accurate, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Gefitinib is most effective for female smokers with adenocarcinoma on histology 
 
  • Gefitinib is an epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) tyrosine kinase inhibitor used in the treatment of NSCLC with specific EGFR mutations.
  • It has shown significant efficacy in patients with EGFR mutations, particularly in those with exon 19 deletions or exon 21 L858R mutations.
  • EGFR mutations are more common in Asian populations and in non-smokers or light smokers and have adenocarcinoma histology, but it is not limited to female smokers.
  • Gefitinib is more effective in patients with EGFR mutations, regardless of gender or smoking history.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 595, 600, 606, 607.

questions.text: A patient who was given a bronchiectasis diagnosis five years ago appears with proteinuria and edema on the legs. His kidneys will most likely reveal one of the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Amyloid Nephropathy
 
  • Amyloid nephropathy: Kidney damage and dysfunction caused by amyloid protein deposition..
  • It can present with proteinuria and edema due to impaired kidney function and fluid retention.
  • Bronchiectasis is a chronic lung condition, and in some cases, it can be associated with systemic amyloidosis, leading to amyloid deposition in various organs, including the kidneys.
Other options:
  • Minimal change disease (MCD): Glomerulonephritis with minimal glomerular changes, often in young individuals with allergies.
  • Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN): Severe form of glomerulonephritis, leads to rapid kidney failure. Associated with infections, autoimmune diseases, and medications.
  • Crescentic glomerulonephritis: Type of RPGN with crescent-shaped structures in glomeruli, causing kidney damage.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 878, 2345.

questions.text: Which hormone can you identify from the picture?
questions.solution:
Release of growth hormone is stimulated by strenuous exercise. Also during sleep, large pulsatile bursts of growth hormone secretion occur.

Factors which stimulate secretion of growth hormone:
(1) starvation, especially with severe protein deficiency;
(2) hypoglycemia or low concentration of fatty acids in the blood;
(3) exercise;
(4) excitement;
(5) trauma; and
(6) ghrelin, a hormone secreted by the stomach before meals.

 

Reference:Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition Page no 929, 945, 977

questions.text: Which of the following does not stimulate insulin secretion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Rosiglitazone

Rosiglitazone does not act by increasing insulin secretion. Rosiglitazone is an oral antihyperglycemic agent that acts primarily by decreasing insulin resistance.

* Mechanism of action:
  • Potent and highly selective agonist for peroxisome proliferator activated receptor gamma (PPARg). 
  • PPAR receptors are found in tissues important for insulin action such as adipose tissue, skeletal muscle and liver (highest level in adipose tissue).
  • Activation of (PPAR) nuclear receptors modulates the transcription of a number of insulin responsive genes involved in the control of glucose & lipid metabolism. 
  • Rosiglitazone appears to reduce insulin resistance by enhancing fatty acids storage and possibly by increasing adiponectin levels

* Other options: 
2. Repaglinide- Is a meglitinide which increases insulin release
3. Exenatide- GLP 1 analogue which increases insulin release
4. Sitagliptin- It is a DPP-4 inhibitor, it increases incretin level, which in turn increases insulin release

Anti Diabetic Drugs -
 
Class Examples Mechanism of Action
1. Insulin - Regular insulin- Long-acting (e.g., glargine)- Rapid-acting (e.g., lispro) Mimics natural insulin to control blood glucose.
2. Insulin Secretagogues DPP-4 Inhibitors: sitagliptin, saxagliptin, linagliptin
GLP-1 Agonists: exenatide, liraglutide-
Sulfonylureas: glibenclamide, glimepiride
 Meglitinides: repaglinide, nateglinide		 Stimulate insulin release from the pancreas.
3. Drugs that Reduce Insulin Resistance - Biguanides: metformin-
Thiazolidinediones (TZDs): pioglitazone, rosiglitazone		 Improve insulin sensitivity in muscle and fat.
4. SGLT-2 Inhibitors - Empagliflozin- Canagliflozin Increase glucose excretion by inhibiting renal glucose reabsorption.
5. Alpha-glucosidase Inhibitors - Acarbose- Miglitol Slow carbohydrate breakdown, reducing post-meal blood sugar spikes.
6. Amylin Analogs - Pramlintide Delay gastric emptying and reduce glucagon release.
7. Bile Acid Sequestrants - Colesevelam Improve insulin sensitivity and lower blood glucose.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 300.

questions.text: It was discovered that a 50-year-old smoker and hypertensive had non-small cell lung cancer with brain metastases. He is taking hydrochlorothiazide and enalapril to treat his hypertension. Upon examination, he had blood pressure of 150/90 mm Hg, blood sugar of 112 mg/dL, serum sodium of 120 mg/dL, urinary sodium of 110 mg/dL, serum creatinine of 0.8 mg/dL, serum osmolarity of 255 mOsm/L, urine osmolarity of 350 mOsm/L, and urinary K+ of 9 mg/dL. What of the following is most likely to be the reason for his hyponatremia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: SIADH

SIADH is a condition characterized by excessive release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH), also known as vasopressin, resulting in water retention and dilutional hyponatremia.

The key findings supporting SIADH in this case are:
  1. Serum sodium of 120 mg/dL: The low serum sodium level indicates hyponatremia.
  2. Urinary sodium of 110 mg/dL: In SIADH, the kidneys retain sodium, leading to increased urinary sodium excretion.
  3. Normal serum creatinine: Normal kidney function suggests that the hyponatremia is not due to impaired renal clearance.
  4. Euvolemic status: The absence of volume overload or depletion suggests a normal fluid balance.
  5. Normal serum osmolarity: A low serum osmolarity is expected in SIADH due to water retention without dilutional changes in other solutes.
 
  • Cerebral salt wasting (option 1) is a condition characterized by excessive renal sodium loss due to brain injury or intracranial pathology. It is typically associated with  hypovolemia, which are not consistent with the patient's presentation.
 
  • Diuretic-induced hyponatremia (option 2) is possible when diuretics, such as hydrochlorothiazide, cause excessive urinary sodium and water loss. However, the patient's urinary sodium level is not consistent with this scenario.
 
  • Pseudohyponatremia (option 4) refers to a laboratory artifact where the measured serum sodium level appears low due to abnormal levels of lipids or proteins in the blood. The patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings are not suggestive of pseudohyponatremia.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 723, 2924, 2925.

questions.text: Which of the following is FNAC unable to detect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Follicular carcinoma
 
  • FNAC (Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology) is unable to detect follicular carcinoma (Option A).
  • Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid cannot be reliably distinguished from follicular adenoma by FNAC alone because it requires histopathological examination of the tumor capsule to confirm invasion.
  • FNAC is useful in detecting other thyroid pathologies such as papillary carcinoma, colloid goiter, and Hashimoto's thyroiditis.
  • FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions as malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion. Hence, Trucut biopsy is required to confirm malignancy.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 858.

questions.text: Which of the following is the maximum steroid produced by the fetal adrenal?
questions.solution:
• The steroid produced in the maximum quantity by the fetal adrenal glands is DHEA-S.
  • The fetal adrenal gland is formed around 8-10 weeks.
  • Initially, the glands produce cortisol which acts to suppress ACTH production from the pituitary. During this phase, the gonadal development in males and females is taking place and such an action is necessary.
  • In the second trimester, cortisol production decreases and DHEA and DHEA Sulphate are produced in large quantities. The placenta uses these for the production of estrone and estradiol. 
  • In the third trimester again, cortisol production is increased but the hormone produced in maximum quantity stays DHEA-S.


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2959

questions.text: Along with insulin, which of the following is released by pancreatic beta cells?
questions.solution:
Amylin is also produced by beta cells in the pancreas and is co-secreted with insulin that is also produced in the beta cells in a pulsatile manner in response to stimuli.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 424

questions.text: What ingredients make up lente insulin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 30% Amorphous + 70% Crystalline insulin

Lente insulin is made up of 70% ultralente (crystalline) and 30%
             Semilente (amorphous)

            
* [Extra Edge]: Different types of insulin and their duration of action   
         

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 286.

questions.text: TSH is raised in a female patient and the free T4 level is below normal.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Primary hypothyroidism
 
  • Primary hypothyroidism refers to a condition in which the thyroid gland is unable to produce an adequate amount of thyroid hormones.
  • This results in elevated TSH levels as the pituitary gland releases more TSH in an attempt to stimulate the thyroid gland.
  • However, the thyroid gland fails to produce enough free T4 (thyroxine), leading to low levels of free T4 in the blood.It is not subclinical as free T4 level is below normal.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2933-2936.

questions.text:
A thyroid nodule on the right side was observed in a 27-year-old woman who was 20 weeks pregnant. The nodule's FNAC indicated that papillary cancer might
be present. Which of the following should not be used in her management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Radioactive iodine ablation
 
  • In a pregnant woman with a thyroid nodule suspected of papillary cancer, radioactive iodine ablation (Option C) is contraindicated during pregnancy.
  • Radioactive iodine therapy is commonly used in the management of papillary thyroid cancer to ablate residual thyroid tissue after total thyroidectomy or to treat distant metastases.
  • However, it is contraindicated during pregnancy due to the potential harm to the developing fetus.
  • The other options, total thyroidectomy plus neck node dissection (Option A), right lobectomy (Option B), and total thyroidectomy (Option D), may be considered in the management of papillary thyroid cancer in non-pregnant individuals.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 869.

questions.text: Which form of aberration in sexual development has the best prognosis?
questions.solution:
• Congenital adrenal hyperplasia is a type of abnormality in sexual development, which has the best prognosis.
  • It is possible to treat congenital adrenal hyperplasia by giving the body enough glucocorticoids to stop the overproduction of androgens.
  • Surgery can be used to treat the genital abnormality (enlarged clitoris, fusion of labia minora).
  • The prognosis has improved as a result of efforts to treat CAH in pregnancy and newborn screening techniques to detect it. CAH patients can become pregnant and give birth to healthy children.


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 522-524

questions.text: Which hormones fall under the hypothalamus's inhibitory control?
questions.solution:
Both growth hormone and prolactin are under inhibitory control of hypothalamus.
 
  • Growth hormone release is regulated by the hypothalamus, which also secretes somatostatin, an inhibitor of growth hormone release, as well as growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH).
  • The level of growth hormone release will therefore depend on how these hypothalamic elements interact with one another to affect the pituitary.
  • Hence, the growth hormone secretion stimuli may work by boosting hypothalamic GHRH secretion, lowering somatostatin secretion, or both.

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition Page no 908, 917

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with stage 5 chronic renal disease and hypertension recently received a Type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosis. He does not desire to use insulin injections. Which of the following oral hypoglycemic medications, which doesn't require renal dosage modification, is preferred for this patient
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Linagliptin

Linagliptin binds extensively to plasma proteins and is cleared primarily by the hepatobiliary system, with little renal clearance.

*[Extra Edge]: Linagliptin

  • Linagliptin is a competitive inhibitor of DPP 4 enzyme.
  • Dipeptidyl peptidase 4 is a serine protease that is widely distributed throughout the body, expressed as an ectoenzyme on vascular endothelial cells, on the surface of T lymphocytes, and in a circulating form. DPP-4 cleaves the two N-terminal amino acids from peptides with a proline or alanine in the second position and seems to be especially critical for the inactivation of GLP-1 and GIP.
*Audio Explanation:
 

Trick:- 
Linagliptin- Liver excretion, therefore safe in Renal failure.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1039.

questions.text: What does high calcium intake lead to?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Milk-Alkali syndrome

High calcium intake can lead to the development of Milk-Alkali Syndrome. This condition occurs due to excessive consumption of calcium-containing products, such as milk or calcium supplements, combined with excessive intake of absorbable alkali (such as antacids containing calcium carbonate). The syndrome is characterized by the triad of hypercalcemia (high levels of calcium in the blood), metabolic alkalosis (high pH of the blood), and kidney dysfunction.

The other options listed are not directly associated with high calcium intake.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3173.

questions.text: A young woman came in with a bulge in the middle of her neck, as can be seen below, which movements with swallowing and tongue protrusion. Its size has remained unchanged throughout the last year. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Thyroglossal cyst

Thyroglossal cyst is the only cause of midline neck swelling which moves with both swallowing and tongue protrusion.

Thyroglossal Cyst
It is a fibrous cyst that presents as a regular neck mass or a lump.
They are the most common cause of midline neck masses and are generally Subhyoid in location.
The mass on the neck moves during swallowing or on protrusion of the tongue because of its attachment to the tongue (foramen of cecum) via the tract of thyroid descent.

* [Extra Edge]: Treatment Of Thyroglossal Cyst

Treatment must include excision of the whole thyroglossal tract, which involves removal of the body of the hyoid bone and the suprahyoid tract through the tongue base to the vallecula at the site of the primitive foramen caecum, together with a core of tissue on either side. This operation is known as Sistrunk’s operation and minimises recurrence, most notably from small side branches of the thyroglossal tract.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 806.

questions.text: Which medication is best for treating congenital adrenal hyperplasia caused by a 21-alpha hydroxylase deficiency during pregnancy itself?
questions.solution:
• Drug of choice for pre-natal treatment of congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-alpha hydroxylase deficiency is Dexamethasone. 
  • Hydrocortisone, prednisone, and prednisolone are inactivated by the placental type 2 11β-HSD; dexamethasone is not inactivated and should therefore be used in pregnant patients. 
     
 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2796

questions.text: At the start of puberty, which of the following hormones has a permissive effect?
questions.solution:
The permissive effect is a biochemical phenomenon in which the presence of one hormone allows another hormone to exert its full effects on a target cell. For example, thyroid hormones have a permissive relationship with certain reproductive hormones

Leptin has a permissive action at the onset of puberty by increasing GnRH
 
  • Leptin, a hormone that causes satiety and is released by fat cells, may link body weight to puberty: Leptin injections can restore fertility in obese  mice that are infertile due to a lack of leptin production.
  • In young female mice, leptin therapy also causes early puberty.
Clinical Edge- Infertility is seen in female athletes who have very low body fat percentage. As leptin is released from fat cells.


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 319

choices.text: To be given empty stomach with a glass of water

questions.text: What directions should be given to a patient while administering bisphosphonates?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) To be given empty stomach with a glass of water
 
  • Oral bisphosphonates have the potential to cause stomach discomfort, inflammation, and esophageal erosions.
  • This can be avoided by taking the drug on an empty stomach and being seated upright for 30 to 60 minutes afterward.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 370.

choices.text: Start antithyroid drugs, and do urgent MRI brain
Start antithyroid drugs and wait for symptoms to resolve

questions.text: A young woman had high FT4 and TSH level of 8.5 IU/l and hyperthyroidism symptoms. Bitemporal hemianopia is discovered upon closer inspection. What will be the next line of action?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Start antithyroid drugs, and do an urgent MRI brain.
 
  • Bitemporal hemianopia with hyperthyroidism (elevated TSH and T4) is highly suggestive of Central hyperthyroidism due to TSH-secreting adenoma. MRI should be done to confirm the diagnosis of pituitary adenoma. 
 
  • Patients usually present with thyroid goiter and hyperthyroidism, reflecting chronic overproduction of TSH.
  • Diagnosis is based on demonstrating elevated serum free T4 levels, inappropriately normal or high TSH secretion, and MRI evidence of a pituitary adenoma.
  • Elevated free glycoprotein hormone α subunits are seen in many patients.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2917, 2918.

questions.text:
A young female with history of renal calculi complains of bone pain and abdominal cramps.
Multiple fractures were identified during the study, and serum calcium and PTH levels were elevated. Which of the following will be the best inquiry to arrive at a conclusive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Sestamibi scan
 
  • The clinical presentation of bone pain, abdominal cramps, elevated serum calcium, and elevated PTH levels suggests the possibility of hyperparathyroidism.
  • Sestamibi scan is the imaging of choice for diagnosing primary hyperparathyroidism.
  • It is also known as a parathyroid scan, & is the best inquiry to localize the source of abnormal parathyroid activity.
  • The scan involves injecting a radioactive tracer that is selectively taken up by hyperactive parathyroid glands, allowing for their identification.
Other options:
 
  • CECT neck and ultrasound neck can provide additional information, but they are not the primary diagnostic modalities for hyperparathyroidism.
  • Radioiodine scan is used to evaluate thyroid function and is not directly relevant to the diagnosis of hyperparathyroidism.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 877.

questions.text: A diabetic mother delivered a baby whose blood glucose level was 60 mg/dL at birth. What other investigation does the nurse anticipate the doctor would have her conduct?
questions.solution:
Babies of diabetic mothers are more prone to metabolic irregularities than those of non-diabetic mothers, including hypoglycemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia.
Therefore, it is important to check for these quickly. 


Reference-:Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition Page no 913, 983-985

Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 78, 175

questions.text: Which stratum of the bone is the most metabolically active?
questions.solution:
Most metabolically active layer in the bone is endosteum.

In children, periosteum is very active but endosteum is the most
active layer in the bone (overall).



Reference:https://rbmb.net/article-1-105-en.pdf

questions.text: Which of these does not use levonorgestrel for purposes other than contraception?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Premenstrual tension
 
  • In premenstrual tension combined OCPs are used instead of Levonorgestrel.
  • In all other cases Levonorgestrel is used.
  • Severe premenstrual syndrome requires suppression of ovulation by combined estrogen-progesterone treatment given cyclically. Relatively higher dose of progestin is generally used.
  • Ovarian suppression with GnRH agonist may be required in nonresponsive cases. Progestins are added to estrogen when it is used for severe dysmenorrhoea.
     
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 344.
Online Reference:
InformedHealth.org [Internet]. Cologne, Germany: Institute for Quality and Efficiency in Health Care (IQWiG); 2006-. Premenstrual syndrome: Learn More – Treatment for PMS. [Updated 2022 May 18]. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK279264/

questions.text:
A 16-year-old female patient was admitted with primary amenorrhea. Her mother stated that when she was 12 years old, she first began to develop breasts.
A doctor gave her OCPs two years ago, but they had no impact. She played football and was of average height. Examination revealed minimal pubic hair (Tanner's stage 1) and well-developed breasts (Tanner's stage 5). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Androgen insensitivity syndrome

Most likely diagnosis in a 16-year old girl who presents with primary amenorrhea, normal sexual development, normal breasts (Tanner stage 5) but minimal pubic hair (Tanner stage I) is androgen insensitivity syndrome.

Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome: Because the testes produce normal amounts of mullerian-inhibiting factor (MlF), also known as mullerian-inhibiting substance (MIS) or anti-mullerian hormone/factor (AMH/AMF), affected individuals do not have fallopian tubes, a uterus, or a proximal (upper) vagina.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3002, 3003.

questions.text: A thyroidectomy was performed on a patient who had hyperthyroidism. He appeared with thyroid storm symptoms two days later. What is most likely to be the reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 2) Inadequate preoperative preparation

Thyrotoxic crisis (storm) is an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism.
It most commonly occurs if a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy. 
During thyroid storm, an individual's heart rate, blood pressure, and body temperature can soar to dangerously high levels.

* [Extra Edge]: preoperative preparation
 
  • Traditional preparation aims to make the patient biochemically euthyroid at operation.
  • Preparation is as an outpatient and only rarely is admission to hospital necessary on account of severe symptoms at presentation, failure to control the hyperthyroidism or non-compliance with medication. Care should be coordinated with endocrinology input.
  • Carbimazole 30–40 mg/day is the drug of choice for preparation. When euthyroid (after 8–12 weeks), the dose may be reduced to 5 mg 8-hourly or a ‘block and replace’ regime used.
  • In this case, the high dose of carbimazole is continued to inhibit T3 and T4 production and a maintenance dose of 0.1–0.15 mg thyroxine is given daily. The last dose of carbimazole may be given on the evening before surgery. Iodides are not used alone because, if the patient needs preoperative treatment, a more effective drug should be given.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 862.

questions.text: Infant of diabetics mother with weight 3.8 kg presented with seizures after 16 hours of birth. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Hypoglycemia 
The given clinical scenario is a baby with macrosomia due to diabetes in mother. 
  • The given clinical vignette describes a condition which occurs after 16 hours of birth, this rules out Birth asphyxia as its cause which generally occurs soon after birth.
  • Intraventricular haemorrhage is commonly seen in premature babies
  • Hypoglycaemia in neonates born to diabetic mothers , being a very common condition is thus the most appropriate answer to this question. 
 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 983-985

questions.text: Which of the following statements about T3 and T4 acting on THR(Thyroid hormone receptor) is correct?
questions.solution:
T3 T4 acts on transcription factor.
 
  • Nuclear hormone receptors in humans belong to a superfamily of 48 receptors that react to a wide range of ligands.
  • The transcription factors known as receptor proteins are able to influence the expression of genes regulating many physiological functions, including reproduction, development, and metabolism.
  • Receptors for circulating steroid hormones like androgens, oestrogens, glucocorticoids, thyroid hormone, and vitamin D are well-known members of the family.

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 55

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be used for post-coital contraception?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1)  Desogestrel 

After having sex, women may use emergency contraception (EC), sometimes known as emergency postcoital contraception, to avoid becoming pregnant.
Desogestrel is not as an emergency contraceptive.

Emergency Contraception Methods:
1. Progestin-only Pill-0.75 mg levonorgestrel 2 doses 12 hours apart with 72 hours
2. Copper-containing IUD within 5 days
3. Combined oral contraceptive pills that can be used for emergency contraception when taken in multiple doses 12-24 hours apart, within 72 hours.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 347.

questions.text: What other research might you suggest in galactorrhoea-amenorrhea disorders other than serum prolactin?
questions.solution:
Apart from prolactin, TSH should be advised in a patient of galactorrhea-amenorrhea syndrome. 
 
  • Basal, fasting morning PRL levels (normally <20 μg/L) should be measured to assess hypersecretion. Both false-positive and false-negative results may be encountered.
 
  • Galactorrhea and Amenorrhea are commonly associated with hyperprolactinemia caused by many conditions.
 
  • Hypothyroidism should be excluded by measuring TSH and T4 levels.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2909.

questions.text: Which of these is not seen in MEN-1 syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Posterior pituitary tumors

Posterior pituitary tumors are not seen in case of MEN-1 syndrome because in MEN disorders, only anterior pituitary tumours develop.
Since the posterior pituitary contains neural components, endocrine neoplasias cannot develop there.




Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 912.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones should be replaced first in the case of a six-year-old child managed by complete surgical removal of craniopharyngioma and now has developed multiple endocrinopathies?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Hydrocortisone 

Complete surgical removal of Craniopharyngioma leads to the development of Pan hypopituitarism.
  • This leads to reduced production of pituitary hormones ultimately causing multiple endocrinopathies.
  • Of these the most dangerous outcome is the development of secondary adrenal insufficiency due to reduced production of ACTH from the pituitary gland.
  • Hence the first hormone that should be replaced is Hydrocortisone in order to prevent the development of secondary adrenal insufficiency. Thyroxine is replaced in the end because thyroxine supplementation increases BMR and it leads to consumption of other hormones if replaced earlier and deficiencies of other hormones could occur. 
 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2884,2676,2677

choices.text: Increased secretion when plasma osmolality is low
Act on distal tubule and increase permeability

questions.text: Which of the following is not true for ADH?
questions.solution:
The various stimulus for secretion of ADH are as follows- 1. Increased plasma osmolality 2. Decreased blood volume 3. Decreased blood pressure 4. Hypoxia 5. Drugs such as morphine, nicotine and cyclophosphamide. ADH secretion is decreased when plasma osmolality is low.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 307,686

questions.text: What exactly is an ulipristal acetate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answers is (Option 4) Selective progesterone receptor modulator
 
  • Ulipristal acetate exerts its pharmacological activity by binding to the body’s progesterone receptors to produce an anti-progesterone contraceptive effect on the ovary (by suppressing or delaying ovulation) and on the endometrium (by decreasing endometrial thickness).
  • It inhibits ovulation by suppressing LH surge as well as by direct effect on follicular rupture. In addition, its action on endometrium can interfere with implantation.
  • In clinical trials the efficacy of ulipristal (30 mg) as emergency contraceptive has been rated equal to that of levonorgestrel (1.5 mg) when taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse, and to be more effective when taken between 72–120 hours.
  • Thus, it may have an advantage, if the woman misses to take the drug within 72 hours.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 346.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has several lytic bone lesions, a fractured clavicle, and second and third metatarsal periosteal resorption. Which diagnosis is most likely
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Hyperparathyroidism
 
  • Hyperparathyroidism is a condition characterized by excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH) from the parathyroid glands, leading to increased bone resorption and thus increased levels of calcium in the blood (hypercalcemia). It's classical symptoms is explained by bones, stones, groans and psychiatric overtones. 
  • This can result in various bone abnormalities and manifestations, including osteoporosis, bone pain, fractures, and periosteal resorption.
  • The presence of lytic bone lesions, fractured clavicle, and periosteal resorption of the metatarsals suggests a significant bone pathology.
  • Hyperparathyroidism can cause bone resorption, leading to the development of lytic lesions and increased risk of fractures.
  • Additionally, periosteal resorption is a characteristic finding in hyperparathyroidism, where the outer layer of bone (periosteum) becomes thickened and shows evidence of increased bone remodeling.








Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3175, 3176.

questions.text: Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) cannot by itself diagnose:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Follicular carcinoma of thyroid

FNAC is not enough to diagnose Follicular Carcinoma of Thyroid Gland:

Only a core tissue biopsy can show evidence of basement membrane and capsular invasion, which are crucial to distinguish between follicular adenomas and follicular carcinoma of the thyroid.

Simply observing atypical malignant cells in the fine needle aspirate material can detect papillary carcinomas, breast cancer, and lung cancer.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 858.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones is secreted by the area designated "A" in the following regions of the adrenal gland?
questions.solution:
In the diagram, the following layers of the Adrenal Cortex are shown:

A: Zona Glomerulosa - Aldosterone

B: Zona Fasciculata - Corticosteroids mainly 

C: Zona Reticularis - Sex Steroids mainly 

Mnemonic trick: -
GFR- Salt, sugar , sex.


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 330,331

questions.text: Which is not a side-effect of growth hormone therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Hypoglycemia

* [Extra Edge]: GH therapy in pediatrics age group
  • Rarely, patients develop intracranial hypertension with papilledema, visual changes, headache, nausea, or vomiting. Because of this, funduscopic examination is recommended at the initiation of therapy and at periodic intervals thereafter.
  • The consensus is that GH should not be administered in the first year after treatment of pediatric tumors, including leukemia, or during the first 2 years after therapy for medulloblastomas or ependymomas.
  • Because an increased incidence of type 2 diabetes mellitus has been reported, fasting glucose levels should be followed periodically during therapy. Finally, too-rapid growth may be associated with slipped epiphyses or scoliosis.
* [Extra Edge]: GH therapy in adult age group
  • Side effects associated with the initiation of GH therapy in adults (peripheral edema, carpal tunnel syndrome, arthralgias, and myalgias) occur most frequently in older or obese patients and generally respond to a decrease in dose.
  • Estrogens (e.g., birth control medications and estrogen supplements) inhibit GH action so that a larger dose is needed to maintain the same IGF-1 level.
  • GH therapy can increase the metabolic inactivation of cortisol in the liver.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 930.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient had spade-like fingers, frontal bossing, an expanded jaw, and an enlarged nasal bone. Which of the subsequent tests will you perform to make a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  IGF1
  • The clinical presentation of spade-like fingers, frontal bossing, an expanded jaw, and an enlarged nasal bone are characteristic features of Acromegaly.
  • It is a hormonal disorder caused by the excessive production of GH in adulthood, usually due to a pituitary adenoma which leads to increased production of IGF1, which is a growth factor that mediates the effects of GH on tissues.
 
  • Measuring IGF1 levels is an important diagnostic test for acromegaly. Elevated levels of IGF1 in the blood are indicative of excessive GH production.
  • However, the diagnosis of acromegaly requires additional confirmatory testing, such as an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) and measurement of GH levels.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2912.

choices.text: 99 m-Tc scan should be performed to determine whether the nodules are hypo-functioning or hyperfunctioning
All nodules >1 cm should be resected irrespective of cytology
FNAC ideally should be performed for all nodules >2 cm in diameter

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is diagnosed with a nodular goiter. Which of the following statements regarding her evaluation and management is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) All nodules >1 cm should be resected irrespective of cytology 

Subjects with a benign cytology are considered true negative if they are followed up for a period of at least 2 years – this will allow identification of those with changing symptoms for a repeat FNAB, and true negativity is confirmed if a diagnosis of thyroid neoplasia has not been made after a 2-year follow-up.

Surgery is required if malignant or suspicious cytology is reported. Rapid growth and increasing pressure effects (breathing difficulty) will signal the need for surgery. Some patients may undergo surgery for pressure effects like dysphagia, and other patients may opt for surgery because of cosmetic reasons due to the size of the goiter.
It has been suggested that in subjects with a suspicious FNAB report, the rate of surgery may be reduced further by subjecting patients to radio nuclide scanning and performing surgery on those nodules that are cold or warm, and simply following up those with hot nodules without surgery as the risk of malignancy in these nodules is very low.



Online Reference: Unnikrishnan AG, Kalra S, Baruah M, Nair G, Nair V, Bantwal G, Sahay RK. Endocrine Society of India management guidelines for patients with thyroid nodules: A position statement. Indian J Endocrinol Metab. 2011 Jan;15(1):2-8. doi: 10.4103/2230-8210.77566. PMID: 21584159; PMCID: PMC3079862.

questions.text:
The graph below shows the three chemicals during hunger. On the left is the scale for letters A and B, while on the right is the scale for letters C. Which of the compounds does curve B represent?


1. RT3
2. T3
3. T4 
4. DIT
questions.solution:
In the given diagram:
A curve is rT3
B curve is T3
C curve is T4

The fall in T3 levels with a corresponding increase in RT3 is the most notable consequence of fasting on the thyroid profile. Refeeding quickly undoes the modifications, which lower tissue metabolism to conserve calories. In wasting disorders, similar alterations take place.


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 360,361

questions.text: When should the next dose of levonorgestrel 0.75 mg be given for adequate protection following unprotected intercourse?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) 1 tab after 12 hours
 
  • Levonorgestrel is used as an emergency contraceptive, first at 0.75 mg and then again at 0.75 mg after 12 hours.
  • Levonorgestrel acts via multiple mechanisms including prevention of ovarian development, fertilization, and implantation.
  • It should be taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 348.

questions.text: For two days, a patient has been exhibiting escalating muscle weakness. Examining the limb reveals it to be flaccid. Which investigation should be carried out first?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Serum potassium

The presenting symptoms of escalating muscle weakness and flaccid limb raise concerns about potential electrolyte abnormalities, specifically hypokalemia (low serum potassium levels). Hypokalemia can cause muscle weakness and affect muscle function, leading to flaccid paralysis.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 350, 3530.

choices.text: 50% reduction in PTH within 10 mins of gland removal
50% reduction in PTH within 5 mins of gland removal
25% reduction in PTH within 10 mins of gland removal
25% reduction in PTH within 5 mins of gland removal

questions.text: How is removal of the correct gland after surgery confirmed in parathyroid adenoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 50% reduction in PTH within 10 mins of gland removal

The Miami Criteria are used to assess the effectiveness of removing a single adenoma in a patient with hyperparathyroidism.

  • The criteria measure the drop in the circulating plasma PTH (parathyroid hormone) level 10 minutes after resection.
  • A drop in the PTH level to less than half its maximum preoperative levels and to the normal range indicates successful resection and single-gland disease.
  • If the drop in PTH is not detected or is insufficient, multiple gland disease is suspected and further treatment or exploration may be necessary. The half life of PTH is 3-5 minutes, allowing for a significant drop to be detected in the plasma following resection of a single adenoma.

Fig: Miami criteria for intraoperative parathyroid hormone (PTH) measurement. Drop of PTH into the normal range and less than half the maximum value at 10 minutes postresection.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 880.

questions.text: In the production of steroid hormones, a typical intermediary is:
questions.solution:
Pregnenolone acts as a common intermediate in synthesis of steroid hormones.

When ACTH stimulates the adrenal gland, an esterase is triggered, and the free cholesterol that is produced is carried into the mitochondrion where it is converted to pregnenolone by a cytochrome P450 side chain cleavage enzyme.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 336

questions.text: Select the drug that can be given in renal failure safely.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Linagliptin

Linagliptin is primarily excreted via feces and to doesn't require any dose modification in renal failure. 
All the rest of the DPP-4 inhibitors require dose modification if GFR falls below 50ml.min.1.73m2

*Audio Explanation:


Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1039.

questions.solution:

The photo shows a hot nodule

choices.text: Operated even if the patient is asymptomatic
Majority of the goiters derive their blood supply from mediastinal vessels
Majority of the Retrosternal goiter can be removed by a neck incision

questions.text: Which is true with respect to Retrosternal goiter ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Majority of the Retrosternal goiter can be removed by a neck incision

  • Patients with retrosternal goiter should be carefully assessed to determine whether they may require surgery.
  • In most cases, minimal symptoms and elderly age suggest observation only. However, if there is significant airway compression, symptoms present or the patient is young, the benefits of surgery should be weighed against the risks.
  • Most retrosternal goiter can be managed safely via transcervical approach, but may require conversion to an open sternotomy if diagnosis reveals malignancy, extension into posterior mediastinum or large size. In these cases, joint efforts from both thoracic and neck surgery may be beneficial.

Fig: Chest radiograph showing a retrosternal goiter with calcification and tracheal displacement

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 860.

questions.text: At the start of puberty, which of the following hormones has a permissive effect?
questions.solution:
Leptin has a permissive action on GnRH.

Pulsatile release of GnRH is one of the main hormones for initiation of puberty. For one hormone to exert effect, some other hormone must have to prepare the tissue for this effect.

Leptin accelerates GnRH pulsatility in Hypothalamic neurons, fastening puberty.

Thus, leptin is said to be having a permissive action.


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 391

questions.text: Lactic acidosis is a serious, occasionally fatal, adverse effect of metformin. Which of the following does not raise the risk of lactic acidosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Smoking

* [Extra Edge]: Metformin
  • MOA – Stimulates AMPK, blocks gluconeogenesis
  • DOC – Management and prophylaxis of DM type 2
  • Other uses – PCOS, NAFLD
  • Side-effects – Reduced Vit. B12 absorption, Lactic acidosis
* Conditions increasing the risk of Lactic acidosis
  1. Renal failure
  2. Liver failure
  3. Severe lung disease
  4. Elderly
  5. Chronic alcoholics
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 299.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of glucocorticoid deficiency?
questions.solution:
Diabetes is NOT a feature of Glucocorticoid deficiency as glucocorticoids cause hyperglycemia. Rest all are features of Glucocorticoid deficiency.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2972.

questions.text: Name the common site of gastrinoma in MEN1 syndrome.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Duodenum

  • The above statement is referring to Gastrinomas, which are tumors that enhances the secretion of gastrin, a hormone which increases the hydrochloric acid production of the stomach, causing ulcers and other acid-related conditions.
  • It is associated with MEN 1 syndrome, which is a genetic disorder that affects among other things, the exocrine glands of the pancreas. 
  • More than 70% of the gastrinomas in MEN 1 syndrome are commonly located in the first and second part of the duodenum.
  • This section of the duodenum is also known as the 'gastrinoma triangle'.
  • Therefore, due to the high likelihood of tumors being located in this particular section, it is recommended that all patients with gastrinomas should be tested for MEN 1 syndrome and undergo surgical exploration if there is no evidence of diffuse metastases.

Fig: The gastrinoma triangle

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 907.

questions.text: Select the type of lipase that is controlled by glucagon.
questions.solution:
Hormone sensitive lipase, the enzyme which mobilizes fatty acids from triacylglycerol stores in adipose tissue is inhibited by Postaglandin-E  and Insulin while Glucagon, ACTH, epinephrine and vasopressin promote activation of the enzyme.

This lipase is distinct from lipoprotein lipase, which catalyzes lipoprotein triacylglycerol hydrolysis before its uptake into extrahepatic tissues.


Reference-Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 29

questions.text: Which of the following is not serious side effect of thioamide group of drugs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Anaphylaxis

Anaphylaxis is however not seen as a side effect.
Thioamide drugs block thyroid peroxidase.
Propylthiouracil, Carbimazole and Methimazole are included.

*Audio Explanation:

* Side Effects of Thioamide drugs:
  1. Agranulocytosis (most serious)
  2. Urticaria (most common)
  3. Fever
  4. Hepatitis
  5. Nephritis
 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 275.

questions.text: A diabetic and hypertensive patient on multiple medications developed septicemia. The creatinine level in the blood is 5.7 mg/dl. Which of the following medications should be discontinued?
questions.solution:
Metformin should be stopped in this case.

Contraindications of Metflormin:
 
  • Serum creatinine >1.5 mg/dL (men) >1.4 mg/dL (women)
  • eGFR < 30 ml/min
  • CHE
  • Radiographic contrast studies
  • Hospitalized patients
  • Acidosis


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3110.

questions.text: Which hormone will not have to be additionally supplied in case of a 56 years old female who underwent trans sphenoid hypophysectomy for pituitary tumor and now has low ACTH, TSH, FSH and LH
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Mineralocorticoids
 
  • Mineralocorticoids are not required in this patient's treatment plan because, following hypophysectomy, basal levels of mineralocorticoids—primarily aldosterone—remain normal because the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone feedback is not regulated by the levels of ACTH.
  • Rather, it is primarily regulated by serum potassium levels.
  • Since the lady has low FSH and LH, estradiol has to be supplemented in hormone replacement therapy
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 898.

questions.text: On which of the following does sex chromatin testing depend?
questions.solution:
In females, 1-15% of polymorphonuclear leukocytes can be seen with a small "drumstick" shaped segment of chromatin known as barr body protruding from the nucleus, which indicates the presence of an inactive X chromosome. This is not visible in males. The Lyon hypothesis suggests that one of the two X chromosomes in female cells is randomly inactivated, and that all but one of the X chromosomes present in a cell with more than two X chromosomes will be inactivated. This can be observed in a variety of types of cells, most notably within the nuclei of polymorphonuclear leukocytes, with the inactive X chromosome being visible in the form of a "drumstick" of chromatin known as a Barr body.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 385

questions.text: Identify the option that is not a life-threatening side-effect of thioamide.

Thioamide drugs block thyroid peroxidase.

  3. Busulphan
  4. Methotrucksate
  5. Amiodarone
  6. Bleomycin
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 275.

questions.text:
A diabetic woman who was morbidly obese was on failed metformin therapy. She has had pancreatitis and has a family history of bladder cancer.
The patient is unwilling to receive injections. Which of the following options would be best for lowering her glucose levels?
questions.solution:
Orally administered canagliflozin is a Sodium-Glucose Cotransporter 2 Inhibitor and also causes weight loss. 
 
  • Sitagliptin raises the risk of acute pancreatitis
  • use of Pioglitazone is linked to a slight elevated risk of bladder cancer  and
  • Liraglutide is administered subcutaneously by injections

Canagliflozin is the preferred medication for the clinical scenario at hand. It also helps in weight reduction in obese diabetic patients.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3110.

questions.text: The method for thyroid examination is shown below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Lahey's method

Lahey's technique for palpating the thyroid is demonstrated in the image above.
The lobes are pushed to one side for palpation according to Lahey's method. The left hand should be used to push the left lobe laterally while the right hand is used to palpate the lobe.
CRILE'S METHOD- This method involves placing the thumb on the thyroid gland and asking the patient to swallow. Small thyroid nodules within the thyroid gland can be palpated by this method.

Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 454.

questions.text: What is the most common progesterone metabolite discharged in urine?
questions.solution:
Most common metabolite of progesterone excreted in urine is Pregnanediol.

The principal pathway of the metabolism of progesterone is progesterone -> pregnanedione - pregnanolone >- pregnanediol, this pregnanediol is then excreted in the urine.


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 400,401

questions.text: Identify the site that is least commonly preferred for insulin injection.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) dorsum of hand

* [ Extra Edge]Sites of insulin injection:
  • The four safe areas for insulin injections are the sides of the thighs, the backs of the upper arms, the abdomen and the upper outer buttocks.
  • To avoid bumps and scar tissue on the skin, rotation of insulin injection sites should be done and a systematic approach to injection site rotation adopted.
  • Thus, injections may be given in the abdomen, outer thigh, back of the arm, and flank/buttocks regions.
  • Insulin injected on the abdomen acts faster than insulin injected on the thigh.
  • The rate of absorption of insulin injected on the arm is between that of insulin injected on the abdomen and that injected on the thigh.

Fig: Insulin Injection sites

Online Reference:
Bahendeka S, Kaushik R, Swai AB, Otieno F, Bajaj S, Kalra S, Bavuma CM, Karigire C. EADSG Guidelines: Insulin Storage and Optimisation of Injection Technique in Diabetes Management. questions.text: One of the two patients with atherosclerosis has diabetes, whereas the other does not. Diabetic patients are 100 times more likely than non-diabetics to have:
questions.solution:
• The incidence of lower limb ischemia is increased 100 times in patients with diabetes due to the hardened and narrowed arteries caused by high levels of sugar present in the bloodstream.
 
  • The narrowing of the arteries reduces the amount of blood that flows to the lower limbs, thereby increasing the risk of decreased oxygen levels to the limbs and leading to tissue damage.
 
  • The high blood sugar levels also make the blood more viscous, causing it to flow more slowly and resulting in greater chance of a blockage and lower limb ischemia.
  • Other complications are also increased but not 100 times as limb ischemia


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3127.

choices.text: Level 1 to Level 5 nodes of ipsilateral side

questions.text: Which among the following structures is removed in modified radicle neck dissection
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Level 1 to Level 5 nodes of ipsilateral side 

Modified radical neck dissection
This term denotes a procedure in which one or more of the non-lymphatic structures are preserved (the accessory nerve, the sternocleidomastoid muscle or the internal jugular vein) with clearance of all nodal levels (I–V).



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 811.

questions.text: Why is insulin resistance is seen in liver disease?
questions.solution:
Insulin resistance in liver disease is primarily associated with 3. Hepatocyte dysfunction. Hepatocyte dysfunction can impair insulin signaling pathways, leading to decreased glucose uptake and altered glucose production, contributing to insulin resistance. While hepatic steatosis (fatty liver) can also play a role, it is the dysfunction of liver cells that is a key factor in the development of insulin resistance.

 

Reference:Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition page no 2578

questions.text: Identify the drug that does not have a role in osteoporosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Milnacipran
 
  • All of the given options except Milnapricin are used in managing Osteoporosis.
  • Milnacipran is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI). It is not used in treating Osteoporosis. It is used in the management of Fibromyalgia.
  • PTH and strontium can be used in treating osteoporosis in some cases.
  • denosumab is anti-RANK ligand monoclonal antibody used in osteoporosis.
Treatment of Osteoporosis
Class Examples Mechanism of Action
Bisphosphonates - Alendronate- Risedronate- Zoledronic acid Inhibit bone resorption, increasing bone density.
SERMs (Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulators) - Raloxifene Mimic estrogen to protect bones, reduce resorption.
PTH Analogues - Teriparatide- Abaloparatide Stimulate bone formation.
RANK Ligand Inhibitors - Denosumab Inhibit bone resorption by blocking RANKL.
Calcitonin - Calcitonin (salmon) Inhibit bone resorption.
Strontium Ranelate - Strontium ranelate Increases bone formation and reduces resorption.
Estrogen Therapy - Conjugated estrogens Increase bone density by reducing resorption.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 345.

questions.text: What conditions are related to these two images?
questions.solution:
The lower leg's anterior and lateral surfaces were found to have an inflammatory, indurated plaque with a deep pink or purple color and a "orange skin" appearance.

This may point to the presence of pretibial myxedema, a condition that is seen in patients with Grave's disease (hyperthyroidism).
 
  • In 5% of Graves' disease patients, thyroid dermopathy develops, nearly invariably alongside moderate or severe ophthalmopathy.
 
  • Skin alterations can occur at other areas as well, especially following trauma, despite the fact that they are most common over the anterior and lateral portions of the lower leg (hence the term pretibial myxedema).
 
  • The typical lesion is an indurated, non-inflamed plaque with a "orange skin" look and a deep pink or purple tint. The illness can occasionally spread across the entire lower leg and foot, imitating elephantiasis, and nodules may become involved.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2939.

questions.text: After undergoing B/L adrenalectomy due to B/L pheochromocytoma, the patient experienced  lethargy, exhaustion, low blood pressure, and normal pulse 1 day later. There are no indications of volume deficiency, what is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Addisonian Crisis

  • Pheochromocytomas and paragangliomas are tumors which are derived from the sympathetic or parasympathetic nervous system and produce catecholamines.
  • The ultimate treatment goal for these tumors is complete removal of the tumors, which can be done through partial or total adrenalectomy. However, it is important that the normal adrenal cortex is still there, in order to prevent Addison's disease and to make sure that bilateral pheochromocytomas are most likely to be present.
  • Nitroprusside infusion is used for any intraoperative hypertension and hypotension can be solved with a volume infusion. Postoperatively, the catecholamine levels should be checked to make sure they are normalized.
  • An ACTH test should be done to check for cortisol deficiency when bilateral adrenal cortex-sparing surgery is done. The risks of surgery for pheochromocytoma include severe preoperative hypertension, high secretion tumors and recurrence.
  • Additionally, the absence of adrenal glands can lead to a sharp drop in cortisol which requires lifelong glucocorticoid replacement therapy which leads to a 15-25% risk of developing Nelson syndrome.
  • Nelson syndrome is characterized by the enlargement of the pituitary gland and the development of pituitary gland tumors.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 898.

questions.text: What among the following functions via G-protein coupled receptors?

All the muscarinic receptors which are known are G-protein-linked receptors that interact with different cellular mediators.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of drugs and their indications is mismatched?

Carbamazepine is the drug of choice for partial seizures and trigeminal neuralgia.

questions.text: Which of the following results in the following skin changes?

questions.text: The nerve that will sustain the least damage during thyroid surgery is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Marginal mandibular

Among the given options, marginal mandibular nerve is least likely to be injured during thyroid surgery as it is situated higher up among the given nerves. Therefore, it is least likely to be encountered in dissection involved in thyroid surgery. Note- The most common nerve injured in thyroid surgery is ELN ( not RLN ).

The fascia above the facial vessels is palpated in the midportion of the body of the mandible. The nerve is usually identified in the fascia above the vessels and is dissected along its path horizontally to expose it as it exits the parotid and traverses onto the muscles anteriorly.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about the uses of iodine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Its use is contraindicated in hyperthyroidism

Iodine is not contraindicated in hyperthyroidism.

Iodine is used to treat hyperthyroidism in the following ways: 

  • In the perioperative period in preparation for thyroidectomy. 
  • In conjunction with other antithyroid drugs and propranolol in the treatment of thyrotoxicosis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old average-weight female complains of oligomenorrhoea along with facial hair. An initial investigation reveals elevated free testosterone levels. On ultrasound, the ovaries were normal. Which of the following could be a likely etiology?

Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome (PCOS) is the most likely etiology in a 20-year-old average-weight female with complaints of oligomenorrhea (irregular menstrual cycle) and facial hirsutism (excessive facial hair) with raised free testosterone levels (suggesting hyperandrogenism) and normal appearance of ovaries on ultrasound.
She meets two out of the three Rotterdam criteria for PCOS and hence, it's the most likely diagnosis.

Shaw’s Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 314, 315.

questions.text:
A patient with a midline neck enlargement that shifts with deglutition arrives to the OPD. He also has exophthalmos and tachycardia. What specific investigations are necessary in this situation?
(i) Thyroid scan
(ii) FNAC
(iii) Thyroid function tests

Anti - Thyroid Antibodies present.

questions.text: An individual with spread cancer visits the palliative care clinic complaining of nausea, vomiting, and impaired sensory perception. Investigations reveal hypercalcemia. What will be the initial chain of command?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Intravenous fluids
 
  • Hypercalcemia is a sign of paraneoplastic syndromes which arise due to several types of cancers in the body.
  • Intravenous fluids will increase blood volume thereby reducing the concentration of blood calcium levels.
  • Hence it is the first step, after that IV bisphosphonates can be given. Hence correct option is 3.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1058.

questions.text: A diabetic patient, age 55, comes with brief vision impairment that lasts for two to three days until it is abruptly erased. Which test from the list below would be most effective in determining his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The above scenario signifies Amaurosis fugax i.e transient vision loss can be sign of Hyperhomocysteinemia.
 
  • Hyperhomocysteinemia refers to increased total plasma concentration of homocysteine with or without an increase in free homocysteine(disulfide form).
  • Homocysteine can act as an atherogenic and thrombophilic agent, and increased total plasma homocysteine has been associated with an increased risk for coronary, cerebrovascular, and peripheral arterial disease as well as for deep-vein thrombosis.
 
  • Classic homocystinuria, the most common (frequency 1:450,000), results from reduced activity of cystathionine β-synthase, the pyridoxal phosphate–dependent enzyme that condenses homocysteine with serine to form cystathionine.
  • Most patients present between 3 and 5 years of age with dislocated optic lenses and intellectual disability (in about half of cases). Some patients develop a marfanoid habitus and radiologic evidence of osteoporosis.
 
  • Life-threatening vascular complications (affecting coronary, renal, and cerebral arteries) can occur during the first decade of life and are the major cause of morbidity and mortality.
  • Classic homocystinuria can be diagnosed with analysis of plasma amino acids, showing elevated methionine and presence of free homocystine. Total plasma homocysteine is also extremely elevated (usually >100 μM).



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3271, 3272.

questions.text: A thyroidectomy patient was being extubated. The anesthesiologist discovered that the patient starts to experience recurring cyanotic spells when the tube is removed. Which of the subsequent might be the reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) B/L RLN palsy
 
  • Recurring cyanotic spells after extubation suggest bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) palsy.
  • RLN palsy can occur as a complication of thyroidectomy.
  • It leads to vocal cord dysfunction and can result in airway compromise.
  • Immediate intervention may be required to secure the airway and ensure adequate oxygenation.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 864.

questions.text: The potassium ionophore valinomycin has the following effects on pancreatic beta cells:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Decrease the secretion of insulin 
 
  • Valinomycin is a natural neutral ionophore account for its lack of a residual charge, allowing it to move potassium ions through membranes as it acts as a potassium-specific transporter.
  • It increases the permeability of potassium ions which results in hyperpolarization of beta cells and inhibiting the release of insulin.

Huang S, Liu Y, Liu WQ, Neubauer P, Li J. The Nonribosomal Peptide Valinomycin: From Discovery to Bioactivity and Biosynthesis. Microorganisms. 2021 Apr 8;9(4):780. doi: 10.3390/microorganisms9040780. PMID: 33917912; PMCID: PMC8068249.

questions.text: Pick the option that is not true about treatment with iodine.
questions.solution:
Iodine is not contraindicated in hyperthyroidism. Although use of iodine in hyperthyroidism is controversial, studies have suggested that iodine can worsen the condition in some cases, and it is not recommended for use except in extreme cases.

  • Iodine supplements are generally only used after other treatments, such as antithyroid medications and surgery, have failed to adequately control the symptoms.
  • In these cases, high doses of iodine can be used to temporarily shut down the thyroid, allowing time for other treatments to take effect and to alleviate symptoms.
  • Iodide can be used in Thyrotoxicosis also. Stable iodide (5 drops SSKI every 6 h) is given to block thyroid hormone synthesis via the Wolff-Chaikoff effect.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2941, 2942.

A specimen must show at least six groups of follicular cells, each of which should have at least ten cells, ideally on a single slide.

questions.text: Which of the following given below stimulates the secretion of aldosterone?
questions.solution:

This negative feedback effect of exogenous glucocorticoid administration can lead to secondary adrenal insufficiency. Hypernatremia suppresses aldosterone release to prevent further Na+ and water reabsorption.

questions.text: Select the drug which acts through Tyrosine Kinase receptor.
questions.solution:
Tyrosine kinase receptors are integral components of the insulin signaling pathway. They are transmembrane proteins that bind and respond to insulin in the bloodstream, transducing the signal across the cell membrane and into the cell itself. Upon insulin binding to the receptor, the intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity is activated and the receptor autophosphorylates, resulting in the recruitment of adaptor proteins that further activate multiple downstream signaling pathways that regulate many cellular metabolic processes. This ultimately results in the cellular uptake of glucose, essential for maintaining an adequate glucose homeostasis. The tyrosine kinase receptor plays a pivotal role in insulin's mechanism of action, as it is essential for transducing the extracellular signal across the membrane and for regulating the intracellular metabolic processes that enable the cellular uptake of glucose.
 

1. Nuclear receptors- Sex hormones 
2. Cell membrane receptors- GPCR or Tyrosine Kinase receptors 

  •  Tyrosine Kinase - Remember PIG - Prolactin, Insulin, GH
  • GPCR - remaining vast majority of hormones (Non PIG)


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 55

questions.text: Which prolactin concentration would clearly indicate prolactinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: 200 mg/ml

A prolactin concentration of 200 ng/mL (or 2000 mIU/L) would be more indicative of a prolactinoma.

Prolactinomas are typically associated with significantly elevated prolactin levels above the normal range, and a concentration of 200 ng/mL is generally considered high.

questions.text: Which of these is least likely to have lymph node metastasis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Follicular Ca Thyroid

Anaplastic Ca Thyroid > Papillary Ca Thyroid > Medullary Ca Thyroid > Follicular Ca Thyroid.
 
  • Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid is more commonly seen in iodine-deficient areas.
  • They present as solitary thyroid nodules and are associated with a rapid increase in size. 
  • Pain is not common but can be seen if hemorrhage occurs into the nodule.
  • Metastasis is bloodborne and lymph node involvement is not seen.
  • FNAC cannot differentiate benign and malignant follicular lesions.
