questions.text: Which is the first line of RX of osteoporosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Bisphosphonates

  • First line drugs used in postmenopausal osteoporosis include bisphosphonates, selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs), and calcitonin.
  • Bisphosphonates are typically used as the first line of treatment, as they can help reduce the risk of fractures. SERMs are useful for decreasing the amount of bone loss.
  • Finally, calcitonin is generally used as a short-term preventive measure to reduce the risk of vertebral fractures.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 369.

questions.text: What is the replacement dose of hydrocortisone (mg/day) for Chronic Adrenal Insufficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 4. 20 mg/day.
 
  • Glucocorticoid replacement for the treatment of chronic adrenal insufficiency should be administered at a dose that replaces the physiologic daily cortisol production, which is usually achieved by the oral administration of 15–25 mg hydrocortisone in two to three divided doses.
 
  • Pregnancy may require an increase in hydrocortisone dose by 50% during the last trimester. In all patients, at least one-half of the daily dose should be administered in the morning. 

Therefore, among the given options 20 mg/day will be the most appropriate answer.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2972.

choices.text: Lining of tall columnar and cuboidal cells

questions.text: What is the difference between a well differentiated follicular carcinoma of thyroid and a follicular adenoma
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Vascular invasion

The key difference between a well-differentiated follicular carcinoma of the thyroid and a follicular adenoma is the presence of vascular invasion.
  • A follicular adenoma is a benign tumor of the thyroid gland that is usually encapsulated and does not invade the surrounding tissues.
  • In contrast, a well-differentiated follicular carcinoma of the thyroid has the potential to invade the surrounding tissues, including blood vessels, which is known as vascular invasion.
  • Vascular invasion is an important diagnostic feature that helps to distinguish between a benign follicular adenoma and a malignant follicular carcinoma.
  • The presence of vascular invasion indicates that the tumor has the potential to spread to other parts of the body, and therefore, it requires aggressive treatment such as surgery, radioactive iodine therapy, and/or external beam radiation therapy.
  • Other features such as Hurtle cell change, lining of tall columnar and cuboidal cells, and nuclear features may also be helpful in distinguishing between a follicular adenoma and a follicular carcinoma, but they are not as reliable as vascular invasion.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 868.

questions.text: Which of the following is physically and functionally similar to HCG
questions.solution:
The luteinizing hormone (LH), which is released by gonadotropes in the anterior pituitary gland, and HCG share structural and functional similarities. Since there is only one receptor, the actions of hCG and LH are identical.) Chorionic gonadotropin (CG) and LH are both heterodimeric glycoproteins made up of α and β subunits.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 406

questions.text: Which medication from the list below is used to treat obesity over the long term?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Liraglutide
 
  • Because of growing evidence of cardiovascular and other hazards, sibutramine and rimonabant were no longer sold or used.   
  • Fenfluramine and Dexfenfluramine are non-selective 5-HT2 agonists. 
  • When combined with phentermine as Fen-Phen and Dex-Phen, they were somewhat effective. They were the most widely used and successful appetite suppressants. However, these were removed once it was shown that they contributed to heart valve abnormalities and pulmonary hypertension. 
  • Metformin, which is advised as the initial treatment for type 2 diabetes.
  • Liraglutide is a GLP1 agonist. It decreases appetite.
Online Reference:
Mehta A, Marso SP, Neeland IJ. Liraglutide for weight management: a critical review of the evidence. Obes Sci Pract. 2017 Mar;3(1):3-14. doi: 10.1002/osp4.84. Epub 2016 Dec 19. PMID: 28392927; PMCID: PMC5358074.

questions.text: What is the first sign of third cranial nerve involvement in a person with diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Normal light reflex.
 
  • Acquired oculomotor nerve palsy can have various causes, and if a patient presents with specific symptoms such as ophthalmoplegia, ptosis, and mydriasis, it is important to rule out a compressive etiology such as an intracranial aneurysm.
  • The pupillary fibers within the oculomotor nerve are located peripherally and have better collateral blood supply, making them more susceptible to compression. The most common cause in such cases is a posterior communicating artery aneurysm.
  • However, if a patient has a complete or incomplete oculomotor palsy without pupil involvement (pupil-sparing 3rd nerve palsy), it is more likely to be related to ischemic processes, although compression and inflammation should still be considered as potential causes.
  • Pupillary fibers, being more peripheral, are less vulnerable to ischemia.
  • Diabetes is an ischemic rather than a compressive pathology and hence pupil sparing occurs.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3125.
Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, Page 799.

questions.text: The serum calcium level is regulated by which of the following hormones?
questions.solution:
1. In addition to having significant impacts on bone formation and bone resorption, vitamin D has a strong influence on increasing calcium absorption from the intestinal tract.

The exchange between extracellular fluid and bone, intestinal reabsorption, and renal excretion are all regulated by parathyroid hormone.

deficiency of PTH leads to hypocalcemia, which frequently results in tetany. excess of PTH  results in the fast release of calcium salts from the bones and hypercalcemia in the extracellular fluid.

The thyroid gland's peptide hormone, calcitonin, tends to lower plasma levels of calcium. In general, it has the opposite effects of PTH.

To summarise remember the story of calcium metabolism as follows 

Whenever there is Calcium and Phosphate in blood, it will deposit in bone in form of Ca appatite. Vit D causes increased absorption of Ca and Phosphate from intestine and thereby deposits it in Bones. The prime role of Calcitonin is preventing the Ca from bone to reach the blood, or making it stay put in bones. 
Parathormone doesn’t care about anything else but Calcium, it increases Ca absorption via Vit D from GIT, but as vit D increases Phosphate absorption also, PTH causes excretion of Phosphate via urine to prevent the calcium from going into bone as Calcium appatite. 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 372,373,374,377

questions.text: Which of the following drugs promote bone formation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Teriparatide 

Drug that promotes bone formation is Teriparatide.
Drugs promoting bone formation are called anabolic drugs

* [Extra Edge]: Teriparatide
 
  • This recombinant preparation of 1–34 residues of amino terminal of human PTH has been recently introduced for the treatment of severe osteoporosis. It duplicates all the actions of the long (1–84) PTH.
  • Injected s.c. 20 mg once daily, it acts only for 2–3 hours, and has been found to increase bone mineral density in osteoporotic women. The effect was faster and more marked than that produced by estrogens and bisphosphonates (BPNs).
  • Teriparatide is the only agent which stimulates new bone formation, whereas the other two only check bone resorption.
  • In clinical trials it was found to be equally or more effective than estrogens and BPNs in reducing risk of vertebral as well as non-vertebral fractures in osteoporotic women as well as men.
  • Treatment with teriparatide beyond 2 years is not recommended, but BPNs may be continued thereafter. Side effects include dizziness, headache and leg cramps. 
* Other Options are either work by decreasing bone resorption or inhibiting it, no other drug stimulates new bone formation.

* Examples:
  • (a) TERIPARATIDE: a Parathyroid hormone (PTH) analog
  • (b) ABOLAPARATIDE: a PTH receptor peptide analog
  • (c) STRONTIUM RONELATE: anti-osteoporotic agent
  • (d) ROMOSUZUMAB: sclerostin glycoprotein inhibitor

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 365.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most commonly linked to congenital adrenal hyperplasia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 2. Female pseudohermaphroditism
 
  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) most often appears as female pseudohermaphroditism, with the most common enzyme deficiency being 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  • A female pseudohermaphrodite is a genetically typical female (46, XX) whose external genitalia resemble those of a male.
 
  • Children with 21-hydroxylase deficiency typically present between 10 and 14 days of age with a range of symptoms resulting from aldosterone deficiency, cortisol deficiency, and androgen excess.
  • Aldosterone deficiency leads to salt-wasting crises, characterized by hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypotension, and metabolic acidosis. Cortisol deficiency results in symptoms such as hypoglycemia, hyperpigmentation, weight loss, weakness, anorexia, vomiting, and shock.
 
  • Androgen excess in 21-hydroxylase deficiency causes virilization in females, leading to female pseudohermaphroditism, and precocious puberty in males. In females, virilization is typically noticeable at birth, while in males, it becomes apparent by 2 to 3 years of age. Without treatment, severe complications such as shock, cardiac arrhythmias, and death may occur within days or weeks.

Other options:
 
  • Option 1: Male pseudohermaphroditism is seen in CAH due to 17α-hydroxylase deficiency, which leads to incomplete virilization. This is the second most common enzyme deficiency in CAH.
  • Option 3: True hermaphroditism, now called ovotesticular disorder of sex development (DSD), involves the presence of both ovarian and testicular tissue and is not related to CAH.
  • Option 4: 46 XY intersex (now termed 46 XY DSD) involves under-virilization of the genitalia. Adrenal causes include lipoid adrenal hyperplasia, 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency, and 17-hydroxylase/17,20-lyase deficiency, but not 21-hydroxylase deficiency.




Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 2973, 2974, 2977, 3025.

questions.text: Which of the following does not have the Na-I symporter (NIS)?
questions.solution:
Sodium- iodine cotransporters are present in thyroid, stomach, salivary gland, lactating mammary glands, placenta, ovaries.

  • Treatment with teriparatide beyond 2 years is not recommended, but BPNs may be continued thereafter. Side effects include dizziness, headache and leg cramps. 
* Other Options are either work by decreasing bone resorption or inhibiting it, no other drug stimulates new bone formation.

questions.text: Niacin therapy is not recommended for people with diabetes because:
questions.solution:
Niacin is known to increase blood glucose levels - hence, caution is to be exercised if using Niacin in any patient with Diabetes. 

Niacin induces insulin resistance and also decreases glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, which may result in severe hyperglycemia.





Reference: Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 613.

  • Thyroxin

  • GPCR - remaining vast majority of hormones (Non PIG)

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient has both hypertension and diabetes mellitus. He presents with late-stage chronic kidney disease. Which anti-diabetic medication of the following needs the least dose adjustment in renal disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Linagliptin
 
  • Linagliptin is an anti-diabetic drug that requires least dose modification in case of renal disease.
  • Linagliptin is one of the DPP-4 inhibitor drugs
* Other DPP-4 inhibitors used as anti-diabetic are:
  • Sitagliptin
  • Vildagliptin
  • Saxagliptin
  • Alogliptin
All DPP-4 inhibitors require dose adjustment in renal failure except Linagliptin since it has hepatic excretion. 

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1039.

questions.text: Which of these is not associated with Thymoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: SIADH 

About 40% of thymomas present with symptoms stemming from impingement on mediastinal structures. Another 30% to 45% are detected in the course of evaluating patients with myasthenia gravis. 

In addition to myasthenia gravis, other associated autoimmune disorders include:
  1. Hypogammaglobulinemia
  2. Pure red cell aplasia
  3. Graves disease
  4. Pernicious anemia
  5. Dermatomyositis
  6. Polymyositis and
  7. Cushing syndrome

questions.text: Anti-diuretic hormone secretion was observed to be elevated in a patient after head trauma. Which of the following conclusions does not apply to this situation?
questions.solution:
Increased absorption of Na+ and H2O into circulation causing hypertension. Increased excretion of K+ and and H2O into tubule resulting in hypokalemia & metabolic alkalosis. SIADH is characterised by excessive unsuppressible release of ADH either from Posterior Pituitary Gland or an abnormal non-pituitary source.

Lab findings—

i. Decreased serum osmolarity ( < 275 mOsm/Kg ) ii. Increased Urine Osmolarity ( > 100 mOsm/Kg ) iii. Urinary Sodium > 40 mmol/L with normal dietary intake iv. Normal thyroid & Adrenal function

v. Normal renal function, No hydrocephalus, No Acid Base Disorders vi. Clinical euvolemia.

questions.text: A female patient receiving tamoxifen therapy has unilateral breast cancer. Which of the following negative effects is connected to tamoxifen use?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Endometrial carcinoma

Endometrial carcinoma is the adverse effect associated with the use of tamoxifen.

* Following are the side effects of tamoxifen:
  • Selective estrogen activation effect (due to which blood clots, stroke and endometrial cancer is seen)
  • Increased tumor or bone pain
  • Hot flashes
  • Mood swings and depression
  • Hair thinning
  • Constipation
  • Loss of libido

questions.text: Low calcium and high phosphate are observed in the case of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Primary Hypoparathyroidism
 
  • Hypoparathyroidism is a condition characterized by insufficient production or secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH) by the parathyroid glands.PTH plays a crucial role in regulating calcium and phosphate levels in the body.
  • In hypoparathyroidism, the low or absent levels of PTH result in decreased calcium reabsorption from the kidneys and reduced release of calcium from bones.
  • As a result, blood calcium levels tend to be low (hypocalcemia), while phosphate levels in the blood tend to be high (hyperphosphatemia).
 
  • Hyperparathyroidism, on the other hand, is characterized by excessive production of PTH by the parathyroid glands. In this condition, blood calcium levels tend to be high (hypercalcemia), and phosphate levels may be normal or low.
  • Hyperthyroidism (overactive thyroid) and hypothyroidism (underactive thyroid) primarily affect thyroid hormone levels and do not directly cause low calcium and high phosphate levels.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3163, 3185-3187.

questions.text: Which metabolic process best characterises the creation of active vitamin D?
questions.solution:
The pathway that describes the synthesis active vitamin D is:
Skin - liver - kidney
 
  • In skin 7-dehydrocholesterol is converted to cholecalciferol 
  • The liver converts vitamin D to 25OHD ( Storage form of Vitamin D )
  • The kidney converts 25OHD to 1,25(OH)2D ( Active form of vitamin D ) and 24,25(OH)2D.


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 372,373

Combined oral contraceptive pills act by all of the following mechanics except by increase in gonadotrophin secretion.

* For the combined oral contraceptives, main mechanism of action are as follows-
  • Inhibition of follicular development,
  • Inhibition of ovulation, and as consequence, corpus luteum formation.

questions.text: The following statement about pseudohypoparathyroidism is false:
questions.solution:
1. Decrease serum PTH  is the False statement about pseudohypoparathyroidism.

PSEUDOHYPOPARATHYROIDISM
 
  • PHP refers to a group of distinct inherited disorders. Patients affected by PHP type Ia (PHP1A) develop symptoms and signs of hypocalcemia in association with distinctive skeletal and developmental defects, referred to as Albright’s hereditary osteodystrophy (AHO). The hypocalcemia is due to a deficient PTH response in the proximal renal tubules.
  • Patients affected by PHP type Ib (PHP1B) also present with hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia but less frequently with obvious AHO features.
  • In response to the hypocalcemia observed in either disorder, PTH levels increase, leading to parathyroid hyperplasia and, in some cases, to autonomous PTH secretion.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3188, 3189.

questions.text: Which category does the receptors for dopamine, noradrenaline, and adrenaline fall under?
questions.solution:
Cell surface receptors are usually of three types:

1.  Ion channel-linked receptors (Ligand-gated or voltage-gated)
2. Enzyme-linked receptors
3. GPCR (G Protein-coupled receptors)

The receptors for adrenaline, noradrenaline, and dopamine (catecholamines) are G- protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs).
GPCRs span the cell membrane 7 times; hence are also referred to as seven pass (seven helix) or serpentine receptors.(option 3)



Reference: Ganong's Review Of Medical physiology, 26th Edition Page no: 59

questions.text: Identify the drug that acts through intracellular receptors.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Thyroxin

Only Thyroxine acts through intracellular receptors all other act via cell membrane receptors.

* [Extra Edge]:
  • Both T 3 and T4 penetrate cells by active transport and produce majority of their actions by combining with a nuclear thyroid hormone receptor (TR) which belongs to the steroid and retinoid superfamily of intracellular receptors.
  • Two TR isoform families (TRα and TRβ) have been identified. Both bind T 3 and function in similar manner, but their tissue distribution differs, which may account for quantitative differences in the sensitivity of different tissues to T3.
  • In contrast to the steroid receptor, the TR resides in the nucleus even in the unliganded inactive state. It is bound to the ‘thyroid hormone response element’ (TRE) in the enhancer region of the target genes along with corepressors

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 363.

questions.text: A patient reports hypoglycemia-related symptoms. Investigations show elevated insulin levels and lowered blood glucose. The results of the C-peptide assay indicate normal levels of C-peptide. The following is the likely cause:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Accidental exogenous insulin administration
 
  • Elevated insulin levels and lowered blood glucose indicate the presence of exogenous insulin in the body.
  • C-peptide levels, which reflect endogenous insulin production, are normal.
  • This scenario suggests that the patient has inadvertently received additional insulin, leading to hypoglycemia-related symptoms.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3132, 3133.

questions.text: Which of the following is most physically and functionally related to HCG?
questions.solution:
Two connected subunits, alpha and beta, make up the glycoprotein known as human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG). The 92 amino acids in alpha unit are comparable to those in thyroid-stimulating hormone, FSH, and LH. (more comparable to LH.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman who had Grave's disease was pregnant and receiving medication for hyperthyroidism. She gave birth to a child who has congenital anomaly aplasia cutis congenita. Which medication is most likely to be responsible for this teratogenic effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Carbimazole
 
  • Most likely drug implicated for this teratogenic effect is carbimazole.
  • Aplasia cutis congenita (ACC) following is seen following utero exposure to antithyroid drugs such as methimazole or carbimazole. 
  • Aplasia cutis congenita (ACC) or aplasia cutis is a rare skin defect characterized by either a focal or extensive absence of the epidermis, dermis, and in some cases the subcutaneous tissue.
  • It may be unifocal or multifocal and involve underlying bone, intracranial, or vascular structures. Although ACC may affect any part of the body, the scalp is most commonly affected.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 952.
Online Reference: P. Bowman, N.J. Osborne, R. Sturley, B. Vaidya, Carbimazole embryopathy: implications for the choice of antithyroid drugs in pregnancy, QJM: An International Journal of Medicine, Volume 105, Issue 2, February 2012, Pages 189–193, https://doi.org/10.1093/qjmed/hcq248

questions.text: Select the condition that is associated with peripheral artery disease, coronary heart disease and stroke.
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Insulin deficiency
 
  • All the above complications are seen in Diabetes mellitus which is characterised by either Insulin deficiency (Type 1 DM) or Insulin resistance (Type 2 DM)
 
  • Type 1 DM is the result of interactions of genetic, environmental, and immunologic factors that ultimately lead to immune-mediated destruction of the pancreatic beta cells and insulin deficiency.

Macrovascular complications of Diabetes include:
  1. Coronary heart disease
  2. Peripheral arterial disease
  3. Cerebrovascular disease


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3099, 3120.

choices.text: Pseudohyponatremia is associated with low plasma osmolality
Hyponatremia associated with hyperglycemia has high plasma osmolality

questions.text: The following statement about hyponatremia is false:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  Pseudohyponatremia is associated with low plasma osmolality 

Pseudohyponatremia refers to a laboratory artifact where the measured sodium level appears low due to an abnormal distribution of plasma water, typically caused by high lipid or protein content in the blood. However, the plasma osmolality remains normal in pseudohyponatremia. Therefore, statement 1 is false.
 
  • Statement 2 is true. Hyponatremia associated with hyperglycemia can occur in conditions like diabetic ketoacidosis, where the high glucose levels draw water into the extracellular space, leading to dilutional hyponatremia. In this case, the plasma osmolality is high.
  • Statement 3 is true. Hyponatremia associated with syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) is characterized by excessive retention of water, leading to dilutional hyponatremia. It typically occurs in normovolemic or hypervolemic states.
  • Statement 4 is true. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can enhance the effects of vasopressin (antidiuretic hormone), leading to increased water reabsorption in the kidneys and potential development of hyponatremia.
 
  1. Hyponatremia:
    • Hypovolemic hyponatremia: Decreased sodium, decreased extracellular fluid volume, increased urine osmolality.
    • Euvolemic hyponatremia (e.g., SIADH): Decreased sodium, normal extracellular fluid volume, increased urine osmolality.
    • Hypervolemic hyponatremia (e.g., heart failure): Decreased sodium, increased extracellular fluid volume, decreased urine osmolality.
    • Hyponatremia associated with hyperglycemia (e.g., diabetic ketoacidosis): Decreased sodium, normal or increased extracellular fluid volume, increased plasma osmolality.
  2. Pseudohyponatremia:
    • Pseudohyponatremia due to hyperlipidemia: Decreased measured sodium, normal plasma osmolality.
    • Pseudohyponatremia due to hyperproteinemia: Decreased measured sodium, normal plasma osmolality:





Note: In pseudohyponatremia, the measured sodium level is decreased, but the true sodium concentration is normal.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 341-343.

questions.text: Which of the following does not prevent T4 to T3 conversion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Methimazole
 
  • Methimazole and carbimazole do not block the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.
  • Methimazole and carbimazole interfere with the oxidation of the iodide ion and iodotyrosyl groups. Eventually, thyroglobulin gets depleted and circulating thyroid hormone levels decrease.
  • All other drugs mentioned prevent conversion of T4 to T3. Thus Propranolol and Propylthiouracil are used in management of Thyroid storm.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 269.

questions.text: Males with hypergonadotropic hypogonadism are all of the following, with the exception of:

Amongst the given options, Kallman's syndrome (option 3) is a cause of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism while Viral orchitis, Klinefelter's syndrome and Noonan are causes of Hypergonadotropic Hypogonadism. Kallman syndrome has also anosmia.

questions.text: What is the role of the control system in the body?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Maintain a controlled variable at a predefined level
 
  • Control system helps in maintaining Homeostasis which means to maintain body functions at specific predefined normal ranges.
  • Control systems generally maintain homeostasis by negative feedback
  • Control system consists of 4 components :-
  1)STIMULUS
  2) SENSORY RECEPTOR
  3) CONTROL CENTRE
  4)EFFECTOR

 

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition Page no: 7

questions.text: What is bremelanotide used for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Low sexual desire
 
  • Bremelanotide injection (given Sc) is used to treat hypoactive sexual desire disorder (HSDD) in premenopausal women who previously had no problems with sexual desire.
  • Bremelanotide acts as a melanocortin receptor agonist, specifically targeting the melanocortin-4 receptor (MC4R) in the brain. It is believed to increase sexual desire and arousal by stimulating the presynaptic MC4R (causing release of dopamine), which plays a role in regulating sexual function

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 985.

questions.text: The most typical reason for male hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Amongst the given options, only Kallman's syndrome (option 3) is a cause of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism leading to delayed puberty. It also has anosmia. 

Viral orchitis, Klinefelter's syndrome and Radiotherapy to testis are causes of Hypergonadotropic Hypogonadism. (Elevated LH/FSH, low Sex hormones).





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3014, 3020.

choices.text: Secreted separately as a gastrointestinal proactive molecule

questions.text: C-Peptide is not seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Secreted separately as a gastrointestinal proactive molecule 

C-Peptide is a byproduct of the conversion of proinsulin to insulin and is typically secreted in equimolar amounts with insulin, but it is not involved in gastrointestinal activity or secreted separately in that context.

THE FOLLOWING  SEQUENCE DEPICTS THE FORMATION OF INSULIN AND C PEPTIDE AS UNDER :-


 
  • C PEPTIDE is released in equimolar concentrations with Insulin from the pancreatic beta cells.
  • Both Insulin & C peptide are increased in endogenous insulin secretion like Type 2 DM, Insulinoma
  • Exogenous insulin lacks C peptide
 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 425

questions.text: Which is the best agent for premenstrual syndrome management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) SSRI
 
  • Best agent for premenstrual syndrome management is SSRI.
  • SSRIs which show effect due to increase in pregnenolone levels are treatment of choice for pre-menstrual syndrome.
  • Some women develop headache, irritability, fluid retention, distention and breast tenderness a few days preceding menstruation.
  • When depression predominates, it has been labelled ‘premenstrual dysphoric disorder’.
  • Fluoxetine and other SSRIs given daily on symptom days dampen irritability and mood changes in majority of women.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 344.

questions.text: Which of the following Tyrosine Receptor Kinases is affected by Brain-Derived Neurotrophic Factor (BDNF)?
questions.solution:

  • TRK receptors are a family of tyrosine kinases.
  • Each of these receptor types has different binding affinity to certain types of neurotrophins. The different signals initiated by the 3 types of receptors are important for generating diverse biological responses.
  • The three most common types of  TRK  Receptors are  TRK A, TRK B, TRK C.

choices.text: Belongs to a class of Drugs known as SERD

questions.text: Which of the following statements about fulvestrant is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Less effective than SERM
 
  • Fulvestrant is generally considered to be as effective as selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) such as tamoxifen in the treatment of hormone receptor-positive breast cancer. It is a pure estrogen antagonist with no agonist action. Fulvestrant is a selective estrogen-receptor down regulator (SERD).
  • Fulvestrant works differently from SERMs, as it acts as a selective estrogen receptor downregulator (SERD). It not only blocks estrogen receptors but also induces the degradation of the receptors, further reducing estrogen signaling.
  • By blocking and degrading estrogen receptors, fulvestrant helps to inhibit the growth and proliferation of hormone receptor-positive breast cancer cells.
  • It is longer acting and is administered once a month (250- 500mg) intramuscularly. It is generally well tolerated.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 337.

choices.text: Normal person after waking up in morning cortical awakening response

questions.text: Select from the options, where there is elevated ACTH and cortisol levels in the morning in comparison the levels of those hormones in the evening in a human being
questions.solution:
• Corticotropin releasing hormone (CRH) is a hormone naturally produced by the hypothalamus in higher levels of CNS control. This hormone has the ability to stimulate the production of ACTH in the pituitary gland. ACTH is secreted from the pituitary in irregular bursts throughout the day, and the plasma cortisol level varies accordingly.
  • The circadian rhythm is controlled by the suprachiasmatic nucleus of the hypothalamus which causes the highest levels of ACTH secretion to occur before waking up in the morning and diminish late in the afternoon and early evening.
  • Stressors such as physical trauma, exercise, and mental stress can increase ACTH and cortisol secretion in response to the stressor.

Other options:-
 
  • Option 1: In Addison's disease, there is a deficiency of mineralocorticoids and glucocorticoids Cushing's syndrome is characterized by an overproduction of cortisol.
  • Option 2: In normal person after giving dexamethasone the ACTH will be supressed that will lead to decrease in cortisol level.
  • Option 4: Cushing's syndrome is characterized by an overproduction of cortisol. Excess ACTH secretion is the primary cause of Cushing's syndrome and is characterized by an increase of both ACTH and cortisol in the blood. But the diurnal variation won't be there.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2959-2962.
Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th edition, page no 977, 979, 980.

questions.text: Except for______, all of the following are appropriately matched.

questions.text: Pick the one not included in metabolic syndrome, as per NCEP-ARP III
questions.solution:
• The metabolic syndrome is a group of metabolic and cardiovascular health risks that occur together and increase the risk of developing serious health conditions such as diabetes and heart diseases.
  • The main features of the metabolic syndrome are central obesity, high triglycerides, low levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol, high blood sugar, and hypertension.
  • People with these risk factors have a significantly higher risk of developing chronic diseases, such as stroke, heart attack, and type 2 diabetes, compared to people without these risk factors.
  • Therefore, diagnosing and treating these abnormalities early are important for preventing related diseases.


Metabolic syndrome criteria: 






Reference: Williams Textbook of Endocrinology, 14th edition, Page no 1608.

It is a pure estrogen antagonist with no agonist action. Fulvestrant is a selective estrogen-receptor down regulator (SERD).
  • Fulvestrant works differently from SERMs, as it acts as a selective estrogen receptor downregulator (SERD). It not only blocks estrogen receptors but also induces the degradation of the receptors, further reducing estrogen signaling.
  • By blocking and degrading estrogen receptors, fulvestrant helps to inhibit the growth and proliferation of hormone receptor-positive breast cancer cells.

questions.text: What is Addison's disease most commonly associated with?
questions.solution:
Addison's disease is commonly associated with autoimmune adrenalitis.
 
  • In fact, it is the most common cause of Addison's disease in the world.
  • The most common cause of Addison's disease in India is tuberculosis.
     
  • Adrenocortical carcinoma patients display symptoms of Cushing's syndrome, which is an excess of adrenocortical hormones.
  • Hypernephroma and thyroid medullary cancer are not related to Addison's illness.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2970.

questions.text: Diurnal variation in Eosinophil count relates to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Cortisol reduces the Eosinophil count. Therefore, Diurnal variation in Eosinophil count relates to the level of cortisol. 

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC10778409/

questions.text: What is known as "peakless" insulin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Insulin Glargine
 
  • Insulin Glargine, a long-acting insulin analog, is commonly referred to as "peakless" insulin.
  • It is designed to provide a continuous and steady level of insulin activity over an extended duration.
  • Unlike some other insulin formulations, Insulin Glargine has a relatively flat and prolonged action profile, which means it does not have a distinct peak in its activity.
  • This steady release of insulin helps provide basal insulin coverage throughout the day and night, mimicking the body's natural basal insulin secretion pattern.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 287.

questions.text: Choose which is not a symptom of pituitary apoplexy.
questions.solution:
Hypertension is NOT a feature of Pituitary Apoplexy, instead hypotensive shock occurs due to Adrenal insufficiency.
 
  • Pituitary apoplexy is a sudden hemorrhage into the pituitary gland that can be caused by a preexisting adenoma, postpartum syndrome, diabetes, hypertension, sickle cell anemia, or shock.
 
  • Symptoms can include severe headache, diplopia, ophthalmoplegia, hypotension, loss of consciousness, and life-threatening hypotension due to ACTH and cortisol deficiency.
 
  • Diagnosis is usually confirmed with a computed tomography or MRI scan.
 
  • Treatment usually involves high-dose glucocorticoids, but those with significant visual loss, cranial nerve palsy, or loss of consciousness may require urgent surgical decompression.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2897, 2898.

questions.text: Glycogen is incapable of contributing directly to blood glucose In which of the following tissues?
questions.solution:
Muscles can't contribute to blood glucose because they lack the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase which is required to release free glucose into blood stream. 

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 435,436

choices.text: Hypoglycemia is less common than with sulfonylureas

questions.text: Which of the statements is not true about bout meglitinides ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Act by decreasing insulin resistance 
 
  • Meglitinides are oral antidiabetic medications used for type 2 diabetes.
  • Meglitinides work by stimulating insulin release from pancreatic beta cells, which helps to lower blood glucose levels.
  • Meglitinides do not have a direct effect on insulin resistance.
  • They are insulin secretagogues that act by inhibiting the ATP-sensitive K+ channels of the beta cells of the pancreas to cause insulin release.
Anti Diabetic Drugs
Class Examples Mechanism of Action
1. Insulin - Regular insulin- Long-acting (e.g., glargine)- Rapid-acting (e.g., lispro) Mimics natural insulin to control blood glucose.
2. Insulin Secretagogues - DPP-4 Inhibitors: sitagliptin, saxagliptin, linagliptin
 GLP-1 Agonists: exenatide, liraglutide
Sulfonylureas: glibenclamide, glimepiride
 Meglitinides: repaglinide, nateglinide		 Stimulate insulin release from the pancreas.
3. Drugs that Reduce Insulin Resistance - Biguanides: metformin
Thiazolidinediones (TZDs): pioglitazone, rosiglitazone		 Improve insulin sensitivity in muscle and fat.
4. SGLT-2 Inhibitors - Empagliflozin- Canagliflozin Increase glucose excretion by inhibiting renal glucose reabsorption.
5. Alpha-glucosidase Inhibitors - Acarbose- Miglitol Slow carbohydrate breakdown, reducing post-meal blood sugar spikes.
6. Amylin Analogs - Pramlintide Delay gastric emptying and reduce glucagon release.
7. Bile Acid Sequestrants - Colesevelam Improve insulin sensitivity and lower blood glucose.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 296.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a symptom in ACTH deficiency?
questions.solution:
• ACTH deficiencies occur when the body is unable to produce adequate amounts of the hormone ACTH (adrenocorticotropic hormone).
  • This lack of production can be caused by pituitary problems, genetic factors, or the administration of exogenous glucocorticoids. When ACTH levels are decreased, the production of cortisol and aldosterone decreases in turn, which can lead to adrenal atrophy due to the lack of ACTH stimulation.
  • Signs and symptoms of ACTH deficiency are similar to those of Addison's disease and include fatigue, weakness, weight loss, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.
  • However, the serum sodium and potassium levels are usually more normal in secondary adrenal insufficiency compared to Addison's disease and there is no presence of hyperpigmentation.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2971, 2972.

choices.text: Used in the treatment of breast cancer
Slower acting, safer and less effective than SERM
May be administered as 'once a month' dose

questions.text: Which of the statements is not true about Selective Estrogen Receptor Downregulator (SERD), Fulvestrant ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Slower acting, safer and less effective than SERM 
 
  • Fulvestrant is an estrogen antagonist which is indicated in postmenopausal women with hormone-positive breast cancer, which is progressive even after first-line therapy such as tamoxifen.
  • It is longer acting and is administered once a month (250- 500mg) intramuscularly. It is generally well tolerated.
  • It is given as initial biweekly loading doses in the 1st month followed by once-monthly injections. Steady-state levels are achieved in the first month.
  • It is as effective as SERM
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 337.

questions.text:
Patient feels warm and is fatigued; they are not gaining weight. o/e the patient has a staring expression and B/L proptosis. Examination will reveal?
1. Low TSH and High T3/T4
2. High TSH and High T3
3. High TSH and Low free T3
4. Normal TSH and High T3
questions.solution:
•  Thyrotoxicosis is over-functioning of the thyroid gland.
  • It can cause weight loss, despite an enhanced appetite due its increased metabolic rate, as well as hyperactivity, nervousness and irritability, tremor, hyperreflexia, muscle wasting, proximal myopathy, sinus tachycardia, palpitations, widened pulse pressure, aortic systolic murmurs, heat intolerance, palmar erythema, onycholysis, pruritus, urticaria, diffuse hyperpigmentation, fine hair texture, diarrhea, oligomenorrhea and amenorrhea, impaired sexual function, gynecomastia and osteopenia.
  • Depending on the individual, the thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) level may be suppressed, while both total and unbound thyroid hormone levels are increased. In rare cases, there may only be an increase in total triiodothyronine (T3) levels (T3 toxicosis) or an increase in total thyroxine (T4) levels (T4 toxicosis).




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2939, 2940.

questions.text: An exception to presence of Mineralocorticoid Receptors is -
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Liver 
 
  • Mineralocorticoid receptors (MR) are a type of nuclear receptor that specifically binds to mineralocorticoid hormones, such as aldosterone.
  • These receptors are primarily found in target tissues that are involved in electrolyte and fluid balance regulation, such as the kidney, colon, and certain parts of the brain.
  • However, the exception to the presence of mineralocorticoid receptors is the liver (option A).
  • Unlike other target tissues, the liver does not express significant levels of mineralocorticoid receptors.
  • Instead, the liver primarily expresses glucocorticoid receptors (GR), which mediate the effects of glucocorticoid hormones like cortisol.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 1010.

questions.text: Patient had low TSH, however after administering TRH, TSH increased. likely reason?
questions.solution:
• Central Hypothyroidism is a condition of thyroid hormone deficiency caused by a disorder of the pituitary, hypothalamus or the hypothalamic-pituitary portal circulation, resulting in low levels of thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH), thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH), or both.
  • Possible causes of TRH deficiency include diseases of the hypothalamus such as benign and malignant tumors, radiation for certain malignancies, infiltrative lesions, infections, traumatic brain injury and stroke.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2932, 2933.

questions.text: A patient is suffering from weight gain and lassitude. What could be the cause if tests revealed elevated TSH and low T4?
questions.solution:
Hashimoto’s disease is the possible diagnosis in this scenario.

Increased TSH with low T4 -> Hypothyroidism
  • Graves disease -> Hyperthyroidism (Most common cause)
  • Hashimoto -> Increased TSH with low T4
  • Pituitary adenoma -> TSH secreting adenoma shows increased TSH, T3, T4
  • Hypoparathyroidism ->No increased TSH or low T4

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2933, 2936.

questions.text: Except for__________, all of the following result in secondary hyperparathyroidism.
questions.solution:
Parathyroid adenoma will result in primary hyperparathyroidism.

Causes of secondary hyperparathyroidism ie hyperparathyroidism due to other underlying diseases:
  • i. Chronic Renal Failure
  • ii. Malabsorption syndrome
  • iii. Vitamin D deficiency
  • iv. Medullary carcinoma thyroid



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3172-3174.

questions.text: Phosphate in urine in excess leads to osteomalacia. Lab findings include low serum phosphate levels, Normal PTH and Normal Vitamin D level. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The diagnosis most likely associated with excess phosphate in urine leading to osteomalacia is Vitamin D resistance.
  • This condition, also known as hereditary vitamin D-resistant rickets (HVDRR), leads to problems with phosphate and calcium metabolism, contributing to weakened bones and osteomalacia despite normal or elevated levels of vitamin D.

Laboratory findings of Vitamin D-resistant rickets:
  • Raised alkaline phosphatase (ALP)
  • Hypophosphatemia
  • Hyperphosphaturia
  • Normal or mild decreased 1, 25 (OH) D3
  • Normal PTH level



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3162, 3168.

questions.text: A patient with known diabetes and hypertension was discovered on the side of the road in the morning, unconscious, with a pulse rate of 120 beats per minute and a bilateral plantar extensor response. What should we do as soon as possible?
questions.solution:
It is critical to check the blood glucose measurements of the patient since they are diabetic, before intervening, as a way of ruling out a hypoglycemic coma.

Clinical features of Hypoglycemia:
  • Neuroglycopenic manifestations of hypoglycemia are the direct result of central nervous system glucose deprivation.
  • These features include behavioral changes, confusion, fatigue, seizure, loss of consciousness, cardiac arrhythmias, and, if hypoglycemia is severe, death.
  • Neurogenic (or autonomic) manifestations of hypoglycemia result from the perception of physiologic changes caused by the central nervous system–mediated sympathoadrenal discharge that is triggered by hypoglycemia.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3129, 3130.

choices.text: 5 kg baby delivered five years prior, and the numerous blood transfusions that followed. After giving birth, she never started her period again, and she also experienced lactation problems.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old lady complains of being tired and lethargic when she visits the medicine office. She recalls having a 3.5 kg baby delivered five years prior, and the numerous blood transfusions that followed. After giving birth, she never started her period again, and she also experienced lactation problems.
Which diagnosis is more likely?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Sheehan syndrome.
  • The most likely diagnosis in this case is Sheehan syndrome, also known as postpartum pituitary necrosis.
  • Sheehan syndrome is characterized by pituitary gland damage due to severe postpartum hemorrhage, leading to hormonal imbalances and symptoms such as fatigue, amenorrhea, and lactation problems.
  • The most common hormone deficiency in Sheehan syndrome is hypothyroidism (thyroid gland does not produce enough thyroid hormone).
  • The patient's symptoms of tiredness, lethargy, and lack of menstruation are consistent with hypothyroidism. The fact that she had a large baby and needed multiple blood transfusions during childbirth suggests that she may have had Sheehan syndrome.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2890.

questions.text: A female patient with altered sensorium was taken to the emergency room. Upon assessment, the patient's blood pressure was 88/67 mm Hg and her pulse was 60 beats per minute. 34°C was the rectal temperature. Menorrhagia, dry skin, and constipation had a history of being related. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Myxedema coma is a potentially life-threatening condition that can occur in patients with hypothyroidism, typically elderly people.
 
  • It is characterized by altered sensorium, hypotension, bradycardia, hypothermia and other symptoms of hypothyroidism. Patent also had history of menorrhagia, drynskin, constipation.
 
  • It is usually fatal despite intensive treatment and is usually triggered by factors that affect respiration, such as certain drugs, pneumonia, heart failure and other medical problems.
 
  • Exposure to cold may also be a factor. Hypoventilation, hypoxia, hypercapnia and hypoglycemia all play major roles in the development of myxedema coma.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2934, 2937.

questions.text:
A diabetic female patient who had previously eaten outside food was admitted with frequent vomiting.
BP is 90/60 mmHg. pH: 7.52. HCO3-  is 26.
PaCO2: 20+. Na-123, Potassium-3.2, and Chloride-67 meq/l are the electrolytes. What is the reason behind her ABG results?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Persistent vomiting.

The arterial blood gas (ABG) results show:
  1. pH: 7.52, indicating alkalosis as the pH is above the normal range (7.35-7.45).
  2. HCO3-: 26 mEq/L, showing elevated bicarbonate levels, which is a sign of metabolic alkalosis.
  3. PaCO2: 20+ mmHg, suggesting possible respiratory compensation for the metabolic alkalosis.
  • Based on the ABG results and low electrolyte levels, the most likely reason for her condition is persistent vomiting, leading to metabolic alkalosis. 
  • Vomiting causes loss of hydrochloric acid from the stomach, resulting in an alkalotic state.

Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 361, 365.

choices.text: William syndrome consists of precocious puberty, mental retardation and obesity
In absence of sunlight daily requirement of vitamin D is 400-600 IU
1-alpha hydroxylation of vitamin D occurs in kidney
25-alpha hydroxylation of vitamin D occurs in liver

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Williams syndrome is a developmental disorder that affects many parts of the body. This condition is characterized by mild to moderate intellectual disability or learning problems, unique personality characteristics, distinctive facial features, and heart and blood vessel (cardiovascular) problems.
"Vitamin D is hydroxylated twice, once in the liver and then again in the kidney to produce the hormone 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol. 7-dehydrocholesterol is converted to cholecalciferol in the skin on exposure to sunlight. Cholecalciferol is then converted to 25-hydroxy-cholecalciferol in the liver by 25-hydroxylation. 25-hydroxycholeecalciferol is then converted to 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol, the active form of vitamin D, in the kidney by I-hydroxylation.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3166-3169.

choices.text: Low plasma rennin activity that is not stimulated by volume depletion
Hyperaldosteronism, i.e. increased aldosterone secretion which is not suppressed by volume expansion

questions.text: Which of the following does not meet the criteria for primary hyperaldosteronism?
questions.solution:
Primary hyperaldosteronism is associated with metabolic alkalosis and not metabolic acidosis.

Criteria for Diagnosis of Primary Hyperaldosteronism include:

•Diastolic hypertension without edema.
•Hypersecretion of aldosterone that does not suppress appropriately in response to volume expansion
•Low plasma rennin levels.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2964-2966.

choices.text: Serum sodium can be as low as 125 mEq/L
Urine sodium is usually normal or slightly low
Vaptans are new FDA approved drugs for its treatment
Water loading test can be used for diagnosis

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about SIADH?
questions.solution:
SIADH is typically characterized by high urinary sodium (Increased rate of excretion of sodium). SIADH is associated low serum sodium levels (<135 meq/L). Vaptans are new FDA approved agents for treatment of SIADH. Patients with SIADH excrete <90% of the water load within four hours and do not produce urine osmolality <100 mOsm/kg. Serum and urine osmolalities are measured .This is known as water loading test.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 342, 2924.

questions.text:
At what point is diabetes mellitus diagnosed?
1. Fasting blood glucose is \(\geq\)100 mg/dL and post prandial glucose is \(\geq\)140 mg/dL
2. Fasting blood glucose \(\geq\)125 mg/dL and post prandial glucose is \(\geq\)199 mg/mL
3. Level of plasma insulin is \(\geq\)6 IU/dL
4. HbA1C level is > 6.5%
questions.solution:
Glycosylated Haemoglobin (HbA1C) values of> 6.5% represents an independent criteria/or diagnosis of Diabetes Mellitus in accordance with the criteria set by the American Diabetic Association, 2024.

Criteria for diagnosis of Diabetes mellitus (Any one of the following):





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3095.

questions.text: Thomas Addison made the first mention of Addison's illness. There are still several reports about it coming in from throughout the globe. Which of the following causes of Addison's disease is more prevalent in India?
questions.solution:
• Most common cause of Addison disease in India is tuberculous adrenalitis.
 
  • The commonest cause of adrenal insufficiency (Addison s disease) in developing countries like India is Tuberculosis, followed by autoimmune disorders.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2970, 2971.

choices.text: A parathyroid hormone-related protein is responsible for causing hypercalcemia in cancer patients
The unionised fraction of calcium in the plasma is an important determinant of PTH secretion

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true?
questions.solution:
Circulating ionized calcium acts directly on the parathyroid gland and acts in a negative feedback fashion to regulate the secretion of PTH. Hypercalcemia is  a common metabolic complication of cancer parathyroid hormone related protein produced by tumour cells( Paraneoplastic syndrome).
Magnesium is required to maintain normal parathyroid secretory responses. Impaired PTH release along with diminished target responses to PTH account for the hypocalcaemia that occasionally occurs in magnesium deficiency.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3170-3172.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl who was evaluated for her short height was found to have an enlarged pituitary gland. Her T4 was decreased, and her TSH was increased. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
With long standing hypothyroidism, thyrotroph hyperplasia can result in expansion of sella turcica and the enlargement of the pituitary gland. This may mimic pituitary tumour.
In long standing hypothyroidism, the negative feedback of thyroid hormones on hypothalamus is lost. This results in increase secretion of thyrotropin releasing hormone (TRH) from the hypothalamus. This in turn causes hyperplasia and proliferation of the thyrotrophic cells of the pituitary.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2933, 2935.

questions.text: An elderly female presents with the nasal blockade and nasal discharge with black debris. Blood sugar was raised and urine is positive for ketones. Best treatment for the patient would be:
questions.solution:
Best treatment for the patient is amphotericin B

The peri-orbital region and vision impairment are involved in the mucormycosis that this diabetic patient most certainly has, according to the most recent research. All kinds of Mucormycosis are most frequently treated with intravenous (iv) Amphotericin B. Another antifungal used is Posaconazole. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1682-1685.

questions.text: The following is not true about Hashimoto's thyroiditis:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Examination shows reduced TSH level.
 
  1. Hashimoto's thyroiditis: An autoimmune disorder, where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks the thyroid gland.
  2. Oncocytic metaplasia is a characteristic feature of Hashimoto's thyroiditis but not pathognomonic (definitive) for the condition. It is a histological finding of large cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm.
  3. Hashimoto's thyroiditis can present with hyperthyroidism during the early phases of the disease. This is known as "Hashitoxicosis" or "painless thyroiditis".
  4. Examination reveals elevated TSH level due to reduced thyroid hormone production as the feedback inhibition is removed. 


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2935, 2936.

choices.text: Most common site is the para-aortic sympathetic chain
Vascular invasion may occur in benign lesions

questions.text: The following statement is correct regarding pheochromocytoma:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Vascular invasion may occur in benign lesions.
 
  • Pheochromocytoma is a rare neuroendocrine tumor.
  • It originates from chromaffin cells in the adrenal medulla or sympathetic ganglia.
  • Most commonly, pheochromocytomas arise in the adrenal medulla.
  • While usually benign, they can exhibit vascular invasion, mimicking malignant characteristics.
  • Pheochromocytoma is associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN-2), not MEN-1.
  • Approximately 10% of cases are malignant, not 40%.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2976, 2977, 2979.

questions.text: Which of these is true regarding a disturbance in thyroid function?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: There is increased cholesterol in hypothyroidism.
 
  • Thyroid hormones regulate metabolism. Hypothyroidism results from insufficient thyroid hormone production, causing a slowed metabolism, weight gain, fatigue, and reduced heart rate.
  • In hypothyroidism, there is often weight gain and increased cholesterol levels.
  • Hypothyroidism may cause constipation, but not diarrhea.
  • Palpitations and tachycardia are characteristic of hyperthyroidism, not hypothyroidism.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2935, 2936.

questions.text: Most virulent form of Medullary carcinoma thyroid is seen in which type of MEN syndrome:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: MEN - 2B
 
  • Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid (MCT) is a thyroid cancer arising from C-cells.
  • MCT can be linked to multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndromes, genetic disorders causing tumors in multiple endocrine glands.
  • MEN-2B is the most virulent form of MCT, characterized by MCT, pheochromocytoma, and mucosal neuromas.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2988, 2989.

questions.text: Primary Adrenal Insufficiency causes all of the following, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Increased protein breakdown 
 
  • Addison's disease is a primary adrenal insufficiency in which the adrenal is unable to secrete adequate amounts of cortisol (glucocorticoid), aldosterone (mineralocorticoid), and sex hormones. The most common cause of Addison's disease is autoimmune adrenalitis. 
  • Symptoms include:
  1. Low blood pressure
  2. Decrease in extracellular fluid (ECF)
  3. Decreased sodium-potassium ratio  due to reduced aldosterone levels.
  • However, increased protein breakdown (D) is not a typical symptom of primary adrenal insufficiency. People with Addison's disease may actually have increased protein levels in their blood as their bodies try to conserve protein.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2971, 2972.

questions.text: The syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) has which of the following characteristics?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Hypertension
 
  • Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone ADH release (SIADH) is a condition where there is an unsuppressed release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) from the pituitary gland or nonpituitary sources or its continued action on vasopressin receptors.
 
  • Clinical features of SIADH:
    • Hyponatremia (low blood sodium levels)
    • Decreased urination
    • Confusion
    • Fatigue
    • Weakness
    • Muscle cramps
    • High blood pressure- due to increased blood volume 

The other given clinical features are more classic of pheochromocytoma.

Laboratory findings of SIADH :





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 342, 2924.

questions.text: Where is CDKN1B gene mutation implicated ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: MEN-4
 
  • CDKN1B gene mutation is linked to Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 4 (MEN-4), a rare genetic disorder.
  • MEN-4 results from mutations in the CDKN1B gene, which codes for the p27 protein involved in regulating cell division.
  • These mutations can disrupt p27's normal function, leading to uncontrolled cell growth and tumor development in various endocrine glands.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2984, 2990.

questions.text: What is suggested by early morning hyperglycemia with decreased blood glucose of 2.00 AM ?
questions.solution:
Option is 3: Somogyi effect 
 
  • Early morning hyperglycemia with decreased blood glucose of 2.00 AM suggests the Somogyi effect.
  • The Somogyi effect is also known as "rebound hyperglycemia" in diabetes management.
  • It occurs when the body responds to nighttime hypoglycemia by releasing counterregulatory hormones, leading to elevated blood sugar levels in the morning.

Other options:
  • Insufficient insulin would lead to persistent high blood sugar levels, not the specific pattern seen in the Somogyi effect.
  • The Dawn Phenomenon is a separate phenomenon involving mild morning blood sugar elevation due to natural hormonal release for waking up.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3811.

questions.text: What is the likely cause of no increase in the osmolarity of urine , In a patient who has been given an administration of exogenous vasopressin ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Renal Hyposensitivity to ADH 
 
  • Exogenous vasopressin, also known as ADH (antidiuretic hormone), is naturally produced by the pituitary gland and regulates water retention in the kidneys.
  • When ADH is released,prompts the kidneys to reabsorb more water, leading to increased urine osmolarity.
  • If a patient is given exogenous vasopressin, or synthetic ADH, and  osmolarity of their urine does not increase, it indicates renal hyposensitivity to ADH (Nephrogenic DI). This means that the kidneys are not responding to ADH as they should, and are not reabsorbing as much water as they should.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2921, 2922.

questions.text: Mainstay of treatment of Nephrogenic Diabetes Insipidus is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Thiazide/Amiloride diruetics and salt restriction 

Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI) results due to resistance to the antidiuretic action of AVP (arginine vasopressin) leading to the production of large amounts of dilute urine and dehydration.

NDI mainstay treatment:
  • Thiazide and Amiloride diuretics increase water reabsorption by the kidneys, reducing urine output.
  • Salt restriction helps to further conserve water and prevent excessive loss in the urine.
  • Thiazides are used in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus due to their paradoxical anti-diuretic action. These are the first-line drugs used in the treatment of Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. 
  • The treatment of choice in a Lithium-associated nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is Amiloride.
  • Loop diuretic acts on the N+ K+ 2Cl- symporter, but is not given in diabetes insipidus as it can worsen the condition.

Water deprivation test analysis :





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2922.

questions.text: Which of the following is not related with hypothyroidism?
questions.solution:
Elevated Cholesterol is a feature of Hypothyroidism, NOT Low Cholesterol.
 
  • A normal TSH level excludes primary (but not secondary) hypothyroidism. If the TSH is elevated, a free or unbound T4 level (FT4 ) is needed to confirm the presence of clinical hypothyroidism.
  • T3 is also low in majority of hypothyroid patients.
 
  • Other abnormal laboratory findings in hypothyroidism may include increased creatine phosphokinase, elevated cholesterol and triglycerides, and anemia (usually normocytic or macrocytic).

Evaluation for Hypothyroidism: 





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2935, 2936.

choices.text: Sleep EEG studies have shown disruption in REM sleep
SPECT studies have reduced blood flow to the thalamus

questions.text: Which of the following is true for fibromyalgia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: SPECT studies have reduced blood flow to the thalamus 
 
  • Fibromyalgia is characterized by chronic widespread musculoskeletal pain and tenderness. It is more common in females. 
  • Patients with fibromyalgia have an increased prevalence of other syndromes associated with pain and fatigue, including chronic fatigue syndrome, chronic headaches, irritable bowel syndrome, interstitial cystitis/ painful bladder syndrome, and pelvic pain syndromes.
  • Anti-polymer antibody may be seen in 50% of patients. 
  • Single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) studies done on fibromyalgia patients show hypoperfusion of the thalamus.
Other options:
 
  • Sleep EEG studies have shown disruption in non-REM sleep, not REM sleep.
  • Cortisol levels in fibromyalgia patients are typically within the normal range.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2868-2870.

questions.text: The emergence of hyperthyroidism after supplementary iodine treatment to people with endemic iodine deficient goitre is termed as:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Jod-Basedow effect
 
  • The Jod-Basedow effect is due to overactivation of the thyroid gland or autonomous nodules within the gland after iodine repletion without adequate feedback control from the pituitary gland.
  • This phenomenon does not occur in individuals with normal thyroid gland.
  • In iodine-deficient areas, the thyroid gland cannot produce enough hormones due to the lack of iodine. When excess iodine is introduced suddenly, it causes the thyroid to produce and release more hormones, leading to hyperthyroidism.

Other options:
 
  • Wolff-Chaikoff effect: Opposite phenomenon, where a transient inhibition of thyroid hormone synthesis occurs in response to a large amount of iodine exposure.
  • Thyrotoxicosis factitia: Hyperthyroidism caused by the ingestion of excess thyroid hormone.
  •  De Quervain's thyroiditis: Inflammation of the thyroid gland, leading to transient hyperthyroidism followed by hypothyroidism.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2938, 2945.

questions.text: Which option best describes the lowest detection limit for third generation TSH assays?
questions.solution:
Serum TSH is the initial screening test for primary thyroid dysfunction. TSH is a glycoprotein hormone produced by the pituitary gland. It stimulates the thyroid gland to secrete thyroid hormones, which regulate tissue metabolism.

TSH assays are named historically by “generation”; third generation assays are widely used and have a detection limit of 0.01 mIU/L, as compared to first (1 mIU/L) and second generation assays (0.1–0.2 mIU/L).



Reference: Papaleontiou, Maria, and Anne R Cappola. “Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone in the Evaluation of Subclinical Hypothyroidism.” JAMA vol. 316,15 (2016): 1592-1593. doi:10.1001/jama.2016.9534. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5450818/

questions.text: Which of the following has the least likelihood of being connected to gynecomastia?
questions.solution:
• Gynecomastia is a medical condition characterized by the enlargement of male breast tissue. It is caused by an imbalance in the hormones estrogen and testosterone.
  • The condition is often associated with increased levels of estrogen or decreased levels of testosterone in males. Out of the given options, prolactinoma has the least likelihood of being connected to gynecomastia.
  • Prolactinoma is a noncancerous tumor of the pituitary gland that produces high levels of prolactin hormone. Prolactin stimulates milk production in females and can cause breast enlargement and lactation in males. However, the likelihood of prolactinoma causing gynecomastia is lower compared to the other options.
  • Adrenal tumors can produce excess estrogen or androgen hormones, leading to gynecomastia.
  • hCG-secreting tumors can also cause gynecomastia as they stimulate the production of estrogen. Estrogen-secreting tumors can also cause gynecomastia directly by increasing estrogen levels in the body.
 
  • Therefore, based on the above information, option 1, which is prolactinoma, has the least likelihood of being connected to gynecomastia.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2909, 2910, 2967.

questions.text: Except for____, all of the following agents may be used to treat Chronic Hypocalcemia.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Etidronate
 
  • Etidronate is not used for the management of hypocalcemia. It is a bisphosphonate primarily used to treat hypercalcemia.
  • The main goal in managing hypoparathyroidism is to restore the balance of calcium and phosphate in the body.

Other options:
 
  • The mainstay of treatment involves calcium and vitamin D supplements.
  • Thiazide diuretics can be prescribed along with a low-sodium diet to enhance urinary calcium reabsorption.
  • Other underlying conditions contributing to hypocalcemia should also be addressed during the management process.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition, Page no 2936.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in hypothyroidism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Stipulated ribs
Stipulated ribs are not seen in hypothyroidism.

They are small, bony projections that can be seen on the 12th rib in people with certain conditions, such as Marfan syndrome and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

Other options:
 
  • Option 1- Wormian bones: Small, irregular bones that can be seen on the skull
  • Option 3-  Beaking of the vertebra: Tips of the vertebrae become enlarged and pointed. It is also known as bullet shaped vertebra
  • Option 4- Epiphyseal dysgenesis: Growth plates of the bones are affected, which can lead to short stature and other skeletal abnormalities.



Reference: Gutch, Manish et al. “Skeletal manifestations of juvenile hypothyroidism and the impact of treatment on skeletal system.” Indian journal of endocrinology and metabolism vol. 17,Suppl 1 (2013): S181-3. doi:10.4103/2230-8210.119565. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3830298/
